TALK.START.PARA: —You aren't coming back as a senator, so there's not much point, is there?

—Senator Coleman said that I am not coming back as a senator; I gather that she associates with me in this matter. I will be standing for the Senate and I will be back in this place some time, and I believe that will be straight after the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the second reading amendment, which the Democrats have circulated, in respect of the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1987 and move:

At end of motion add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that an additional duty of $2.00 per kilogram should be imposed on uranium concentrate exported from Australia, the proceeds to be used to establish a Trust Fund the money in which would be lent to finance research into alternative energy sources and which would eventually be expended in the rehabilitation of uranium mining sites.''.
I point out that it is extremely important that the Government consider the development of alternative energy resources.

The Democrats will also move to delete clause 4 (c), which exempts the 800 tonnes bought by Queensland Mines Ltd and exported to France. The Government's removal of the embargo on export of uranium to France was a disgraceful breaking of an electoral promise, in relation to which the Government continued to pay lip- service almost right up to the day when it announced the reversal of its policy. This shows the type of gall which this Government has and which is shown again in relation to the forthcoming election; the Government declared that it would have an election, right up to the day when it suddenly decided that it was quite essential for the state of the nation to call an election. This Bill highlights yet again the Labor Government's betrayal of Labor principles, the Government's breaking of election promises, this Government's swindling of the birthright of all Australians and its selling of our resources for its own advantage. The whole history of the Ranger mine is one of Labor Government betrayal of all anti-nuclear and anti-uranium principles.

I urge anybody who values this type of principle to stand up and be counted. Again, we see people within the Labor Party not willing to stand up and be counted. This Bill pays lip service to the need to preserve the environment of the Ranger uranium mine from contamination by mining operations and goes some way to require private enterprise to bear the responsibility for this cost. The Australian Democrats believe that no enterprise can be adequately costed unless it takes full account of the environmental and community costs that are incurred, as well as the direct production costs involved. These costs must be borne directly from the earnings of the enterprise, unless the community benefit is such that it outweighs some proportion of the other costs.

In the case of Ranger, no such community advantage can be demonstrated. The primary resource which is being mined belongs rightfully to the people of Australia and no charge is being made for the loss of that resource. The endangered environment also belongs, firstly, to its legal owners-the Aboriginal people-and, secondly, to the Kakadu region, a national park containing invaluable genetic resources which can be used to increase Australia's genetic pool and which may be endangered by possible accidents and spillages as a result of uranium mining in this area.

By limiting the owner's financial responsibility for the environment to only half the costs, the Government is continuing the myth that business is not responsible for its own mess. This myth has led to enormous damage to our universe, our planet and our environment. Damage to our environment ranges from the health risk caused by smogs in cities and economic damage to farms and forests from acid rain caused by inadequate control of smoke stack effluent, to the loss of all water life and the human health risk caused by manufacturing waste and human excrement fouling up lakes and rivers. All of this is a real problem. Industry has to bear that cost. The Australian Democrats' amendment will make certain that the industry bears the cost to repair the earlier damage to our environment as well as the cost of mining uranium in the Ranger park.

On a more massive scale, the increase in carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere causing heating of the earth's surface and melting of polar ice caps is threatening to drown much of the inhabited coastal areas of the world. Damage to the ozone layer of our outer atmosphere and increasing contamination of the earth's surface by atomic and nuclear waste is leading to increased radiation hazards for all living animals and plants. It is important that the industries which cause this contamination should bear some part of this responsibility. The reason the Bill proposes that a trust fund be set up is to make certain that that responsibility is taken, that money is available for research and understanding what the problems are before they arise, to try to make certain that they will not irrevocably damage our environment. We should make certain that an area such as Kakadu National Park will not be completely destroyed by human intervention. I urge all honourable senators who care about the environment to support the amendment which I have moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the customs legislation, I will briefly touch on a matter mentioned last night by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. I find it quite difficult to come to grips at all with the Government Leader's approach to the Industries Assistance Commission report and the follow through of the legislation. The treatise he put forward in his usual whimsical way was really quite interesting. It would probably have been even more interesting had he delivered it to a meeting of the Fabian Society. He covered at great length subjects such as principle and administrative simplicity and he recited the three-tier arrangements that I think most of us quite plainly have read in the IAC report. He seemed to fail to come to grips with the fact that the potato industry in particular is a very important industry in much of rural Australia. If he were to make that sort of address in the electorates of, say, Macarthur, Ballarat, Barker or Stirling or, of course, Bass and Braddon, I think he would find--
—You missed Lyons.

—And Lyons. I think he would find that his reception might not be as good as that which he received in this environment. As far as my own State is concerned, this is a 200,000 tonne a year industry and it covers a great number of the rural people who grow potatoes either as their prime occupation or as a subsidiary to their prime occupation. It is a very necessary crop for crop rotation. Anything that will affect the overall farming capacity should be considered very carefully. I do not have to declare an interest, because I do not grow potatoes for processing. I used to, but I do not any longer.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it would have been far better had other members of the Cabinet listened to the recommendation that was put forward by both Senator Button and Mr Kerin on this matter. We should look at this matter on the basis of what will be best, not what will be easiest, and that does not seem to have been a consideration. We know who supported the 15 per cent move in the Cabinet and we certainly disagree with the ultimate decision in which those Ministers were overruled by people who obviously have no knowledge of the industry, of what they are doing, or of the flow-on effect. In government, after 11 July, we will see that the Industries Assistance Commission keeps a close watch on the effects of this legislation, and on that understanding we certainly make it clear to the areas involved that we will ensure that bureaucratic simplicity or tidy scales are not the bases on which the decisions should be made. I do not wish to pursue that matter any further but I would like Senator Button to give consideration to the fact that had he tried a little harder he might have been able to do better for the industries that come under this scheme.

Had we had time for a reasonable debate in the Committee stage of the Customs (Valuation) Amendment Bill 1987 we would have moved an amendment to leave out clause 9 on page 6. This matter has been debated very widely in the community. It is a matter on which there is clearly a considerable difference of opinion, and the costs involved and the methods of operation have been questioned considerably. While we support the amendment relating to the valuation provisions, we have expressed many reservations. Accordingly, had we had the opportunity, we would have moved amendments to the effect that this part of the Bill be deleted. The same thing applies to the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. We would have moved for the deletion on pages 8 and 9 of Part V of the Bill, even though this is the section which refers to fertilisers. There is a very real risk in changing the fertiliser subsidy in that the benefit will be passed on to the final user and will encourage greater use of fertilisers. There has been a lot of discussion on the methods that the Government has chosen. We recommend that the Bill not be opposed but that this section be deleted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of 10 Bills that the House is debating today covers a wide range of changes to the customs laws. It includes the regulations tightening up the importation of goods, changes to fertiliser subsidies, allowing duty free importation of passionfruit pulp from the Pacific Islands, letting ball point pens and gas barbecues from New Zealand into the country, reintroducing a tariff on citrus foods, changing of duty rates on petroleum products and so on. By and large the National Party supports these Bills and will not oppose them. We support a planned reduction in the levels of tariff which will remove the cost burden on many primary producers who have had to pay, in indirect support, for secondary industry. We shall be supporting the amendments as to the level to be moved by the Liberal Party. The most important of these concerns the vegetable industry where the Government is planning to reduce assistance across the board to an effective level of 10 per cent. The National Party will be supporting the amendments to change the levels of support to 15 per cent rather than 10 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to emphasise that the National Party is opposed to tariffs. It is accepting these cuts in tariff protection on primary products in good faith, but I would point out that every farmer in Australia pays tariff protection to the level of $9,000 a farm to assist the manufacturing industry mainly in the metropolitan areas of Sydney and Melbourne. There is a transfer of funds from the farm into the secondary industries in the capital cities. Therefore, it is with some degree of reluctance that we see tariffs being reduced on primary products. But I suppose we cannot have it both ways. We cannot say that we are against tariff protection and we are for reducing tariffs on secondary industries, while we are unable to accept changes in tariff protection on primary industries. We feel that there must be an even-handed approach and that tariffs cannot be cut only on primary products. We would expect a cut in tariffs on all secondary industry as well.

I wish to comment on the grocery industry and the importation of primary products. One has only to walk down the aisles of supermarkets to see on the shelves strawberry jam from Bulgaria, pears from Israel, asparagus from Taiwan. One wonders why this is happening when Australia, which has such a wonderful climate and good land, has opportunities to grow and market its own products. Yet we find that we are buying imported products to the detriment of our rural producers. The large retailers must take some responsibility. Only the other day in Queensland I saw on television a news item which drew attention to fruit coming in from the United States of America while our own orchardists were unable to find markets for their products. I am concerned when we see supermarkets with a massive monopoly in the retailing areas. Our rural products are being squeezed out-but not only our rural products. A lot of manufacturing is being adversely affected by monopolies in retail areas. I worked actively for 18 years representing factories in Melbourne and Sydney which sold secondary industry products manufactured in Australia and I also had the agency throughout Queensland. As such, I am concerned that the monopoly is not only affecting our farmers and rural producers but also our secondary industries.

Only last week I opened the newspaper to see that KR Darling Downs, a very big abattoir in my home State, is going down the chute. If not going bankrupt, certainly it is in severe financial difficulty. These people are finding it hard to market their excellent products that have been around Australia for a number of years because the market has shrunk so much. Who is allowed in the market becomes a question of who offers the best discount. I also read, only the other day, that Mr Rouley, the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Farmers Association, is finding the same problem with all that industry's products such as yoghurt, casein and butter. His answer to the problem of finding markets for the many dairy products is to have one large marketing force that would represent the whole of the dairy industry. Mr Acting Deputy President, I know that you share my concern that we are reducing not only our markets into three or four major retailers but now to combat this force we are going down the other track of bringing all our manufacturing products into one selling organisation.

We are facing communism in reverse. We are facing a very narrow retailing sector and a very narrow marketing sector. The number of jobs that will be lost on the way through is tremendous. The solution to Australia's economic problems is to have some type of inquiry to establish just how many jobs are being lost and how many products are being forced off the market by the narrowness of the retail sector. I am concerned that a number of smaller factories and wholesale retailers are suffering. I take as an example the Mitre 10 operation in Queensland. It is a very good operation but a number of stores had to band together to form buying groups to combat the larger retailers. Thus the market has shrunk in the hardware area from 300 or 400 retail outlets. Now factories must go to Mitre 10 or some of the other big wholesale operations and thus compete among the big groups. So manufacturers are forced to deal with just four or five customers. This is certainly shrinking marketing opportunities not only for rural producers but also for manufacturers.

The Bill imposes a flat 10 per cent rate of tariff duty on all imports of processed vegetables. Whereas some vegetable products will have their tariff rates increased, the majority will suffer a significant fall. The overall effect will be significantly to lower assistance to the vegetable industry as well as affecting the large quantity of New Zealand vegetables which enter Australia duty free because of the closer economic relations agreement. The vegetable industry estimates the levels of protection and assistance to be around 7 per cent for canned vegetables, 5 per cent for frozen vegetables, 6 per cent for dehydrated potatoes and 12 per cent for tomato paste. These levels are still below average rates of assistance for the manufacturing industry.

Under the Labor Government assistance to rural industries has been reduced very significantly whereas assistance to secondary industry has increased. The car industry receives significant government grants and help and the steel industry has received massive government help-at the expense of the rural industry which has lost nearly all the assistance that was given to it. This Bill reduces assistance even further. The point of my argument is that rural industries are losing all government assistance. There is now very little left that can be taken from them. Sections of the vegetable industry are very keen to increase exports. We have to provide them with a stable base to do so. I will be giving the amendment my support.

I turn now to the changes in customs duty applicable to petroleum products. The people of Australia will be hearing a lot about petrol prices in the next three or four weeks. I will be reminding them continually that before this Government came to office it promised a reduction in the price of petrol of 3c a litre. But what we have had is a constant increase, indexed quarterly, in the excise on petroleum products. It will be an election plus for the National and Liberal parties when we point out to the people of Australia that the promise of lower petrol prices was another broken promise of the Hawke Government. I will be campaigning continually on this issue. However, in the interests of time-there are many other speakers and we have a guillotine-I will conclude my remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to advise on behalf of the Opposition that we will not be supporting the Australian Democrats' amendments to the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill but that we will be supporting the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be supporting the Australian Democrats' amendments in relation to the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate) Export Duty Amendment Bill. Obviously, more funding is needed to rehabilitate former uranium mines. The Democrats' amendments would see to that. Also more funding is very obviously needed to research alternative energy resources so that Australians do not continue to be tempted to use uranium for energy generation in this country. It is totally unnecessary in Australia and totally unwise on the part of other countries which are presently engaged in the use of uranium for energy production. The nuclear fuel cycle is dangerous at every stage, from the initial mining to the other end of the spectrum where there is still no safe disposal for radioactive leftovers known to humanity. That is despite nearly 40 years of painstaking research on the part of proponents of the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator Vigor's comment that the nuclear industry must be accountable for the mess it has made of the environment. It must be made to clean up its operations. Any uranium mining activity Australia continues to be engaged in should be concerned with clean-up operations only and not with going ahead with more uranium mining. We should be talking about minimising the dangers that have already resulted from uranium mining in many places in this country.

For that reason I am also very concerned about the exploration licences being handed out to companies such as CRA Ltd, although I know that this is a State government matter. At the moment CRA is conducting a massive exploration program in the Kintyre area of the Ruddall River National Park in Western Australia, and on the land which is highly significant for Aboriginal people. This should not be allowed under any circumstances in a national park, for many reasons, not the least of which is that it will eventually result in pressure being applied to the Federal Government to allow mining to go ahead. Despite the frequent assurances of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) that the Government will stick to its three mines policy-which is itself a difficult, contradictory and hypocritical policy and the reason I am here representing Western Australians on a nuclear free Australia ticket-we must remember that if the Opposition is ever returned to government it will give the go ahead to the uranium mining industry, all the exploration having been done during the term of office of the Australian Labor Party which used to be opposed to uranium mining for very good reasons.

Briefly, I will be supporting the Australian Democrats, amendments because I think the industry must be much more accountable than the present Government is seeing that it should be, and also because I believe we should not be encouraging the perpetuation of that industry under any circumstances or in any places whatsoever in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill amends the Customs Tariff Act and provides that the export duty on uranium mined in the Alligator Rivers Region in the Northern Territory will be increased from 11c per kilogram to 80c per kilogram-a rise of some 700 per cent. The levy is being increased to finance further the operations of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. This increase from 11c to 80c per kilogram is a very hefty one, and naturally it will slug the uranium companies. This discrimination against the Northern Territory uranium producers imposes higher costs on them while South Australian uranium can be produced at a lower cost. It makes it more difficult for the Northern Territory mines to compete in an already competitive world market. I believe the move is symptomatic of the Federal Government's inability to bring itself to provide incentive to the uranium industry, an industry it should be encouraging. Only recently the media were full of reports that our oil supplies are running out and that we are not finding new sources of oil to replace them. We should be looking at nuclear energy as a potential resource for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has taken an irresponsible attitude towards uranium development, which is reflected by its failure to give the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation a charter which includes the development of the nuclear fuel cycle within Australia. I believe that would be very desirable. The left wing of the Australian Labor Party refuses to acknowledge that uranium mining and the development of the nuclear fuel cycle within Australia are critical to Australia's future.

I raise just one or two other matters relating to the cost of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. The legislation covering the Supervising Scientist has been in place for several years. I believe that this legislation and the administrative costs of this organisation should be reviewed because there are now too many overlapping authorities in the field of uranium administration. A review would lead to costs being reduced, and as a result there would not need to be extraordinarily hefty increases in charges, such as this increase from 11c to 80c. The Labor Party gag means that time is against us so I make a very brief comment about the rehabilitation of mines. Honourable senators must realise that in the Northern Territory now considerable rehabilitation of uranium mines and other mines is taking place. That is a part of the modern mining of minerals, whether uranium or other minerals. One can look at the rehabilitation of Rum Jungle. I will not go into that at length, because I have done so before. The old practice of mining at Rum Jungle was extremely poor, but what has now been achieved with the rehabilitation at Rum Jungle is indicative of what can be done in the future. There is considerable ongoing rehabilitation of the old bauxite mines at Nhulunbuy, and similarly at the manganese mine at Groote Eylandt. Surely one would have to be very naive to believe that there are no plans to rehabilitate the Ranger mine following the removal of uranium resources. This is the plan that has been agreed to by the Federal Government and the mining authorities in relation to the rehabilitation of Ranger. All in all, I find the legislation very disappointing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the second reading debate and I do not think that I need reiterate the matters that already have been put so well by Ministers in support of the various Bills in the second reading speeches and, I believe, in the debate last night. In relation to the second reading amendment moved by the Australian Democrats, and I understand it is supported by Senator Vallentine, the Government cannot accept the in principle amendment to the motion for the second reading. Honourable senators will be aware that the proposal is to provide for a fund to conduct research into alternative energy sources and to provide for the rehabilitation of uranium mine sites by imposing an additional duty on uranium concentrate that is exported from Australia. It is unnecessary. The Government is not opposed to the matters that lie behind the concerns expressed in the second reading amendment, but honourable senators will recall that rehabilitation of those former uranium mines, which was dependent on public funding, has now been largely completed. The largest expenditure was at Rum Jungle and that amounted to some $20m. It is not necessary to impose a levy to collect funds for rehabilitation of existing uranium mines because, by law, owners of these mines already are required to rehabilitate their mine sites at the end of the mining.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of Ranger, a special rehabilitation trust fund has been established, to which the mine owner is obliged to make contributions and which, together with the bank guarantee, are sufficient to cover the cost of rehabilitating the Ranger Mine site. In the case of Nabarlek, a rehabilitation guarantee has been provided by the company to the Northern Territory Government.

In relation to alternative energy sources, the Government already provides substantial funding for research into alternative energy sources through the national energy research development and demonstration program. I am informed that in 1985-86 the Commonwealth approved funding totalling $2.3m for 21 separate research projects relating to renewable energy technology. The funding was provided under the national energy research development and demonstration program. There is no wish on the part of the Government again to repeat the sentiments that lie behind this second reading amendment, but it is believed to be unnecessary in light of the matters that have been brought to the attention of honourable senators. The amendment will not be supported by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of Bills includes not only the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill 1987, the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1987, the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987 and the Proceeds of Crime (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987 but also the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill. I intend to speak primarily to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill and the Proceeds of Crime Bill and my colleague Senator Durack will concern himself with the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1987 and the amendments that the Opposition will move in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer first to the Proceeds of Crime Bill. In many ways, this type of legislation is well overdue. In the last 10 years Australians have come to realise through the activities of internationally organised crime gangs that there are enormous profits available to those who are prepared to engage in systematic abuse of national and international laws. Certainly the activities of syndicates such as the Mr Asia syndicate demonstrate beyond doubt that the whole fabric of society can be put very much at risk unless measures are taken to deprive criminals of the fruits of their labours. I think one can safely say in relation to traffic in narcotics that even whole countries are at risk. The Cayman Islands and Colombia are two notorious examples where anarchy almost prevails.

It is against that background that one has to consider the Proceeds of Crime Bill. The Bill aims, firstly, to permit a court to grant orders for the freezing and confiscation of property used in, or derived from, the commission of an indictable offence against the law of the Commonwealth; secondly, to provide for the registration in Territory courts of orders for freezing and confiscation of property made under corresponding State laws and which relate to property located in the Territory; thirdly, to provide for the enforcement of foreign freezing and confiscation orders which relate to property in Australia and in respect of which relevant procedures under the mutual assistance in criminal matters legislation have been complied with; fourthly, to confer on police new powers to facilitate the following of the money trail; and, finally, to create new offences of money laundering and organised fraud.
The Opposition in general supports the legislation. However, we seek to move an amendment in respect of the Proceeds of Crime Bill to add at the end of the motion these words:

``, but the Senate notes that the Bill imposes on financial institutions heavy obligations for the retention of records concerning financial transactions, yet no statement from the Business Regulation Review Unit of the cost of such measures has been provided to it.

This is one area in which the Government deserves condemnation because this legislation should have been with us some years ago. The immediate origin of the Proceeds of Crime Bill is a draft model Bill which has already been enacted by South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales as a result of a special Premiers Conference on drugs which resulted in agreement by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. However, this Bill goes further than the model Bill in providing powers to permit law enforcement agencies to following the money trail, to create new offences of money laundering and organised fraud and to provide for the statutory forfeiture of property. In those respects I think it is unexceptionable. No one would disagree with the proposition that criminals should be deprived of the fruits of their crime. Not only is it desirable that there be punishment and retribution but also a significant deterrent should operate. It should be made as difficult as possible for criminals, firstly, to obtain sanctuary and, secondly, to live off the proceeds of their crimes. The principle, I suppose, is that fugitives should live in penury. That, in some ways, is what this Bill will set out to achieve.

Certainly gaol is no substitute for depriving criminals of the profits of their crimes. It is quite clear that in many ways financial penalties and even incarceration are simply a cost of doing business, and a very modest transaction cost at that. The profits of crime have been identified by a number of royal commissions and inquiries as very easily laundered, and we are all aware of the abuses that have taken place through the telecommunications network which have enabled moneys to be laundered through betting transactions. It is equally clear that it is not difficult to ensure that the proceeds are very quickly injected into legitimate businesses. This Bill will go a long way towards ensuring that where that occurs those businesses can be got at and dismantled. The distortion and intimidation that occurs from the taking over by organised crime of legitimate businesses will be very much curtailed.

It is beyond doubt that criminals in business enterprises have unfair advantages over legitimate competitors. The Italian Government's anti-Mafia commission cited three examples. The first was that the setting up of an umbrella of protection within a market in which business operates discourages competition from others. One can well understand the risks of taking on those who have no respect of the law. Secondly, it results in the holding down of wages and a distortion of the operation of the labour market because labour officials are unlikely to visit organised crime controlled firms to check on observance of the law and, quite clearly, the capacity for overbearing conduct is very great. Thirdly, criminal entrepreneurs who have access to financial resources denied to other firms have an enormous capacity to launder the proceeds. Often only a relatively small amount of money is required to set up a criminal transaction which then reaps vast profits which can be ploughed back into an apparently legitimate business.

The basis for this type of legislation is clear, and we do not deny for one moment the overwhelming case for comprehensive assets confiscation legislation. However, we express some concern at the time that has elapsed in dealing with what to date have to be regarded as fairly archaic and ineffective provisions. The Bill sets out a complex and sophisticated system for confiscation of property and the safeguarding of the interests of the Commonwealth in the proceeds of crime. It sets out a series of ingenious attempts to lay down rules to guide courts in assessing pecuniary penalties. One would have thought that lawyers will have a field day once again as a whole new body of case law emerges, perhaps with informers and twilight operators being called to give evidence of the street value of drugs, to determine in some manner what is an appropriate pecuniary penalty, not simply in terms of confiscation but in terms of a very real deterrent to others. Whilst the task is, I think, a daunting one for the courts, it is one from which they should not and, I am sure, will not shrink.

The clauses of the Bill provide for forfeiture of restrained property, for search and seizure of tainted property and for search warrants, which are dealt with in more detail in the telecommunications interception legislation. The clauses also provide for the making of restraining orders to prevent dealings in property and the tracking down of documents and monetary orders, quite often of a pre-emptive nature. Those who are familiar with Anton Piller orders and Mareva injunctions would appreciate the necessity at times for the courts to make ex parte orders and to grant injunctions that do not apprise the victim of what is intended on the part of the law enforcement authorities.

It is very necessary that that should occur, but it is also equally necessary that the rights of innocent third parties should be protected. We are particularly anxious to ensure that legitimate co-partners in businesses which may have some criminal involvement have their rights protected and that they are not subject to the sorts of premature and unfair publicity that attached to the Packer family as a result of the desperate efforts of the National Times to gain publicity in that area. We would want to ensure that persons who claim a legitimate interest in property are not denied every opportunity to pursue those rights, that there are not time limits which will operate to shut them out and that the method and timing of valuations of property will not result in artificially low valuations being placed on property-in particular, the fluctuations on the share market would be a notorious example. One has to be very careful in ensuring that the interests of legitimate business proprietors are protected. The Commonwealth also must be vigilant to ensure that the property rights of others are taken care of. In many ways, rather than simply intervening in a business and seeking to close it down, there may need to be some scheme comparable to a scheme of management which would allow a business to continue to operate. Certainly, where a pre-emptive strike might be necessary, one would have thought the issue should not be pre-judged to the extent that irreparable harm is caused.

I think there is a legitimate concern about the wasting of assets and an acknowledgment that once a business is closed down the goodwill may well vanish beyond recall and the capacity to regenerate the business will be very limited. So it is our concern that there should not be an excess of enthusiasm to make up for lost time in this area. There are also some legitimate burdens placed on financial institutions, and I certainly would not quibble with some of the very heavy penalties that are applied by the legislation in respect of, for instance, money laundering, for which the penalty is 20 years imprisonment, a $200,000 fine for individuals and $600,000 for bodies corporate. I think these penalties will act as a very great deterrent. It has always been said in the criminal courts that without fences there would be no thieves, and I think that one has to be very conscious of the fact that, unless there are deterrents along the line, we will not be taking sufficient steps to cut off the offences at source.

The creation of an offence of organised fraud is again a very novel and necessary one. The legislation defines organised fraud as acts or omissions that constitute three or more public fraud offences and from which the person derives substantial benefit. Again, very high penalties are imposed but, in the context of the evil that is sought to be cured, I think those penalties are fully justified.

The burden on financial institutions is a matter of concern to us, and this is reflected in the amendment we will move. It is not at all clear precisely where the cost burdens will fall. At the moment, financial institutions will be required to disclose details and to retain records of any money transactions in excess of $200. Whilst it can be argued that any increase in that level creates opportunities for rescheduling and restructuring so that a whole series of transactions can be brought under the higher limit, I think it is also fair to say that, if that then catches many thousands of ultimately innocent transactions, the retrieval costs may outweigh the benefits. Therefore, we would want to see much more evidence that such a low limit is justified.

I know that the banks have said that they have no major objections to the legislation, but I think that in many ways they are embarrassed by the disclosures that have been made as to how easy it has been for people to operate bank accounts under different names and to deposit enormous cash sums without questions being asked and without the matter being brought to the attention of the authorities by the banking institutions. I suspect that in many ways they are embarrassed to the extent that they are not prepared to complain about what would seem to be a very low level. I might just say in passing that we have no objection to the amendment that the Government will move in respect to the Proceeds of Crime (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987.

I turn now to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill 1987. Again I think this legislation is long overdue. It provides a legislative basis for Australia to enter into arrangements with other countries for the purpose of requesting and granting assistance in criminal matters and for assistance to be granted and received in respect of the investigation and prosecution of crime and the recovery of assets, including moneys obtained as a result of crime. At present, the international network to a large extent is informal and haphazard. The Bill seeks to formalise the arrangements that will operate so that it will be much more difficult for countries and individuals to avoid prosecution. This measure will not only apply to Commonwealth countries, where there will be an automatic arrangement, but also will allow a bilateral network of treaties to operate in respect of non-Commonwealth countries. In certain circumstances the Attorney-General will be obliged to refuse assistance to a foreign country. That will be where the offence is judged by Australian authorities to be political or otherwise discriminatory on the grounds of race, sex, religion, nationality or political opinion, or where the granting of the request would prejudice the Australian national interest. In other circumstances, the Attorney will not be so disposed to reject the request of assistance, and one can spell out a number of areas where it would clearly be very necessary to have that ability.

One matter that concerns us is that, when an application is made to a magistrate, there will be a discretion to deny legal representation. I confess that, having read the record of the debate that took place in the House of Representatives, I still do not understand the basis for the suggestion by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that this is simply a necessary requirement to accommodate different types of criminal proceedings in foreign jurisdictions. From an Australian point of view, one would have thought that it was a cardinal principle that no person subject to criminal proceedings should be denied the opportunity for legal representation. I would have thought that at the very least a provision should be embodied in the legislation to the effect that a magistrate shall permit legal representation unless it would be inappropriate in the circumstances to do otherwise. So I think that there is a valid concern in that area.

I think a number of legitimate criticisms can be made in relation to the Government's approach to organised crime to date. Certainly, at present there is no system for the national collection of criminal statistics to enable the analysis and correlation of factors pertaining to the problem. No attempt has been made to tackle the problem of illegal betting, especially via Telecom Australia. The National Crime Authority still has no power to investigate illegal starting price betting; is still has inadequate powers. The Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence still lacks sufficient resources, and the Australian Taxation Officer, as I think we all acknowledge, has been rather tardy and perhaps under-resourced in its investigation of taxation evasion. The Bill goes some way towards making up for lost time, but it does not limit the provision of obtaining assistance otherwise than in accordance with the legislation. Assistance can be given only to foreign countries specified in the regulations. Our concern in respect of the entitlement to legal representation is probably the most significant one.

Another provision specifies that the Attorney-General must be satisfied that a prisoner has consented to giving evidence in a foreign country. We take the view that it is unrealistic to expect that prisoners will consent. The Government would seem to acknowledge that but says that is something that has been insisted upon by other countries and that it has simply been a necessary part of the compromise to obtain agreement. That seems to be an unsatisfactory state of affairs. Nonetheless, we understand why the Government has put in an otherwise unsatisfactory provision.

I simply say in conclusion that the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill follows from a whole series of inquiries. It is based on recommendations of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Activities of the Nugan Hand Group, the report of which came out several years ago, although concerns in relation to this matter had been expressed some four or five years earlier in the course of the Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. It is clear that this type of legislation is long overdue. It is certainly our hope that, in conjunction with the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987 and the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill, Australia will shortly have in place a network which will make it much more difficult for criminals to operate in this country or to have assets in this country while operating elsewhere, committing offences which tangentially affect this country. I think it can be said that to date Australia has been very fortunate-perhaps by force of geographic location and by force of what I think is one of the best justice systems in the world-to have been relatively free from the effects of organised crime, but we know that as the global village comes closer it is much more likely that criminals are going to see Australia as affording a convenient opportunity, even one that will simply provide a cloak of legitimacy, for their operations.

I will now deal with the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill. There have been many warnings about the need for electronic surveillance through interception. Mr Justice Stewart's Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking report in February 1983 recommended that interception powers be increased and the Premiers Conference, held in April 1985, shared that view. The inquiry into the Age tapes in April 1985 resulted in the setting up of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions. I say in passing that this was done very reluctantly as a result of pressure from the public, the media and the Opposition. Nonetheless, I think the end result was unarguable. It was very necessary to have a much more comprehensive system of access granted to police officers. Mr Justice Stewart, in the course of his inquiry, said that many officers had expressed particular dismay at the state of present legislation which, effectively, excluded State police from access to lawful telephone interceptions.

It is a matter of disgrace and regret that the New South Wales Government under the discredited former Premier, Mr Wran, was so tardy in moving in this area but despite all of the obfuscation and procrastination on his part, it ultimately emerged that it was very necessary to have these powers available. The Commission found that the material it had obtained was of considerable value in identifying criminal offences, that it was very useful for criminal intelligence purposes and that the current system for lawful telephone interceptions was both narrow and too cumbersome. Again as a result of references to parliamentary committees and elsewhere, there was a delay of some years before this very serious matter was tackled.

A number of recommendations of Mr Justice Stewart have not been picked up by the Government. I say in passing that it would seem-reading between the lines-a matter of concern that State police forces and even State judges should be involved as little as possible. One might understand concern in certain narrow areas but I think that is a reflection across the board on the honesty and efficiency of State law enforcement authorities. I would have thought that any concern could be allayed if those authorities were given extensive powers where the actual request or initiative derives from them. It may not be quite as suitable if the initiative originates at Commonwealth level and they are then in a position in which they are forced to ask for assistance from State authorities in whom they do not have full confidence. However, where State authorities are seized with the necessity for action, I would have thought there is a case for extending the powers both to Federal and State police forces.

I do not understand why Supreme Court judges have been left out. They are not able to issue warrants and that would seem to be unnecessarily restrictive. I would have thought that many more Supreme Court judges are much more accessible, in terms of their home and office locations, than are judges of the Federal Court of Australia. As I have said, there are a number of examples of the Government not accepting the recommendations. One which I think is of particular interest is that all interceptions are to take place through the telecommunications interception division of the Australian Federal Police and Telecom Australia. The National Crime Authority identified one example of a delay of 19 days before operations could be set up to conduct a proper telephone intercept. The shadow Attorney-General, Mr Spender, has discovered from discussions with the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York that it is possible in the United States for phone taps to be in place in the space of 30 seconds in urgent cases. Not only is the need for speed very necessary but where Telecom, for various reasons, may be incapable, simply reluctant or may have officers who are more impressed with civil liberties considerations than the need to act in accordance with the legal requirements, it is undesirable that the hands of the authorities should be tied in that manner. We certainly take the view that the Government has not gone far enough in granting sufficiently wide powers.

We are also concerned that the admissibility of such material should not be determined by common law, as recommended by the Royal Commissioner. Common law has been remarkably flexible in its approach to the discretion that it brings to bear on weighing up the seriousness of the offence, the importance of the material, whether the prejudicial effect would outweigh the probative value. I certainly think it is necessary to have that discretion rather than an arbitrary set of rules imposed under statute. We simply do not understand why that normal approach has not been adopted in this instance.

One other matter on which I want to touch relates to clause 64 which has the effect of making admissible, despite illegality, evidence which has been obtained retrospectively. What we are faced with if this clause is accepted is a pre-emptive strike against the High Court of Australia which is currently about to hear a series of pending cases which seek to reargue a decision in Hilton v. Wells in 1985 where it was held that even information illegally obtained was admissible in courts of law. The aim of clause 64 is to take away the prospects of acquittal, which certain citizens would have had under the law as it stood at the time they engaged in the conduct for which they have been prosecuted. That pre-emptive strike would seem to be an intolerable denial of justice. The imposition of retrospective criminal liability is something from which one should shrink in almost every conceivable instance. Simply to jump in and adopt the view that the High Court might have taken in 1985 and not to await the benefit of further reflection and wisdom-in other words the outcome of the Commonwealth v. Jones in particular and a number of other cases in the pipeline-would seem premature in the extreme. We take the view that the High Court should be left to decide the proper interpretation of the existing Act. That section has been criticised by the Law Society of Australia, the President of the Bar Association of New South Wales and the Law Council of Australia. We simply do not understand why the Government is so anxious to give effect to one view of the High Court which is not set in stone and nor should it be.

To a substantial extent our concerns are outweighed by the overall merits of the legislation and I would not want to be seen to be carping or cavilling too much. However, I certainly suggest that significant opportunities remain for improving this legislation. Although what is sought to be done is very necessary, some matters need urgent attention. Accordingly, my colleague Senator Durack will move amendments, one of which will lower the threshold in respect of offences that would justify an application being made. In many ways, the argument is over how far interception should extend. I think it can be said that the Government is being unduly cautious in this instance. We take the view that organised criminals are capable of committing even relatively minor offences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time is about to expire. Do you formally move the amendment you foreshadowed?
—Yes, I do. There is only one, and that is in respect of the Proceeds of Crime Bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add:

``, but the Senate notes that the Bill imposes on financial institutions heavy obligations for the retention of records concerning financial transactions, yet no statement from the Business Regulation Review Unit of the cost of such measures has been provided to it''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The three substantial Bills in this package are the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill 1987, the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987 and, finally, the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1987. Also in this package are some Bills which are consequential on the above Bills being passed. The package has been made necessary by perception in the community of crime becoming not only more widespread but also, and perhaps more importantly, more sophisticated and spread out across the world. In the old days before technology gave us aeroplanes and communications to the extent that we now have them the commission of a particular crime was very much confined to a particular area and a particular country. Funds can now be transferred in and out of Australia very rapidly. People can go from one country to another in a short time. It is becoming clearer and clearer that the fight against crime should be conducted more and more on an international scale. It is in that context that these Bills come before the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Criticism has been made that the Bills were brought forward in a tardy fashion and that in some ways they are inadequate. I will come to that matter later. But overall, as I understand Senator Alston's remarks, the Opposition supports the substance of the measures. Senator Alston said that the Bills should have been brought on earlier and that even greater powers should have been given to the people who are battling crime. At the same time he took the Government to task for introducing clause 64 in the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill because he claimed that this was retrospective. Of course that was not the Opposition's approach when the Age tapes and related matters came before the Parliament. I simply point out to Senator Alston-although I realise he was not here when those debates took place, and I am sure that he would have taken the view that the Age tapes should not have been made available as evidence to the courts-that many of his colleagues took a different approach to the Age tapes from the one he now takes to clause 64 of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill.

I wish to correct Senator Alston on one other matter. Clause 64 of that Bill does not, as I understand it, make crime retrospective. There is no suggestion in any way that something that was not a crime prior to the passing of this Bill will now be made a crime. The Bill simply makes available evidence which was illegally obtained and enables it to be used in prosecuting people who are charged with crimes which were crimes before this legislation was introduced and which were crimes when the people concerned allegedly committed them. This raises the question of whether tainted evidence should ever be admitted. It is a bit difficult to argue, on one hand-as Senator Alston apparently argued-that the common law rule should apply to the question of whether evidence that was wrongly or illegally obtained should be admitted and, on the other hand, criticise clause 64. All that clause 64 does is to add to or modify the common law position. My view is that if evidence is illegally obtained it should only be admitted if it can be shown that this is absolutely necessary in terms of the public interest, as defined by the court.

While I am on the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill there is another point I wish to make which also applies to the other Bills in this package. Of course crime is horrible and it should be eradicated from the community. That has been the approach ever since communities began. At the same time great regard must be paid to the civil rights of the citizens of the community. When we discuss these Bills it would be dangerous for us to fall into the trap of saying that crime must be eradicated at any cost, even if it means convicting people who are, in reality, innocent, or putting cruel pressure upon innocent people and bringing the processes of law to bear against them when this should not occur. The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill should not be regarded simply as a measure which gives power to various authorities; it should also be regarded as a measure which protects the privacy and civil liberties of individuals and their ability to move about as free citizens in a free community. It protects those rights as well as arming certain authorities with the ability to fight crime. It must not be forgotten that in fighting crime we often crush those who have not committed a crime but who find themselves placed in suspicious circumstances. Perhaps the most graphic example of how the processes of enforcing the law can go wrong is the current case of the Chamberlains. That is a very salutary example to put forward when we consider these measures which are dedicated to enforcing law and order in the community.

In the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill it is interesting to note that the crimes that are available to justify the granting of a warrant are restricted in clause 5 of that Bill, the interpretation clause, which sets out how certain words must be interpreted. It is worth reading those out. The first is `loss of a person's life or serious risk of loss of a person's life'. Others include `serious personal injury or risk of serious personal injury', `serious damage to property in circumstances endangering the safety of a person', `trafficking in narcotic drugs', `serious fraud' or `serious loss of revenue of the Commonwealth or of a State'. That is a very wide ambit within which the authorities can operate because it covers a wide range of crimes. For example, `loss of a person's life' would include negligent or culpable driving, manslaughter and, indeed, domestic crimes in respect of which a good argument can be raised to the effect that their investigation does not justify prejudice to privacy or to the integrity of the telephone system. Nevertheless, it is a matter of balance and on balance those sorts of things have been included.

Senator Alston made a point about the fact that the intercept procedures must be conducted through Telecom Australia and the Australian Federal Police. I think that that is a justified approach because this is Federal legislation. It is a power being exercised by the Commonwealth pursuant to the Constitution. The Constitution gives the Commonwealth the ability to make laws in this respect. Given that, it is only proper that the Commonwealth should police the exercise of those powers. Not only will this measure be used against people who have allegedly committed crimes but also it is aimed at protecting the rights and civil liberties of people. This legislation acts both ways. It empowers people to investigate but it also prohibits people going beyond what are considered justifiable limits within which crime authorities should act. Taking that into account, it is proper that the operation of this legislation be policed and overseen by the Federal Police because the Commonwealth has a duty, pursuant to the provisions of the Constitution, to see that its legislation is not transgressed. Accordingly, it is proper that Federal judges and Federal police should be the ones to look after the Federal law.

I turn to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill. This legislation is felt to be necessary as a result of the internationalisation of crime. It has been drawn to my attention by the Commonwealth law officers that Australia is the first Commonwealth country to introduce legislation that will enable the passing between countries of evidence necessary to obtain convictions. The Commonwealth Law Ministers met in Harare in July 1986 and agreed to a Commonwealth mutual assistance scheme. A Bill on this topic has been introduced in Canada recently but has not yet been passed. The Commonwealth law officers in the Attorney-General's Department and other departments have done a great deal of work in preparing this legislation. The legislation has been well thought out and the officers, in preparing these Bills, have performed a mighty task. The legislation will help to stop the perpetration of crime in the community.

The Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill contains some exceptions as to the areas in which it is applicable. Although Australia will help authorities in another country to obtain information leading to the conviction of somebody who has committed a crime in that country, Australia will not do so if the crime alleged to have been committed by the person is an offence of a political character or an offence that depends on the person's race, sex, religion, nationality or political opinion. In other words, if the offence in respect of which Australia's help is sought has political overtones or is based on considerations of sex, religion, race or nationality, Australia will not give assistance. Again, if it is an offence against what in Australia would be no more than a military law of Australia and not also against an Australian criminal law, Australia will give no assistance.

One matter of concern should be mentioned. This legislation can be used to help obtain evidence in this country which may lead to the execution of somebody in a foreign country. That is a matter which I find very worrying indeed. I find it abhorrent, but again it is a matter which, given the balance that has to be struck in this package, remains among the provisions covered by this legislation. Although exceptions are made in respect of some matters, no exception is made relating to crime which in another country is punishable by death. I refer to requests by foreign countries for search and seizure. This too is a grave matter but again, given the internationalisation of crime, it is considered to be necessary. Clause 15 of the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill says:
Where-
(a) a proceeding or investigation relating to a criminal matter involving a serious offence has commenced in a foreign country;
(b) there are reasonable grounds to believe that a thing relevant to the investigation or proceeding is located in Australia; and
(c) the foreign country requests the Attorney-General to arrange for the issue of a search warrant under this section in relation to that thing;

the Attorney-General may, in his or her discretion, authorise a police officer, in writing, to apply to a Magistrate of the State or Territory in which that thing is believed to be located for the search warrant requested by the foreign country.

Once a warrant is granted dramatic results follow. A person, his house and immediate surroundings can be searched. The intention is that this legislation will be used only in very serious matters. It must forever be kept in mind that the Telecommunications (Interception) Act is directed not only towards discovering crime and bringing those who have committed crime to punishment but also at protecting people from the excesses of law enforcement agents which do occur. It is forever to be remembered, when talking of legislation such as this, that that balance must be struck and that, if the balance is to tip in favour of anybody, it should tip towards the individual against whom the state directs its might.

I turn to the Proceeds of Crime Bill, which again is a measure worthy of being brought before and passed by this House. It provides that if a person has been convicted of an indictable offence the Director of Public Prosecutions can apply to have the property-and the sort of property is defined-confiscated. It is referred to as `tainted property', and means property which a person has used to commit an offence, or the proceeds of the offence itself. Therefore, if through some fraud a person obtains vast sums of money, or indeed any sum of money, that money is confiscated, and if he or she has used particular instruments to perpetrate the crime those too can be confiscated. It is similar to forfeiture under the old felony rules at common law. It makes sense that a person who profits through his or her ill-doing should not be allowed to retain that profit. It should be borne in mind that, even for a person who has committed a crime, one should seek to ensure that only property connected with the crime is confiscated.

The package contains the Proceeds of Crime Bill, which takes from a person convicted of a crime the fruits of it or the instruments used by the person to perpetrate it. There is the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill, which enables countries to exchange evidence to be used in the trail of those who have allegedly committed crimes. There is the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill which enables the authorities in certain circumstances to gather intelligence about criminal activities and to obtain convictions.

Whenever instruments aimed at fighting crime are discussed one should remember that the people into whose hands those instruments are given have a heavy responsibility laid upon them. Those people must have a consciousness of human dignity and human freedom. They must be aware of the rights of people to go about their business unhampered, not only by their fellows but also by those who are placed in authority and by those whose task it is protect the community from crime and from violence and dishonesty. People are entitled to go about their business assured that the people who are placed in positions of trust and power exercise that trust and power properly. If the community can be assured of that, these Bills and what they purport to do can be accepted as a means of fighting crime. It must be remembered-and I do not say this in a facetious way-the crime has always been and always will be with us. There are two points about that. The fight against crime must be continuous. On the other hand, we must never, in an attempt to overcome it, adopt processes which prejudice justice, freedom and compassion-the characteristics of a decent community.

Senator Alston said that the whole of society could be put at risk by the drug problem. That is true. But the whole of society will be put at risk if the measures used to counter crime are too draconian, too insensitive to human dignity and too mechanical in their application. It is not only drugs which are a threat to society but also the many money transactions which flow into and out of the community and round the world. I notice in this context the great work that the honourable member for Hawker, Mr Jacobi, has done in bringing the attention of this Parliament and society generally to the crimes committed in the world of business and finance. In large measure they go unpunished. In raising the issues of financial fraud, business wrongdoing and business rorts he has given this Parliament much to ponder and act upon.

I finish by commending the Bills. I understand from what Senator Alston says that the Opposition, with some amendments or objections, will agree to them. No doubt those opposite have to put forward some objections and amendments to justify the time given to the debate. By and large this package, with sensitivity and understanding of the need to preserve the liberties and freedoms of the citizen, will hopefully root out from society those who have committed crimes and bring them to proper punishment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The complementary pieces of legislation which make up this package on organised crime represent a significant increase in the armoury available. Australia has long suffered from serious deficiencies in its approach to organised crime. It is only in relatively recent times that we have managed to put together a more effective approach than was possible by reliance upon State police forces as the only enforcement agency available to us. The development of the National Crime Authority out of a series of royal commissions was an important step forward in this area. These pieces of legislation add to that movement. As such, they are welcomed not only by people in all political parties but also by all citizens in Australia who understand the dangers that confront our society from organised crime and the necessity for a continued fight in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: It is extraordinary when one talks about this matter and the need for resources that at the same time people are wandering around saying that money should be cut, that the Budget and taxes should be reduced in such and such a way because we do not need services. These people do not realise that amongst the types of services which would come under severe financial pressure in those circumstances are these types of services to the community, services which support the fabric of the community and make sure that if we cannot eliminate organised crime we can at least take up the fight in such a way that crime is destabilised, so that if we do not win at least it is a drawn game.

An exercise whereby we would severely deplete Commonwealth revenues would necessarily detract enormously from this fight. This is one of the areas which would come under severe political pressure to have funding reduced. I say in passing that when we talk blithely about reductions in Commonwealth services it might be worth while sometimes to allude to the services provided by the Commonwealth. The fight against crime is one of the important services that the Commonwealth provides, and it is one of the services for which the Commonwealth will have to increase funding, because some of these Bills, for example the Mutual Assistance and Criminal Matters Bill 1987 and the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1987 which concern the internationalising of co-operation-and I will come to them in a moment-will entail significant costs. These types of operation cannot work effectively without additional resources.

The Australian Democrats support this legislation not only for a number of reasons which I will come to but also for the rather consistent reason that in quite a number of debates in the past we have urged a number of these reforms to be included in legislation. I remember on one occasion having to take over from Don Chipp in this chamber because he was ill and moving a series of amendments regarding the money trail and the confiscation of proceeds of crime. We were not successful on that occasion but I am very pleased to see that a far more effective and useful mechanism has been brought forward by the Government in this legislation. We are hopeful that it will be another useful adjunct in this area.

When the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) introduced this package of legislation he said that it represented the implementation of the recommendations of Mr Justice Stewart in his Royal Commission of Inquiry into the activities of the Nugan Hand group, which reported in mid-1985. The need for better mutual assistance legislation had been recommended for quite some time before then. For example, it had been recommended by Mr Costigan almost four years earlier. So this legislation represents a convergence of opinion in Australia and internationally of the best way to deal with this matter. In seeking to combat organised crime it is quite obvious that governments have to have a coherent strategy. Such a plan must include wide-ranging information gathering to identify the activities of organised crime. It must ensure that the resources of the relevant crime enforcement agencies are adequate and it must involve proper co-ordination of all the agencies involved in law enforcement. Of course, over all that there must be a suitable legislative framework.

The Democrats have pointed out deficiencies in each of these areas, including the long-standing problem of understaffing in the Australian Federal Police, which is the responsibility of the Special Minister of State (Senator Tate), who is in the chamber at the moment. We are pleased to find that this somewhat overdue package of legislation has now been brought forward. The two Bills dealing with mutual assistance provide the basis for Australia to enter into agreements with other countries whereby we can request and grant assistance in criminal matters, and amend various Commonwealth Acts in this regard. At present, international assistance is available to Australia through Interpol. These Bills also specify the nature and methods by which other countries will be able to obtain assistance from Australia. In contrast, the types of assistance available to Australia from other countries are stated in broad terms only. The details of the reciprocal assistance measures will depend upon domestic legislation in each of those foreign countries. By way of example I point out that obviously the effective method of dealing with drug importation into Australia or into other countries is to know what is coming. If our Customs officials have prior warning effective searches can be done to locate the illegal drugs. Indeed, some of the most recent and spectacular successes of our Customs officials have resulted from the knowledge of such information.

The Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (Consequential Amendments) Bill will enable the Director of Public Prosecutions to appear and grant indemnities in proceedings under the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill, repeals provisions in Australian extradition legislation in relation to the taking of evidence for the purpose of criminal proceedings overseas, as those provisions are now in the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill, and makes provision for entry into and departure from Australia of non-citizens whose presence is required for purposes connected with the Bill. Again, this is an area involving quite considerable costs.

The two Bills dealing with the proceeds of crime, the Proceeds of Crime Bill and the Proceeds of Crime (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, address themselves to following the money trail and the confiscation of assets derived from criminal activity. Whilst one may believe that this is a relatively simple matter, once one has read the Bill one realises the complexities one is confronted with in this area-determining whether the proceeds being dealt with are the proceeds of crime or the proceeds of legitimate business activity. If money were stained and identified it might be easier, but that is not the case. Hence following the money trail and the confiscation of assets are relatively complex matters. The Government has proceeded cautiously and effectively in this area with the legislation.

The legislation will permit a court to grant orders for the freezing and confiscation of property used in or derived from the commission of an indictable offence against a Commonwealth or Territory law. It provides also for the registration in Territory courts or orders for freezing and confiscation of property made under corresponding State laws and which relate to property located in the Territory. It provides for the enforcement of foreign freezing and confiscation orders which relate to property in Australia and in respect of which the relevant procedures under the mutual assistance legislation have been complied with. It confers on police new powers to facilitate the following of the money trail and to require financial institutions to preserve their records to maintain the money trail. Finally, the Bill creates a range of new offences, particularly with regard to money laundering and organised fraud.

The Australian Democrats believe that these provisions will greatly assist the fight against organised crime. The legislation seeks to deal with some very complex and sophisticated problems, as I have already said. Whilst it cannot be seen as a panacea for all of the problems involved in organised crime, it will certainly remedy some of the deficiencies which, in the past, have cried out for solutions.

Having made those general remarks, I want to draw attention to some matters of concern in the Bills. In trying to solve the difficult problem of organised crime there is, as Senator Cooney said, a danger of being too draconian in our solutions. We run the risk of ignoring civil rights which we take for granted in our society. The Democrats have some concerns of this nature and, whilst we recognise the need to act firmly in this area, I want to put our concerns on the record and point out that the Democrats will be keeping a careful watch on the operation of the legislation in case amendments to it are needed in future.

I refer to the problems perceived by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills with the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill, particularly in regard to clause 7 (2) and clause 34. Clause 34 is of great concern to us. Here I am at somewhat of a disadvantage because the truncation of debates and the bringing forward of this debate have meant that I have not had access to all the information the relevant Minister has provided to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee by way of response. I understand that the Minister's responses have gone a long way towards satisfying the concerns raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. If that is the case, some of the Democrats' concern will be alleviated, but we do not wish to put aside these matters entirely.

Our concerns with the Proceeds of Crime Bill relate particularly to clause 5 which states that for the purposes of the Act conviction includes a person found guilty of an offence but discharged without conviction and a person who absconds in connection with the offence. There are obvious problems in that area. The discharge of a person guilty of an offence without the registration of a conviction if the court believes that is warranted obviously is warranted for a number of reasons. It seems odd that we should have overridden the court's discretion in this way. Likewise, absconding in connection with the offence is loosely worded and could very well pick up people who were not aware of the provision. Whilst there are other provisions in the legislation with regard to this matter, we have some significant concerns.

In clause 7 the definition of `serious offence' can probably be most charitably described as pretty loose and, at the worst, as entirely circular. Even if one takes into account subsequent sections of the legislation which seek to clarify this matter, we are still of the view that the definition of `serious offence' needs to be tightened. Later we will seek to move amendments with regard to this matter.

Clause 13 is to operate retrospectively. Clause 19 reverses the onus of proof, as does clause 27. Clause 27 also reverses the hearsay rule, in relation to which some significant difficulties could certainly arise in individual cases. In clause 81 the definition of `money laundering' is not much better than the definition of `serious offence'. It is extremely important in legislation of this kind that these definitions be as rigid as possible. We understand and are aware of the difficulties. I wish I were aware of the Minister's response to these difficulties because it might make my present job a little easier. Because we understand that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has withdrawn most of its major concerns we do not intend to move the series of amendments we had intended to move to a whole range of provisions. We have limited our amendments to provisions whose definitional problems we are not satisfied with, even if the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is.

The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill also presents some significant problems, for example, with regard to the evidentiary certificates referred to in clause 61 (2). The concerns that we have in this matter again are identical to those spelt out in some detail by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.
