The Opposition moved amendments to clause 5 and at the moment we are studying that clause. We have some concerns about the Opposition's amendment, but at this stage I flag that we are inclined to support the first amendment of the Opposition and also that we will support subsequent amendments. However, at a later stage, possibly in debate, one of my colleagues will be able to give some further details on a study we are undertaking in regard to clause 1. Unfortunately, we have not had the opportunity to have those amendments for any length of time and, as I say, we wish to study clause 1 in more detail. Some time ago we understood that amendments 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 would be moved and hence there was an opportunity to discuss them in detail.

I do not want the impression to be left at the end of my remarks that we are unhappy with these Bills, because the exact opposite is the case: The Australian Democrats express very strong support for this package of legislation. We believe that it will be an effective and useful element. The concerns that I have expressed relate only to detail and, again, I think it is a pity that we will not be able to have the type of detailed debate that we normally have in Committee on these matters so that they can be thrashed out fully. We strongly support the Government and I urge it to continue the legislative process upon which they have started so successfully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, support the general thrust of the legislation. However, we expected the introduction of such legislation by this Government some three or four years ago and it has taken a tremendous amount of time to see how serious the Government has been in trying to attack some of the more fundamental areas. As a result of the various royal commissions and inquiries that have been held over the previous few years, a lot of recommendations have been presented. Many of those recommendations have been picked up in one or other of these Bills and, as Senator Macklin said, I would not want there to be any impression that we do not support completely the general thrust of these Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Having been involved with the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception I wish to make some comments on that area. I fully appreciate and accept the protection of privacy as being a very important factor in all these discussions. However, we have to balance that against the fact that criminals, and particularly those high-powered, commercial and international criminals, cannot be let off the hook. The attitude in the community towards crime and apprehension generally is getting to the worrying stage. When it comes to making sure that the work that goes into criminal apprehension is not lost, I believe that we have to be more direct in our methods, because we pussyfoot our way with them and we let them get away when there is absolutely no justification for it. Senators are aware of the fact that nationally our police and apprehension services are stretched to the absolute limit. We know that there is a need for more people, for better equipment and for better methods. Passing the laws alone will not provide for the people and it will require additional use of government resources if we are to get the result that should come from legislation of this nature. Accordingly, I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: MATTERS OF PUBLIC INTEREST

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:

That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day matters of public interest may be discussed by senators, provided that no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes, and provided further that should a division be called for such division shall be forthwith postponed until a later hour in the day, not being earlier than 2 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise some problems that exist with the Senate scrutiny provisions in the Commonwealth Electoral Act. There are four main defects of varying degrees of seriousness in section 273 of the Electoral Act; that is, the section that deals with the counting of votes after a Senate election. These concern deferment of surpluses and bulk exclusions and the definition of the transfer value when a candidate is elected and there is a surplus to be distributed. The explanatory memorandum circulated with the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1987 said that clause 32 provided for `deferral of the transfer of surpluses where this would not affect the next exclusion'. There was no apparent mechanism for deferral in the legislation. If (13A) had replaced (13) in line 32 on page 21 of the Bill, there would have been a deferral mechanism. It may indeed be important at the end of the scrutiny, and I wonder whether a printing correction has been made since the Bill left this place. No amendment was moved in the House of Representatives to fix the matter up, even though I did alert the Special Minister of State.

SPEECH.PARA: The second defect is in subsection (13B), which deals with bulk exclusions. The Australian Electoral Commission has picked up a problem area but it has not been able to sort out how to always get the same result as under the current situation. For this subsection to apply, an absolute minimum of nearly two quotas of votes must be exhausted. The two proposed subsections identify a theoretical problem point but then put forward a rather careless way of handling this particular impasse, which may lead to results different from those which exist under the current scrutiny procedures. I take a simple example to illustrate this. The quota is 100 votes and there are two vacancies still to be filled, the continuing candidates and their respective progress totals are as follows: Smith, 64; Lopez, 17; Charles, 16; and Young, 2. The vacancy shortfall is 119 votes-in fact, 36 plus 83. There is no candidate A and Lopez is candidate B. Lopez's notional votes total 35; that is, 17 plus 16 plus 2, which is also less than the leading shortfall of 36 votes under this example.

Under the proposed subsection (13A) (c), three candidates could be excluded in bulk. Hence, proposed subsection (13B) comes into operation and leads to the simultaneous exclusion of Charles and Young so that Smith and Lopez are declared elected. However under the current scrutiny arrangement, Young would have been excluded first. His two votes may well both be transferred to Charles, taking her progress total to 18 votes, and in this case Lopez is next to be excluded and Smith and Charles are therefore declared elected. Consequently, it is quite possible for the bulk exclusion procedure to produce a result completely different from that obtained under the current scrutiny procedures. The intention was to use bulk exclusion to expedite the scrutiny without interfering with the outcome of the election. I believe this is part of a really deep problem of lack of attention to principle in the electoral system. There is a relatively straightforward way of dealing with this particular problem. If more than one candidate is to be excluded at the same time in these unusual circumstances, it should be a requirement that the notional votes of the excluded candidate highest in the poll be fewer than those of the unexcluded candidate lowest in the poll.

The third defect is in the definition of the transfer value when a candidate achieves a quota on first preferences alone. It may cause unnecessary exhaustion of votes. The transfer value in this case is currently found by dividing the surplus by the number of first preference votes for the candidates elected at the outset of the scrutiny. However, in the elections for the Maltese Parliament, the Irish Dail and the New South Wales Legislative Council, as well as in New South Wales local government elections, the transfers value is found by dividing the surplus by the number of transferable papers with a first preference for the elected candidate, provided that this does not exceed one. Doing this does not slow down the scrutiny. The non-transferable papers remain in the quota of the elected candidate, and as much as possible of their value is used in the election of the candidate and as little as possible is regarded as lost by exhaustion. This respects most of the clearly expressed intentions of the voters and I believe it should be supported.

I will give a simple example. Once again, if the quota is 100 votes and Gelbart has 150 first preferences votes of which 15 cannot be further transferred, the definition in section 273 makes the transfer value for all 150 papers 50 over 150-that is, one-third. As a result, five votes-that is, 15, the non-transferable votes, multiplied by one-third-are written off as a loss by exhaustion.

The alternative approach involves exactly the same physical work but it distributes the surplus in accordance with what is on the transferable papers, so that the transfer value in that case becomes 50 over 135, or 10 over 27, which is one twenty-seventh higher than the section 273 result. The effect of this is that the 15 non-transferable papers are taken to contribute 15 votes towards the elected candidate's quota, rather than just 10 with a further loss of five by exhaustion. Overall the use of the number of transferable papers as a divisor, instead of the number of first preference votes, allows the voter to get maximum effectiveness from their clearly expressed intentions. I believe altering this in the legislation, which would improve the vote effectiveness, would be a very straightforward matter. It may seem to be somewhat esoteric, but it is extremely important and may result in quite a difference at the end of a large count in the Senate.

The fourth defect that we have managed to pinpoint is the general definition of transfer value which may allow some voters in effect to get more than one vote. Because all papers are given equal weighting in the distribution of surpluses where candidates are elected, but not on first preferences alone, it is possible for the transfer value of some papers to rise as a result of those papers helping to elect a particular candidate. This is unprecedented in quota preferential systems and is tantamount to allowing some voters more than one vote. Previously, the transfer value has been taken to be part of a person's vote not yet used in electing candidates. Of course it is decreased when it has helped to elect someone.

On page 1061 of the transcript of the inquiry of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform into the operation at the 1984 election of the most recent amendments to the Act, an illuminating example is presented by Mr Wright, who is the immediate past President of the Proportional Representation Society of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Wright?

—Mr Wright is generally right about electoral matters. In this example the value of the parcel of 5,000 papers rises from 98 votes to 2,091 votes as a result of the parcel helping to elect someone. Quite clearly, those 5,000 voters would be much better off falsifying their real wishes if this enables their papers to rise in value from 98 votes to 2,091 votes at some stage during the scrutiny. The effect of this is to give those 5,000 voters nearly 7,000 votes.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course the example is calculated to demonstrate this in its extreme, but with this comes the possibility of a startling impact upon the outcome of an election scrutiny in which several candidates remain very much in the running for the last vacancy or vacancies. That is the type of situation that could occur in the next election, with a larger number of smaller parties. It is possible to define transfer values more sensitively to avoid such anomalies. This will certainly have to be done when computer processing of votes comes into effect.

We would open up the possibility of people using tactical voting to achieve more than they could in normal circumstances if we left this particular rort in the system. It was not possible under the old last-parcel approach; the limitations of that, however, were exposed in Queensland in the Senate election of 1974. Quite a few basically Labor supporters gave their first preferences to Neville Bonner, on the coalition ticket, and these then were to go on to the Australian Labor Party candidates. Their papers stopped with Neville Bonner. He was third on the ticket. Had he been first, these papers would have been transferred on to the Labor ticket. This was obviously quite an anomaly and was the result of quite a large amount of investigation and outcry at the time of the scrutiny.

The current procedure was designed to deal with that particular problem. When one does the calculations, one finds that around 30 per cent of those who put Neville Bonner first would have had to continue with Labor senators for Labor to have won a fifth place. However, if counting had been undertaken with strict rules about transfer values being in proportion to the value at which the papers were received, only 20 per cent would have been required to continue with the Labor ticket. I believe that is quite a difference in this case.

The matter of accuracy arose in practice at the New South Wales scrutiny when the Call to Australia votes were totally swamped by the Liberal first preferences and they helped to elect Senator Michael Baume. During the transfer of surpluses, an undervaluation of over 10,000 votes occurred to the Call to Australia votes, and the Liberal papers were overvalued to make up for that. In a close election that may well have made an enormous difference, although it did not affect that particular case directly. I believe that the Special Minister of State (Senator Tate) should bring this to the notice of people who are drafting this legislation and are responsible for it. I gave him notice of what I was going to say, and I hope that the Government, whether the Labor Government is returned or another government gets in next time, will take up these matters and try to get us a completely fair system which will give us one vote one value, and a proper way of assessing who should be the representatives of the people of Australia in this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak today about the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence inquiry into safety procedures relating to nuclear powered and nuclear armed vessels in Australian waters. It is generally known that from 1971 to 1976 a moratorium on the visits of nuclear powered warships into Australian ports was imposed by the McMahon Government. During that time, the Government prepared an environmental impact statement which is classified, that is, unavailable to the public even under the terms of the Freedom of Information Act. When nuclear powered warships visits resumed in 1976, the Fraser Government produced a document entitled `Environmental considerations of Visits of Nuclear Powered Warships to Australia'. When this was tabled on 4 June 1976, the then Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is taking these decisions on the basis of international experience with nuclear powered warships . . .
He also said, as reported in Hansard of 4 June 1976:

Appropriate arrangements concerning environmental safeguards will be applied in consultation with State governments by a group of officials led by officials of the Department of Environment, Housing and Community Development. Such arrangements will be undertaken, as necessary, before visits take place.

Such arrangements are not in place 11 years to the day later. Only Western Australia has publicly released a port safety plan; it is inadequate but at least it has done that in relation to the visits of nuclear powered warships. Other States which receive such visits have not completed safety plans.

To return to Mr Fraser's statement that the visits were being resumed on the basis of international experience with nuclear powered warships, I wish to inform the Senate and the people of Australia that the international experience to which Mr Fraser referred is flimsy indeed. I have letters here which indicate that there was no written evidence of the international experience to which Mr Fraser referred. In its deliberations the Senate Committee sought a report from Australian Atomic Energy Commission officials who went overseas in 1972 to seek this international experience. The report could not be located. Mr G. K. Greenslade of the AAEC, currently on detachment to assist the Senate Committee inquiry with technical advice, wrote a letter dated 1 April 1987 to Mr D. W. Crancher, one of three AAEC officers who went to France, the United Kingdom and the United States in 1972 to seek overseas expertise on the matter of nuclear powered warships and the safety implications of the visits to Australian ports. The other two members of the delegation were Mr Timbs, in his capacity as Executive Commissioner of the AAEC, and a Mr M. Farrell, who were probably also asked whether they had written a report and, if so, where was that report. What I now read to the Senate is the reply to Mr Greenslade's request from Mr Crancher, dated 23 April 1987:
Dear Mr Greenslade,

Thank you for your letter of 1.4.87. I well recall the overseas visit you refer to. The circumstances surrounding this visit were rather unusual since, although safety aspects of nuclear propelled warships visits were to be investigated, this was never stated officially. You must not forget that the law in the USA specifically forbade any exchange of technical information on nuclear warships (the McMahon Act). The same embargo held in the UK by virtue of their strong bilateral agreement on nuclear propelled sub. design. Timbs accordingly instructed both Farrell and myself to pursue the matter with great discretion. The official purpose of the visit was then limited to an investigation of overseas policies regarding acceptance of nuclear propelled merchant ships and a study of the status of light-water reactors. I prepared a twenty page unclassified visit report limited to these aspects.

We did of course probe nuclear propelled warship safety but in general learned very little due to the prohibition. In London Timbs and I met Reg Farmer, who gave us a probabilistic viewpoint in general terms (all now in BR3019). In the USA Timbs did manage (a rare!) discussion with Rickover, I was not invited, since Rickover considered me too technically qualified (and might ask embarrassing questions). This discussion was written up by Farrell and is on file. I do not consider it very helpful. Timbs then lined up discussions with M. Bourgeois, Director of Reactor Safety, CEA. Farrell and I met Bourgeois, who was responsible for the safety assessment of the French nuclear subs. The French appeared to me to be willing to talk more freely than the USA but only gave us an hour. We learnt a little but not much of significance.
None of the warship material was written up, apart from the Rickover discussion; however, Timbs did give Tange and others in Canberra a verbal debriefing.
Hope this is of some use.
Regards,
D. W. Crancher.

The essential substance of this letter is that there was no written report relating to nuclear powered warship safety. Information was not forthcoming from the United States Navy. Admiral Rickover refused to see Mr Crancher because he knew too much and might ask embarrassing questions. What discussion did take place with Mr Farrell and Mr Timbs, Mr Crancher says, was not very helpful. He said that none of the warship material was written up; there was only a verbal debriefing by Timbs on his return to Canberra.

So what we have is the May 1976 document, `Environmental Considerations of Visits of Nuclear Powered Warships to Australia', presented with great flourish by the then Prime Minister which was concocted without the most basic of evidence from the United States Navy. There was no report to back it up. In other words, the Australian Government was prepared to put millions of Australians and the Australian port environment at risk without bothering to satisfy the most fundamental questions relating to the safety or otherwise of mobile nuclear reactors aboard naval vessels. It asked some questions but when it did not get answers it decided to go ahead anyway. It is a scandal of momentous proportions and highlights yet again the grovelling subservience of successive Australian governments to the United States Government. The interests of the United States Navy are more important to Australian governments-that is, the Fraser Liberal Government and now the Hawke Labor Government-than the welfare and safety of the Australian people and the Australian environment. The people of Australia have a right to know the scant regard in which we are held by our own elected governments.

There are many other examples, such as the Menzies Government lending Australia to the British for their atmospheric nuclear testing program. We see subservience over and over again. How embarrassing and how disgraceful. No sovereignty, no independence; and who cares? I do, I care deeply about this country and work hard for its independence and nuclear-free status, and so do an increasing number of concerned Australians. Right now there are eight United States Navy warships ploughing through Australian waters, visiting Australian ports and disgorging United States sailors for their rest and recreation, but worst of all bearing their nuclear weapons and bringing them right into our harbours right now. No safety plans exist to deal with the possibility of accidents to warheads in ports. The only plans which do exist relate to nuclear powered vessels. Up until the terms of this inquiry were laid down there was no admission that there was any danger connected with nuclear weapons on board such warships, but at least that is being considered by this inquiry.

I want to return to Mr Crancher's letter. In it he mentions Rickover. It is important that people understand that this United States admiral, called the father of the United States nuclear navy, was a very important figure in the collating of this evidence, which was never written up. He was in the United States Navy for 63 years, but on his retirement in 1982 he had been converted away from that which he had so actively promoted-that is, the nuclear navy. I quote from his testimonial, which says:
I'm not proud of the part I played in it. . . . As for nuclear powered ships, I would sink them all.
Later, he said:
We should outlaw nuclear weapons to start with, then outlaw nuclear reactors too.

This is the man who refused to see Mr Crancher of the AAEC because he might ask embarrassing questions. I contend that the premise on which visits of nuclear powered warships to Australia were resumed is a false premise. We do not have access to the necessary information to make an informed judgment on the safety of such port calls because the United States Navy would not in 1972 give adequate information and still will not give adequate information to foreign governments who are expected to host its nuclear warships. Time and time again the Senate inquiry has been stymied because of lack of information from the United States Navy. So much for our equal relationship. That notion is not only nonsense and insulting; it is also dangerous. Whose interests are being served by the visits of the nuclear navies? Not ours, because we are targeted by the Soviets whenever the ships are in port. Right now Sydney is targeted because of the presence there of the United States ship Midway.

It is outrageous that the Australian Government allows its people and its ports to be used by any foreign nuclear navy-especially when it does not have basic information on which to make a judgment about the so-called safety of such visits. In conclusion, I want to emphasise that Mr Crancher's letter of 23 April 1987 to Mr Greenslade of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission reveals that there was no documentation of the specific fact finding tour undertaken by AAEC officials in 1972 to back up the 1976 document.
Sitting suspended from 1.09 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: JAPANESE SHIPBUILDERS: LETTER FROM MR JOHN HALFPENNY

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware of a letter from his Victorian Labor Party Senate ticket colleague, Mr John Halfpenny, to Mitsubishi Australia Ltd in which Mr Halfpenny accuses Mitsubishi and two other Japanese shipbuilders of being, in Mr Halfpenny's words, `less than honourable' in the way they allegedly implemented what he describes as an `understanding' about Australian participation in a contract associated with the North West Shelf project? I ask whether the Minister is further aware that in his letter Mr Halfpenny overtly threatened the shipyards with industrial action by saying:

QUESTION.PARA: I feel no longer obliged to encourage the co-operation of Australian unions and their members.

Does the Minister's Department, which was apparently party to the negotiations referred to, agree with Mr Halfpenny's assessment of the Japanese attitude? Indeed, does the Minister agree with it? If he does not agree, will he dissociate the Australian Government from this latest example of his Senate ticket colleague's industrial blackmail tactics?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the particular letter to which Senator Chaney referred, although I was, I suppose, generally aware of a course of discussion on which Mr Halfpenny has been embarked now for some months with Japanese firms about the shipbuilding contract associated with the North West Shelf project. It is not an enterprise in which my Department has been other than peripherally involved, to my knowledge. As such, I am not able, even if I were willing, to comment on that part of the question.

ANSWER.PARA: All I would say, however, about Mr Halfpenny's general role in the North West Shelf project negotiations for the supply of a maximum amount of Australian content and material during the construction phase is that his role in relation to that project-and I have been closely associated with it over the last 2 1/2 years-has been highly constructive and very well regarded by both government and all sectors of involved Australian industry. Mr Halfpenny has been a key member of the national liaison group that was established by myself and Mr Parker, the Western Australian Minister for Minerals and Energy, just over two years ago to bring together the North West Shelf joint venturers, the two Australian governments involved, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and its affiliate unions and all the relevant sectors of Australian industry, including in particular heavy engineering, in an attempt to minimise the friction and maximise the amount of Australian content associated with the project.

I am pleased to be able to say that the level of 72 per cent Australian content was achieved in the domestic gas phase of that particular project, while the level of the Australian content in the liquefied natural gas project-the export phase of the project-which involved much more sophisticated technology and, as such, could perhaps have been expected to result in a rather lower level of Australian content, has so far produced Australian content of the order of 70 per cent. To the end of April 1987, sub-contracts and procurement orders for the LNG project totalled $1,900m, with 68 per cent of this amount sourced in Australia.

I have to say that Mr Halfpenny has been a very constructive influence in achieving that result. While I am unable to comment about the specifics of the particular matters relating to shipbuilding to which Senator Chaney referred, so far as all other aspects of this project, with which I am very familiar, are concerned, my description of Mr Halfpenny's role is as exactly as I have just given it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's glowing praise for Mr Halfpenny's role in this matter. Is the Minister aware of the threats which have been made by Mr Halfpenny that there will be industrial action against ships which are involved in this project if the people who are being threatened do not comply with what Mr Halfpenny has requested? Does he agree with the use of this sort of industrial blackmail to maximise Australian participation, which seems to be the point for which he is praising Mr Halfpenny? I draw his attention to the use of similar tactics by the Newcastle State dockyards which are a less than honourable part of that institution's traditions. I ask the Minister: Does he approve of the use of that sort of tactic for the purposes for which he is praising Mr Halfpenny?

—Industrial blackmail has been no part of the armoury of anyone associated with the national liaison group, including Mr Halfpenny and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, in achieving the results I have referred to in the construction phase of the LNG project.
—Do you know that or are you just fibbing?

—I happen to know that that has been the case so far as the on-shore and off-shore construction phase in north-west Australia of the LNG project is concerned, which was the area with which I said I was familiar-not as to every last event obviously, but as to the general ebb and flow.
—What about the ships?

—As to the ships, I said I am not familiar with that aspect. I am certainly not aware of any such threats having been made by Mr Halfpenny, and I do not propose to answer hypothetical questions from Senator Chaney on this matter or on anything else.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the transcript of an interview with the National Director of the Australian Taxpayers Association heard on Tuesday's Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program AM on the subject of income splitting. Has the Government prepared estimates of the costs to revenue if an income splitting proposal were implemented? If so, what is the estimate? Does the Government share Mr Risstrom's doubt about the capacity of a government to realistically fund such a proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did hear part of that interview with Mr Risstrom on AM, and I have looked at the transcript of it since. Senator Giles asked me what the cost to revenue of income splitting would be. The estimated cost is $2.85 billion. That is almost $3 billion. The fact that the National Director of the Australian Taxpayers Association was equivocal about the capacity of the Government to fund that sort of proposal does not surprise me. The equivocation was expressed as follows. The interviewer asked Mr Risstrom:

ANSWER.PARA: Could the Opposition in government realistically fund this sort of proposal:
Mr Risstrom replied:
I don't think anybody knows until we learn about it . . .

And so it went on. I suppose that, compared with the other set of irresponsible fiscal commitments that the Opposition has been throwing around the place, an extra $3 billion hardly matters. It just adds $3 billion to the set of both expenditure and taxation promises which would add $10 billion to the deficit. If we are already up to $10 billion, some people might argue that another $3 billion does not really matter that much, or that it is hardly worth counting. What in fact would happen, I expect, is what happened in 1977-78; that is, during an election campaign the Liberal Party of Australia ran, day after day, full page newspaper advertisements saying: `Liberals give you tax cuts'. There was a large hand with as many $5 notes as could be stuffed between the fingers on that large hand. One could not count them for sure, but there were certainly several hundred dollars in $5 notes in the hand. That was their approach in the election campaign, and on 1 February, yes, there was a new tax schedule. But on 1 July John Howard put the taxes up again. The fistful of fivers lasted for just five months. `Liberals give you tax cuts'-for a little while. Then on 1 July they stuck the tax rates up again to above what they were before. That was a pea and thimble trick presided over by Mr Howard, and I have no doubt that that is what he has in mind again. He has in mind a variant of that dirty little trick that he pulled on the electorate in 1977 and 1978.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I remind the Minister that 10 days ago she admitted that 44,000 Austudy applications were awaiting processing and that students in financial difficulties should contact the Department of Education in their State. Is the Minister aware that students are having terrible trouble getting help because they are being met by either a recorded message or an apparently continually engaged telephone? Is she further aware of a letter in Tuesday's Age newspaper from Mr Bay, the welfare officer at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology, which states that the extreme financial pressure on students caused by the Austudy payments delay has more than trebled the amount in student loans paid out by the RMIT this year compared with last year and that there has been a dramatic increase in the number of referrals to agencies such as the Salvation Army for food vouchers? Instead of merely expressing regret at these delays, which are causing such hardship, what positive action will the Minister take to overcome what Mr Bay describes as this administrative `stuff up' by the Hawke Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a few things to say about Austudy and its payments. The first thing is that more students than ever before-many more than under the Fraser Government-are already in receipt of Austudy payments. Although there have been some delays, most delays have been substantially overcome. I do not know whether Senator Newman was directing her remarks to a particular office, say, the Victorian office-she quoted a letter in the Age-or the office in her own State. Many thousands of students have received emergency payments of their Austudy entitlements by contacting their local member or my office, so there has been substantial progress in meeting the needs of students in serious difficulties.

ANSWER.PARA: I find it ironic that Senator Newman will rise to her feet and complain about delays in payment of student assistance when she is a member of a party whose leader, John Howard, has promised that students next year will not just have to worry about late Austudy payments but will have to pay an average of $10,000 a year in fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. This sort of gross misrepresentation of the Opposition's policy is quite improper and I will object to it if the Minister persists. It is an absurd thing that Question--

—Whether or not I have a point of order will never be determined if Senator Evans keeps babbling away, Mr President. My point of order is that the Minister is clearly debating the question. In addition, she is offensively misrepresenting the Opposition's policy position and there is no reason why the Opposition should tolerate that. It is quite disorderly.
—There is no point of order. I have no power as to how the Minister shall answer a question and I interpret that she is dealing with an area of her responsibility.

—Senator Newman's question referred to the financial circumstances of higher education students. In response, it is quite proper for me to point out that under the policies endorsed by a Liberal government, new higher education students and even some students already in the system would be facing full fees next year. Two days ago I quoted for the enlightenment of the Senate the words of Senator Chaney's leader, John Howard, speaking on the John Laws program. I quoted him precisely and accurately. I said: If Senator Chaney wants to deny that his leader said this or that this is the policy, let him do so. He did not. John Howard has said that under a government of which he would be the Prime Minister, universities and colleges would charge full fees if they so wished for students coming into their institutions and that a certain number of places-he did not say that that would be the present 400,000 places or so that we have funded during the rapid growth under our policies-would be maintained as free places, but that the rest would be subject to full fees.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, nobody can challenge my statement that full fees can amount to as much as $25,000 a year for veterinary science students, that the full fee for law students is $6,000 or thereabouts and that the average full fee for a higher education course is $10,000. I say in reply to Senator Newman that, if she is acting on behalf of her student constituents, she should find some answers for them when they ask: `What will happen to us next year when, far from our worries that our Austudy payments might be held up, our real problem might be that we will have to turn around and find $10,000 to pay for our year's study?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I recognise that the Minister answered long, but she did not answer the question. I ask whether she is concealing the bungle in her own Department. Is she denying it? Why is there so much need for these emergency payments of which she seems to be so proud? Is that not an admission of defeat by her own Government? How is it that her Department has managed twice to lose an application form from one of my constituents? How is it that Australian students who have already run out of their holiday money and are off welfare benefits still cannot get Austudy money from her Department?
—Order! Senator Ryan can answer those parts of the question which were supplementary. There was also another question involved.

—The payment of Austudy is substantially complete as far as higher education students are concerned. Some payments are still outstanding. Some of those late payments were a result of students giving inadequate information. An emergency system for processing students in economically difficult circumstances has been in place and has worked very successfully. If the best Senator Newman can do when a student goes to her with a problem is to get up and make a fuss in the Senate, I would say that her constituent is very badly represented by her. What sensible senators and members are doing-I have invited every member of the Government and the Opposition to do this-is to immediately contact my office or the Department of Education and have the matter resolved. It seems to me that Senator Newman is holding her constituent to ransom so that she can make a phoney fuss in the Senate instead of doing what any decent representative would do, and get the payment for the student.

—I ask the Minister for Finance representing the Treasurer about an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) that was moved by the Australian Democrats and passed by a majority of the Senate on Monday night. Is it correct that the amendment may have rendered some of the provisional tax arrangements of the tax system unworkable? If so, what action does the Government plan to take about this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I advised the Senate when that amendment was being debated that if it was carried it would make the Act unworkable because of internal inconsistency plus the fact that the specific clause is functionally inoperable. A minute from the Australian Taxation Office, which I shall table later, states:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the amendment cannot be applied in its present form because

at the time of its application it depends on there being an actual taxable income from primary production/abnormal income of the year of income, a figure that is not available because, by definition, the year of income would have only just begun at the relevant time;

I told the Senate on Monday night that that was the case. Over and above the internal inconsistency, the clause that the Senate put through is itself inoperable. It is, by definition, virtually inoperable. The Senate was told that and ignored it. I think that the amendment was a Vigor special; it was dropped in in about the last half hour of debate and accepted by Senator Vigor's long suffering colleagues among the Australian Democrats, and then somebody showed it to the National Party-it refers to primary producers' tax and exemptions-upon which National Party senators started twitching, jerking and salivating, in the way they usually do when they hear phrases like that. The National Party senators said: `This is good; we will support it'. Then the National Party flea on the Liberal Party tail went along to the Liberal Party and said: `You should vote for this'. Senator Short, who in the Liberal Party has responsibility in the Senate for tax matters, accepted it, even though he was told that it would make the Bill inoperable. This is one of the most irresponsible acts of sabotage that this Senate has yet committed, and that is saying something. Senator Coates asked me what the Government intends to do about it. There is nothing much that we can do about it at this stage because those obstructers, those saboteurs, those mindless maniacs on the other side, still will not accept that the amendment passed by the Senate has to be dropped.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: Is Senator Walsh going for the Treasurer's prize for vulgar abuse, Mr President? Will you let him get away with it? I am sick of this sort of unparliamentary language.
—I ask Senator Walsh to withdraw that comment.
—Certainly, Mr President. I am happy to do that. The fact remains, however, that because of the irresponsible actions of the Senate on Tuesday night it is impossible--

—Order! There is a standing order concerning reflecting on a vote of the Senate. The question was in order because it asked about government action, but I remind the Minister not to reflect on such a vote.

—I withdraw that, Mr President. Senator Short has the distinction of putting out a Press release-his first Press release as shadow Minister for Finance-which said that the payment on the national debt, or public debt interest, amounted to $55 billion in a year. That was his first action as shadow Minister for Finance, to say that public debt interest was $55 billion a year. About the next time he was heard of was when he committed the Liberal Party to voting for this stupid amendment that, I suspect very strongly, originated from Senator Vigor.
—Not only innumerate but illiterate.

—As Senator Gareth Evans reminds me, he is illiterate as well as innumerate. No wonder he got out of Treasury, as I said before. It was probably getting ready to kick him out if that is a fair sample of his competence.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked what the Government intends to do about it. We ought to amend it pronto and delete that amendment. Since there is no indication that we can get any co-operation from any of that gaggle of people over the other side, I do not think there is much point in doing that. If the Opposition offers to correct the blunder that it made on Monday or Tuesday night I will certainly see what can be done within the time available to have the Bill fixed up. Failing that, the action proposed is as I forecast on Monday or Tuesday night, and that is that we will be bringing in an amending Bill very early in the Budget session of Parliament. I table the minute provided by the Australian Taxation Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Communications comment on a report in the Age this morning that the Fairfax group will start legal action against the cross-ownership rules forbidding a media proprietor from owning a television licence and a newspaper which has more than 50 per cent of its distribution within the market to which the television licence applies? Does this mean that Holmes a Court and Fairfax will be able to emulate Murdoch and litigate endlessly to postpone disposing of their illegal media investments? Was this possibility canvassed in the telephone conference, mentioned in today's Australian Financial Review, between Mr Keating, Mr Duffy and the media moguls on Friday night, when presumably Labor Ministers sought and gained the approval of those who stood to benefit most from the media sell-out, before concluding their deal with the Joh Nationals? Does this mean that the Hawke Government need not have bothered legislating to achieve its sell-out of the Australian media to large multinational and domestic corporations since media owners are a law unto themselves?

—It is not surprising that a party which believes in fairies at the bottom of the garden should take off on such flights of fancy as that which was demonstrated in the last part of that question. If I can give a bit of gratuitous advice to the Australian Democrats, I suggest that they pay less attention to the fairies at the bottom of the garden and more attention to important things such as getting taxation legislation right and having a taxation law which is technically operable, instead of coming in here like spoilers and saboteurs, at the behest of Senator Vigor admittedly, and slipping in a one-line amendment that makes a Bill inoperable. I suggest that the Democrats pay a bit more attention to the things that matter and indulge their fantasies a bit less than they normally do. I have not read this morning's Age. I did not even see the report. I will refer the question to Mr Duffy for comment and/or opinion.

—Can the Minister for Education, in her capacity as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women, inform the Senate what impact the abolition of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission would have on the administration of the Sex Discrimination Act? Can the Minister comment on the consequences for women seeking redress against sex discrimination?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators will be aware, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is the body vested with the power to deal with complaints under the Sex Discrimination Act, and the Sex Discrimination Commissioner is a member of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. If the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission were abolished there would be no authority vested with the power to make determinations under the Sex Discrimination Act. The Sex Discrimination Commissioner would continue to exist until the Sex Discrimination Act was repealed, but there would be limited scope for inquiries. The Sex Discrimination Act, in other words, would be rendered a toothless tiger. The Sex Discrimination Commissioner would be left with an Act to administer and no guarantee of resources.

ANSWER.PARA: The impact on women would be disastrous as a significant avenue for redress against discrimination on the basis of sex, marital status and pregnancy would be rendered ineffective. Of particular interest to Senator Reynolds is that women in Queensland-also in Tasmania-would be particularly disadvantaged as in those States there is no State legislation to protect women in these ways. It is no surprise that the Opposition is proposing to take this course of action. Women in Australia have been shown all too clearly what sort of priority the official Opposition accords to improving the status of women. Its recent stand on the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Bill indicates that it is not interested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you have to read an answer on that? I thought you knew something about it.

—Senator Chaney likes to interject at this stage. He, of course, was not able to persuade his Leader, John Howard, to maintain any continuity in their attitude on equal employment opportunity. He voted for EEO on one occasion but then, because the Liberals were desperately trying to keep the National Party flea on their tail, they walked across and voted against legislation.
—Sold out.

—They sold out women and sold out on a piece of legislation that their spokesperson at the time, Senator Peter Baume, had advocated. Then, when they realised that they had gone too far, when they saw that they had lost 10 percentage points in the polls in relation to their support by women, they immediately turned around and voted with us on the next stage of the EEO legislation. It has been a pathetic effort, and it is no wonder that they are now proposing to abolish the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. They would vote to abolish that because that is where their true interests lie. Of course, Senator Walters, a well known opponent of EEO, is trying to interject also.

ANSWER.PARA: They are very ill-advised in adopting this policy because the Sex Discrimination Act has been an outstanding success, with over 2,000 complaints being resolved satisfactorily to date. It is quite clear that those 2,000 complainants would have been left with no redress whatsoever in the absence of the Act and the Commission. It is the intention of the Opposition, if it can ever get its act together to state an intention, that no women in Australia-of course, it is a particular problem to women in Queensland and Tasmania-would have the protection of the Sex Discrimination Act under the Opposition's current proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for communications. I remind the Minister that, in relation to the Senate Select Committee on Television Equalisation, about the only unanimous resolution was the recommendation that the Minister appoint an independent consultant about the clearance of band II. The Minister would know that if band II were cleared this would have a significant effect on viewers in Newcastle and Wollongong, as well as the Australian Broadcasting Corporation audiences throughout Australia, as for many of them the signal received would be either completely lost or downgraded. In addition, the cost of these stations moving from band II to UHF would amount to $90m for the viewers, $40m for the Commonwealth and $10m for the commercial broadcasters. In the light of all this, why has the Government notified at least one of the stations involved that the Minister has decided to drop any plans of calling upon a consultant to review this important and expensive change, particularly as the Minister recently said, on 30 March, that he was sympathetic to the idea of engaging a consultant? In addition, the Minister, in relation to extra licences has been quoted as saying: `Any new services would have to be UHF services with all that that implies about the character of competition between that licensee and existing licensees'.

—If Senator Sheil was quoting me at the end of his question, I think I must have been quoting from a note which the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, had supplied to me-but I do not remember saying it. I will check this with Mr Duffy, but on this issue I believe that the licensees have had warning for a very long period, if not since the time when their licences were granted, that they would be required to move out of band II on to UHF. On the matter of the appointment of a consultant, I do not know anything about that. I will obtain a response from the Minister for Communications and ascertain whether in fact he did write to one licensee and his reason for it. Senator Sheil says that he did. This was quite a technical question, of course-apparently much too technical for the shadow spokesman for Communications, who said on the Sunday program, about 11 or 12 days ago, that, effectively, there should be no regulations in relation to broadcasting. If that were to happen, of course, then anyone who wanted to set up a transmitter could do so and just let it rip. The sort of thing that would occur on a television set tuned into a particular channel or frequency would be that there would be one picture with about three shadows behind it, as the four transmitters would be broadcasting on the same frequency. As to which picture was dominant would be related to the power of the transmitter and perhaps to some topographical and geological factors. I think that the shadow Minister for Communications has learnt a bit since then. I believe that Mr Duffy told me that either he or some officers from the Department did take Mr Beale through a bit of a training course on this matter a couple of days ago, and they produced the graphs and charts, and the sorts of things that I have seen before, which make it easier to understand what things can be done in broadcasting throughout the spectrum that is available-as well as those things which cannot be done. However, I will see what the Minister for Communications has to say about the question of a consultant.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the progress--
—Try asking him a question about how to manage business.

—He is a very effective manager of business. Can the Minister inform the Senate of progress on the North West Shelf project and about the impact that this project is likely to have on Australia's future balance of payments and our energy security?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My only regret, Mr President, is that I have used some of this material earlier in Question Time in answer to a question asked by Senator Chaney. Given the Channel 9 Sunday program last weekend, which some honourable senators may have seen, which raised some question marks about the North West Shelf project, I think it is important to make the point that, notwithstanding some of the problems that do exist with the difficulties that Western Australia is having in absorbing the contracted gas volumes in the domestic phase of this project, the Government and I are extremely confident that the export phase of the project will proceed as planned and that the project will continue to provide significant benefits for both Western Australia and the nation as a whole for a long time to come. It would be well known that the North West Shelf natural gas project is the largest resource project ever to be undertaken in this country, its being some two and a half to three times the size of the Snowy Mountains project.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's approach has been to do all that we can in putting together a tax and royalty regime which will make the project effective and, in relation to the announcement that I made earlier today about the crude oil tax review, it may be noticed that the decision to reaffirm existing policy on condensate production and the excise treatment of that was expressly designed to give a further degree of assurance to the North West Shelf project venturers about the viability of that project and to ensure its continued development through to fruition. I have already mentioned the achievements that have been made in this project as far as Australian content is concerned. The other point to mention, apart from the other obvious employment spin-offs that have been associated with that, is that the project will have a number of significant long term benefits for Australia's balance of payments. The substitution of natural gas for petroleum products used by industrial, commercial and residential consumers in Western Australia will reduce our oil import bill for at least the next 20 years. Condensate production will either earn valuable export revenue of up to $1 billion a year at today's prices or, if consumed domestically, reduce our oil import bill during the 1990s by a similar amount. Liquefied natural gas exports are estimated to be worth around $2 billion a year, in 1986-87 dollars, once the plateau level of 5.8 million tonnes a year is reached in 1994. That of course will rival the traditional great earners of foreign exchange in this country, namely, coal, wheat, iron ore and wool.

Exports will start generating income in about two years time, with exports being scheduled to commence in October 1989. A project of these dimensions, with its total cost of $12 billion, bringing gas from 3 platforms, 135 kilometres out to sea, and liquefying and exporting some 6 million tonnes of gas per year, using seven specialised tankers, is really a very impressive one on any scale. Undoubtedly, it will encounter its share of problems but, as I said at the outset, I am confident that it will proceed to be an excellent example of Australia's ability to construct and to run such an impressive resource project.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Minister will recall telling the Senate on 14 May that Mr Simon Crean was wrong to say, as he had said on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation television on mini-Budget night, that the Australian Council of Trade Unions had a commitment from the Government to increase family allowances. In fact, the Minister said: `There is no private commitment to the ACTU.' Is the Minister aware that the Prime Minister will meet an ACTU delegation, led by Mr Bill Kelty, in Canberra tonight in an attempt to keep the unions quiet for the duration of the election campaign, so that strikes such as that which shut down the New South Wales south coast, and guerilla action against metal trades employers in Victoria will be held off until after 11 July? What price is the Government prepared to pay to guarantee industrial peace for the next 5 weeks? Will the Minister tell the people of Australia and the Senate what commitments the Government will give the ACTU at tonight's meetings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite aware of the meeting tonight between the ACTU and Ministers of the Government. This does not surprise me; they take place fairly regularly, just as do meetings between government Ministers and leaders of the business community, for example. That is the pattern of government that we have adopted since we have been in government in this country, and that will continue. There is nothing extraordinary or surprising about this. Senator Baume's question has been fired up by the headline of a newspaper article this morning and I understand that. However, let me say this: When I said what I said on 14 May about private undertakings to the ACTU I meant it. They were not private undertakings; they were public undertakings. This Government has said all along that it intends to introduce a family package in the context of the Budget.
—Why didn't you announce it on the thirteenth?
—Senator Messner may realise that a statement was made on 13 May and it dealt--
—They were initial Budget measures.

—No. Can the honourable senator tell me what additional government outlays were in the package of 13 May? It has been said all along that the Government would do that in the context of this year's Budget.
—Exactly. That is why I am saying: `Why didn't you tell us?'.
—Look, `Alley Oop', be quiet for just one moment, put away your club and sit back and have a bit of a sleep.
—You are making it a lot easier.

—It is no good carrying on with silly interjections. I see that Senator Messner has been joined by his other troglodytic mate. In answer to Senator Baume's question, let me say this: No particular private undertaking was given to the ACTU on this matter; it is a matter which concerns a wide section of the community and it is to those people that we, as a government, make the undertaking and it is to those people we will deliver a family package.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Baume, in the other part of his question, sought to imply that the Government was meeting the ACTU to try to hose down a few industrial stoppages around the place. He asked me what price the Government will pay. I will tell him the price it will pay. Ministers in this Government will be working very hard in the next five weeks to keep honourable senators opposite away from the treasury bench because the people of Australia know--

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have to work very hard.

—We do not mind that at all. The people of Australia know that if honourable members opposite ever got near the treasury bench the level of industrial disputation in this country would go back to what it was in the Fraser days. Under the Liberal Government the level of industrial disputation was twice what it is today. The Opposition's present leader, Mr Howard-he might last until the election-is on record as saying: `We are prepared for five years of industrial warfare in order to try to settle some of these problems'. In saying that no doubt he was inspired by some of the forces outside the Liberal Party who put him up to that statement. That is the price we will pay. We will continue what we have been doing for a long time-improving industrial relations in this country-and we will do it by a process of consultation. We will not do it by the silly methods which the Fraser Government adopted and to which this country can, at its peril, return.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I had asked the Minister what commitments the Government will give the ACTU at tonight's meeting. As he has introduced the newspaper report, I ask him in that context: Will the Minister specifically deny the report that there will be top level talks aimed at neutralising industrial relations during the Federal election campaign? Will he specifically deny the import of the Australian Financial Review report?

—There are always top level talks on a regular basis between the Government and the ACTU about a variety of matters. The meeting which will take place tonight will be no different at all from any other meeting which is designed to reduce the level of industrial disputation in this country and to improve productivity and industrial relations.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to concern and criticism about apparently poor levels of investment activity occurring in manufacturing industries. Is the Minister able to report on investments which have been committed in particular sectors of manufacturing industry? Will he indicate whether any such details, if available, support the gloomy picture painted by the Opposition parties?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This type of question is sometimes called a dorothy dix question and this question is a dorothy dix question because I want to provide an answer to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, who asked a thoughtful question about this issue the other day, and to Senator Messner, who asked a thoughtless question about this issue the week before. The picture is not as gloomy as the Opposition would like to paint it. In the March quarter of the national accounts released last week, on 27 May-perhaps that is a little earlier than last week; it is 8 days or so ago-business investment increased at an annual rate of 12.3 per cent in the six months to March. Australian Bureau of Statistics investment expectation figures also released last week show an expected decline in future investment-I think that was one of the points raised in Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's question. These expectations were formed prior to the well applauded May economic statement which is expected to lead to declining interest rates.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's question last week, I indicated that I received, as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, regular reports on investments committed for particular sectors of manufacturing industry. I would be pleased to share some of that information with her. While the reports provide a partial picture of investment activity, nonetheless they are a good indicator of commitments to investment-they are commitments to investment, not shadowy suggestions of better things to come. I will refer to those matters. I identified four or five industry sectors. In the pulp and paper manufacturing industry, investment currently committed is in the order of $200m. In the steel industry the investment currently committed is $324m. At the end of March 1987 the total authorised investment of Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd. was $1.24m and actual investment was $1.1 billion.

In the motor vehicle industry-I can specify the companies if the honourable senator wishes-total capital expenditure by vehicle manufacturing companies will exceed $1.5 billion in the years from 1987 to 1989. In the chemicals and plastic industries the committed investment to take place next year is $270m. In the textile, clothing and footwear industry committed investment to take place this year is $44.5m. Those are some examples; I can specify them by companies if Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle wishes. The other point I would like to make is that to my knowledge there are investment plans in those sectors which I think are more than double the figures I have given but, for reasons of commercial confidence, I cannot discuss them in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think the Minister has overlooked the food processing area. Will he outline future investment plans in that area?

—I would very much like to outline that investment figure. I gave Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle figures for four or five sample industries. I would not like to outline the figures for food processing today; I would prefer to do that tomorrow.

—Mr President, you will be aware that in the next few weeks parliamentary attendants will be engaged in a familiarisation program at the new Parliament House. Are you aware that those attendants will be required to be paid site allowance in addition to their normal salary? Is this site allowance paid to all staff employed by this Parliament who attend the new Parliament House for familiarisation? What is the reason for these extraordinary payments and how extensive are these rorts?

—As part of the general staff development and preparation for occupying the new building, all attendants periodically make familiarisation tours of the new Parliament House site. These tours are of about one hour's duration and occur every six months. No site allowance has been sought or is paid for these visits. At present the Parliament has received a claim for a site allowance on behalf of Joint House Department technical services staff engaged in duties on the site-and I assume that those are full time duties. This claim is currently the subject of negotiation. I have been advised that no other employees of the parliamentary departments, including parliamentary security attendants, have made a claim for a site allowance at this stage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has his attention been drawn to a Press statement emanating from the National Health and Medical Research Council meeting in Hobart two days ago in which the NHMRC supported the establishment of a national body to control all areas of biomedical ethics, including in vitro fertilisation research? I quote from the report:

QUESTION.PARA: In endorsing the establishment of a national bioethics body, the NHMRC accepted recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation.

Is it a fact that the NHMRC has accepted the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee, which recommended legislation to establish a national body and also recommended legislation making unlawful any destructive non-therapeutic experimentation which frustrated the development of a human embryo? As it is now eight months--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want an extension of time?

—I do not have too many questions. As it is now eight months since the Senate Select Committee reported and more than two years since the introduction of my Bill concerning human embryo experimentation, when will the Government make its views clear on this subject? Is it likely to do so before the next election? What is meant by the words in the NHMRC statement `a Health Minister's and Attorneys-General advisory committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen a report of the proceedings or resolutions-if they were formal resolutions as such-or Press releases emanating from the meeting of the National Health and Medical Research Council which was apparently held in Hobart yesterday. However, about three minutes before Question Time my attention was drawn by Senator Harradine to the fact that Australian Associated Press carried some reports purporting to be from that meeting. Insofar as the NHMRC is alleged to have supported the creation of a national body to deal with questions of biomedical ethics in Australia, that would be consistent with accepting a recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation in that that Committee did say, basing it in part on the model of the Asche Committee, the report of the Family Law Council and the report of the New South Wales Premier's Women's Advisory Council, that there should be such a national body established of a broadly representative kind, chaired by an eminent lay person and carrying out the task of setting guidelines, monitoring research and indeed approving research protocols. Insofar as the NHMRC claims-in the terms of Senator Harradine's question-to be endorsing one of the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee, that would be true. However, as far as I know it would not be true to say that the NHMRC has endorsed other elements of the Senate Committee report. I imagine that, if it were consistent with its previous position, the NHMRC would not be looking to a legislative framework setting down the basic ethical guidelines as recommended by a majority in that report, nor would it be endorsing the actual recommendation of the Committee that destructive experimentation on human embryos not be permitted.

ANSWER.PARA: On Senator Harradine's question about the relationship between the NHMRC and the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and the Health Ministers Council, I point out that the NHMRC is very low in that hierarchy and nothing that it says could pre-empt the deliberations by those bodies on the material and matters raised by the Senate Committee report. Nor can it pre-empt deliberations by the Government. In answer to the final part of Senator Harradine's question, I have not had an opportunity to consult the Minister, but I doubt very much whether in the election period a matter of such high policy content would be decided, given the normal constraints that apply to governments during the period from the double dissolution onwards.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that there is an understanding in this place that the Government will respond to Senate committee reports within three months? Will the Minister agree that even now, as acknowledged by the NHMRC, there is community concern about the rapidly increasing area of biomedical research and that this is a major matter of public importance on which it would be appropriate for the Government to make a determination now?

—It would be appropriate for the Government to respond as soon as practicable but the Senate Select Committee itself recognised that this would not be a matter for this Government alone and that the best way forward for Australia-being a country in which the Federal system has at times caused very arbitrary and artificial divisions in the response of various geographical areas to matters which are of equal concern and should be resolved in a uniform way-was by consultation in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and the Health Ministers Council in order to ensure that we have a national system of accreditation of those institutions which might undertake such experimentation and to ensure a supplementing of those matters which are appropriate for Commonwealth legislation or executive government involvement by equal and complementary legislation or executive action by State governments. Insofar as our Government has been in consultation with State governments, that probably accounts for the time lapse that has occurred. I hope that this will be resolved by the time the next Parliament meets.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the intended proclamation of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act on 1 July 1987 and the publication on that date of a massive list covering artefacts, documents, paintings, relics, craftwork, stamps, coins, exploration equipment and implements, diaries, furniture and other objects which reflect the particular nature of the Australian experience. What steps are in hand for Customs officers to check outgoing passengers to ensure that the provisions of the Act are complied with? —Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce received any further information about industrial disputes affecting metal trades companies in Victoria?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have received further information and I am particularly glad that Senator Chaney is here because I thought that he would like to hear it.
—I have checked it already. I have the information.
—Of course you have, Senator, but we ought to share these things with the community at large. It was only the day before yesterday when, in a series of questions, Senator Chaney used these words:

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Minister that on Friday he cited the return to work by strikers at Port Kembla as justification of his softly softly approach to industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did it cost them in Port Kembla?

—It cost them a lot less than it cost them in 1982, when 6,000 workers lost their jobs and the steel industry was left in chaos. I want to take up a couple of issues. In the middle of last week Senator Chaney was referring to 20 companies being subject to industrial action. Later it dropped down to five, and yesterday--
—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. This is again a case of clear misrepresentation of what I said.
—It is not a point of order. Sit down.
—I am being helped again by Senator Evans. Mr President, the Minister has misquoted me, I do not know whether intentionally or accidentally, and I object to that.
—Order! There is no point of order. There are other forms open to Senator Chaney.
—The expression I used was `20 companies being subject to industrial action'. As Senator Chaney goes on in his portfolio-shadow portfolio-he will understand what that expression means.

—After what Senator Walters said last night, I am surprised that she mentions the name of Sigmund Freud in this chamber. I hope that he is not obsessing her in any way. Earlier Senator Chaney was asking me about 20 companies being subject to industrial pressure, if you like. Later it became five and yesterday it was one, ANI National Forge. Senator Chaney asked me a question again about that. In respect of each of those questions I said that the Government was doing what it could to bring about a reconciliation of the industrial disputes in those areas. Yesterday the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union recommended a return to work--

—Senator Chaney should get the facts straight. The Victorian Branch of the Metal Workers Union, which Senator Chaney attacked in every question he asked, yesterday recommended a return to work.
