DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN DEMOCRATS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This morning there were reports in the newspapers concerning the pre-selection in South Australia. I wish at this stage to make a statement concerning my relationship with the South Australian division of the Australian Democrats. I can no longer remain associated with the South Australian division of the Australian Democrats, which has successively whittled all the principles of democracy which I hold dear. Last night the Council of the Australian Democrats in South Australia decided to ignore the regulations under the South Australian Constitution which would have put me second on the Australian Democrats ticket.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it is extremely important to point out that I have been a member of the Australian Democrats since its inception more than 10 years ago. I have worked as a member of the National Executive and in almost all its administrative policy and political roles, both within South Australia and federally. I believe that during my time in Parliament I have represented the members of that Party effectively. To this end I have stayed in the Party and worked hard within the structure of the Democrats during the last two years, despite a number of differences of principle, which resulted at an earlier stage in Senator Siddons leaving the Party. I feel at this stage that the Party in South Australia has lost its original basis of honesty, tolerance and compassion. This has been replaced by a cynical, political manoeuvring and dealing which resulted in Lance Milne leaving the Party at the time of the last State election-

TALK.START.PARA: —After he lost pre-selection too.

—No, he did not lose pre-selection. It resulted in Don Chisholm being replaced from the top of the ticket in South Australia following a factional brawl. Similar types of operations have happened in New South Wales and most recently in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make the announcement to this Senate that I will be standing against Janine Haines in South Australia. The form and method in which I will be standing I hope to announce tomorrow. But I wish to make the point clear to the Senate that I shall continue to work effectively within all the portfolio operations which I am still undertaking until the end of this Parliament.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It is a sad day for any political party when one of its members makes an announcement such as Senator Vigor has made. It represents another split in the Australian Democrats. It reminds me of the fact that, when this Government was last elected to office, there were four opposition parties in the Senate. Now there are nine. If we could only sit for another week to allow the National Party to have its preselection, probably there would be 10-or maybe 11-parties. It reminds me of the Agatha Christie story Ten Little Niggers. I am not making a racist comment in saying that.
—Ten green bottles.
—Yes, ten green bottles. The continual fragmentation of the Opposition in the Senate is a matter of concern to the Government. We very much regret it, in terms of the statement made by Senator Vigor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As the leader of one of the two parties that have not suffered a defection during the present Parliament I share some of the sorrow that has been expressed by Senator Button. I look around this place and see Senator Siddons, who led the charge from the Australian Democrats; Senator Vigor, who has discovered at this rather late stage of his lead into the election that he too has to leave the Democrats; Senator Vallentine, who established the precedent by leaving the Nuclear Disarmament Party before it was really formed; and, of course, Senator Georges.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to congratulate the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) for being one of the two leaders of the Australian Labor Party during my political life who have managed to lose a single member of the Caucus under their jurisdiction. The only other person was Captain Sam Benson-and I see Senator Georges resuming his seat-who managed to win a seat against the endorsed Labor Party candidate when he was ejected from the Labor Party for crossing the floor. Senator Georges may set out to follow that precedent of Captain Sam Benson. I can only say to Senator Georges that if we have to have somebody from the Labor side it may as well be him. I would just like to acknowledge the fact that the Liberal members of parliament have stayed in a tight cohesive group and I thank them for their support and assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It is an extraordinary development that has occurred in the Senate. I agree with Senator Chaney except for the fact that there has been a defection from his Party, of which perhaps he is not aware. A person who has been prominent, active and a power in this place has indicated that for reasons which he is not prepared to spell out he will not renominate. If Senator Chaney looks at that carefully, he will see it is a defection in a sense. It is very sad that a person should be brought to the point, when he was able if he so wished to carry on in the Party which he has represented so well for so long in this place, of defection. I just want to bring a sobering note into this debate. The person about whom I am speaking, of course, has announced his resignation from this place. His retirement-
—Senator Elstob.

—No, it is Senator Withers. The difference with Senator Elstob, Senator Coleman and others is that they are retiring for other reasons. They are forced by a variety of rules of the Australian Labor Party or because of circumstances previously announced not to stand again. But that was not the case with Senator Withers. I point out to the Senate and to the Liberal Party the enormity of that decision by a man, who, in his time, was an extremely powerful figure.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I had just commenced making comments on the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill. I started by saying that protection of privacy is terribly important. But the attitude in the community towards crime and criminals is something that we really need to take very seriously. I have become more and more concerned in recent times that there always seems to be this folk hero aura about criminals-saying that it is not right to take all means possible to apprehend criminals, that they should be played on gentlemen's rules and that certain ways of apprehending them generally should be excluded. From that flows the fact that police force resources are stretched very tightly. No credit is given to government. People do not know how difficult it can be to apprehend the various miscreants in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Telecommunications interception is very much becoming a last resort. The police do not like it. The cost of performing telecommunications interception is a real budget wrecker. But we must take into account that it is effective. It provides good evidence in court and under some circumstances it can save a considerable amount of time. I do not believe that we should give any comfort to criminals. To make them realise that the use of the telephone can be very risky is most useful as far as their apprehension is concerned. We must protect the rights of people. We need to make sure that the methods we use are as up to date and likely to result in apprehension as possible. Simplicity in courts is important. We do not wish to make the process more difficult. In this regard I disagree with Senator Cooney and the Bill before us. They agree that there are certain things we ought to do to make it more difficult to effect an interception.

I was a member of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception. In the course of taking evidence we did not interview one law enforcement agency which supported the proposition in the legislation; that is, that there should be only one office to look after interceptions. There is absolutely no demonstrable advantage in having only one office. The only reason for that provision is to pacify certain of the civil liberties groups, left wing organisations and divisions within the Australian Labor Party. Every law office in the States of Australia, the joint drug forces and the National Crime Authority, in my opinion, should have access to Telecom Australia arrangements and be able to pursue the matter from there. All States preferred to have interceptions under their control. There is a thing amongst police officers that they have a certain territorial imperative, that they do not like sharing information. The more hands information goes through and the more organisations are involved the more likely it is that there will be a loss of security.
Crime Legislation

The other matter I take issue with is the level of the judges. There is absolutely no reason in the world to believe that a Federal Court judge is superior to a Supreme Court judge for the purposes of the taking of an affidavit. This is a stupid, hairsplitting arrangement. Two of the jurisdictions we are talking about do not even have any Federal Court judges within their boundaries. It is nonsense to make people go elsewhere to try to get the approval of a Federal Court judge.

I believe that the problems will be overcome when the Federal Government makes the necessary resources available to the States and gives them the opportunity to accept them if they wish. That would be a far better and simpler solution. There needs to be a complete and satisfactory audit. I can find no fault with that proposition. But there should also be a total ban on the manufacture, import, sale or ownership of bugging devices. This could begin in the Commonwealth area of law enforcement. We could then pursue ways of getting other areas of jurisdiction to follow.

There are law enforcement funding problems. I guess that there always will be. We will not be able to provide the desired amount of money to fund the fight against crime to the extent we believe is necessary. But if we are genuine and if we provide adequate protection and adequate safeguards there are no grounds for not solving crime in the most appropriate way. I am reminded regularly by people who are involved in this area that the Australia Card-what a debacle that was-would have been far more obtrusive on people's rights and privacy than the selective telecommunications interception of people on the basis of their being suspected of being involved in a high level of crime. Criminals who doubt the security of their telephones are often forced into the open. That is one of the advantages of telecommunications interception. If they believe that it is possible that their telephones are being intercepted they will go into the open where they are much easier to trace in a variety of ways.

I believe that the Bill does not go far enough. It helps the crims. They would be quite happy with the legislation because I think they were expecting it to be further up the track than it is. It does not please those who really want to clean up major crime. The minority report of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception covers the issues. Although the report is a start, we will amend the legislation along the lines I have mentioned when we get back into government next month.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the conclusion of the last Parliament in October 1984-I think it was during the election campaign-Mr Costigan presented the final volume of the report of his major investigation of organised crime in Australia. He had already presented a number of interim reports. In Mr Costigan's final report he made further important recommendations about the way in which organised crime should be tackled by governments in Australia, both Federal and State. Mr Costigan recommended that some very major responsibilities be assumed by the Federal Government. During the election campaign the Hawke Government steered away from any significant commitment to implementing the recommendations of Mr Costigan. Nor did it indicate that any sense of urgency was required as a result of the notable investigation over a period of four years by Mr Costigan and his assistants.

SPEECH.PARA: There were two very significant recommendations in the report. One recommendation was that investigators of organised crime should be able to follow what Mr Costigan called `the money trail'. He described in his reports in great detail what he meant by `the money trail', how the recommendation should be carried out and the methods he had adopted which had proved so fruitful to his investigations. One method was to be able to seize as many documents as possible without warning to the organised criminals and then to follow that up with the computer methods pioneered by the Costigan royal commission. One set of documents could be used to get information from other sources and so on. One would then find out where the proceeds of crime had gone. That could be done only by a series of such operations.

Another very important recommendation Mr Costigan made was that there should be uniform drug trafficking laws, both Federal and State, throughout Australia. For some time prior to the report of Mr Costigan and because of the way the Hawke Government had dealt with Mr Costigan, closing up his inquiry as fast as it could in 1984 before he was able to make any proper handover arrangements to the National Crime Authority which took over some of the work he had been doing, we felt that the Hawke Government was not really serious about the pursuit of organised crime. Clearly we were justified in that view. It has taken the Government until the dying days of this Parliament, nearly three years from the time of Mr Costigan's final report-as I have said, the report was released in the middle of the last election campaign in November 1984-to introduce legislation into this Parliament, the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill 1987 and, more particularly, the Proceeds of Crime Bill, to give effect to one of the two major recommendations of Mr Costigan.

It is not as though Mr Costigan's recommendations were new. There had been many recommendations before to the effect that the only really effective way of deterring or dealing with organised crime was to seize and confiscate the proceeds of those crimes. Other commissioners investigating organised crime had pointed out the inadequacies of Australian law in relation to the confiscation of the proceeds of crime, but Mr Costigan highlighted them because of the very sophisticated methods he developed and the very forthright way he went about tackling the problems he confronted in the great task of his inquiry. There is absolutely no justification for the Government having taken this inordinate length of time to introduce this legislation. There is even less justification for the delay, because the former coalition Fraser Government introduced amendment to the Customs Act which enabled the seizure, the freezing and ultimately the forfeiture of proceeds from drug trafficking. That legislation was pioneered by the Fraser Government, admittedly in relation only to drug trafficking, but that was the serious organised crime about which we were concerned at that time. That legislation was passed by this Parliament and it has been given effect. It was shown to have worked. Of course, Mr Costigan highlighted the much wider issue of organised crime, not just in relation to drug syndicates and drug trafficking, but also in relation to the whole range of organised crime. There were findings of other royal commissioners, there were the findings and recommendations of Mr Costigan and there was the precedent set by the Fraser Government, but it took this Government 2 1/2 years to implement those recommendations.

The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill widens the powers of telephone tapping in relation to serious criminal activities and, in particular, in the case of organised crime. The principal Act, the Telecommunications (Interception) Act, was known to have been too restrictive in relation to telephone tapping. Again, a precedent was set by the former coalition Government, which for the first time, allowed interceptions of telephones for the purpose of criminal, as opposed to security, investigations. The former Act applied only to security matters. Again, the Fraser Government showed the way and enable interceptions of telephones by the Australian Federal Police for serious narcotic offences when warrants had been obtained. In that case, again the Government had the prece- dent for the use of telephone interceptions in criminal investigations.

It was quite clear that the step taken by the Fraser Government as far back as 1979 was to be only the first step but, apart from that precedent, I think recommendations were made at about the time this Government took office. Mr Justice Stewart, in his report on the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, indicated the need for wider powers of interception. Ultimately, when the Government was shamed by its delays and negligence into doing something about the New South Wales, or the Age tapes, as they are perhaps better known, and after the Opposition had been calling for this to be done for about a year, the Government gave another commission to Mr Justice Stewart to investigate the Age tapes. About a year ago he reported on the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions and mentioned the value that intercepting telephones would have in investigating serious criminal matters generally and not just in relation to drug trafficking. Mr Justice Stewart had available to him, admittedly illegally obtained, the Age tapes, but he was able to analyse the value of that information to the New South Wales police in their investigations of various crimes. About a year ago the Government introduced a Bill to give some effect to Mr Justice Stewart's recommendations. Even then, in June 1986, it did not have the courage of its convictions to proceed with that legislation-indeed, it probably did not have the power to do so-because of the intransigence of many of its back benchers who delayed that Bill, even within the Government. Here we have a situation where the importance of a particular tool of criminal investigation had been clearly spelt out and a precedent had been provided by the Opposition when it was in government. Based on the experience of the Age tapes, there was a report on the most up to date and full investigation of the whole matter by Mr Justice Stewart but, again, there was another delay when the Bill was sent to the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception. That Committee has performed most valuable work in bolstering the recommendations of Mr Justice Stewart and, although it reported in November last year, again there was further delay before the Government introduced this legislation.

Despite all those delays, the Government still has not got this question right in relation to telephone interceptions. My colleague Senator Alston has already dealt very effectively with the other parts of this package, the Proceeds of Crime Bill and the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill, so I do not intend to deal with them any further, except to emphasise the disgraceful delays that have characterised this Government's whole approach to this question.

The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill is based on recommendations by Mr Justice Stewart and by the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception but, unfortunately, the Bill still does not pick up a number of important recommendations that were made by Mr Justice Stewart. First, Mr Justice Stewart recommended that the warrant should be issued by judges of either the Federal Court of Australia or the Supreme Courts of the States, but this Bill is limited to warrants being issued by judges of a court created by this Parliament, that is, either a Federal Court or a Family Court of Australia judge, and, apparently, certain judges will be selected for that work. The important fact is that there ought to be ready availability of judges in order that the police may obtain the warrants. It would seem to me, as it did to Mr Justice Stewart, to be good sense that judges of the Supreme Courts of the States or Territories should be available to issue such warrants.

The second matter that concerns the Opposition is the failure of the Government to implement fully the recommendation of Mr Justice Stewart that a discretion be given to the judge issuing the warrant to determine whether it is justified in the circumstances of the offence-the gravity of the offence and the other matters that Mr Justice Stewart recommended should be taken into account such as the extent to which privacy may be interfered with and the extent to which the investigation of the crime may be assisted. The two latter matters have been implemented by this legislation, but again the Government has unduly restricted the area of criminal activity that may attract this power of interception of telephones. It has established two different classes. The way it has done it has made it even more complicated. There are differences between the two but, broadly speaking, the power is given only in relation to murder, kidnapping, narcotics offences, or for the purposes of an interception by the National Crime Authority, which would mean in any case of organised crime. The second group comprises offences punishable by imprisonment for at least seven years but involving the loss of life, serious injury, serious risk thereof, serious damage to property, serious fraud and so on. So the power to intercept is confined to this very limited class of cases, despite the recommendation of Mr Justice Stewart that it should be a much wider power exercised at the discretion of the judge.

There are very strange anomalies in this respect. The National Crime Authority, which has rightly been given this power to apply for an interception, has a wider brief than the police will have when they are investigating crime, because the police are confined in this more narrow way by this Bill. The Opposition proposes to move an amendment to widen that power and to bring it more into line with the provisions applicable to the National Crime Authority in terms of the nature of offences. That amendment will be dealt with at the Committee stage.

Mr Justice Stewart also recommended that, in issuing a warrant, a judge be empowered to authorise in some cases that the interception take place without recourse to Telecom. The State police have mobile units with sophisticated equipment, listening devices and so on, which they use under State powers. The Australian Federal Police also have these facilities. It is a weakness in the legislation that power is not given directly to State police. They have to proceed through Federal Police. But, even having proceeded through the Australian Federal Police to obtain a warrant, the State force will then have to proceed through Telecom, except in very limited circumstances. Yet, as I have said, the facilities are available to the police, as they certainly should be, to make these interceptions themselves. There are very substantial delays on the part of Telecom in these matters. Evidence before the Joint Committee indicated in one case that an intercept sought by the National Crime Authority took 19 days to be set up. Obviously that is quite inadequate when there may be a need for a very speedy use of this particular power.

I mention a final matter relating to recommendations of Mr Justice Stewart which have not been taken up by the Government. This matter greatly worries the Opposition and we have a number of amendments concerning it. Mr Justice Stewart's recommendation referred to interceptions which were illegal, in the sense of their being made without the procedures provided under this legislation being followed. Of course, this may involve cases where there was an attempt to follow the procedures, but where for some reason or other there was a failure to do so, thereby making it an illegal interception. Alternatively, it may involve a case of a quite blatant illegality where no attempt whatever was made to follow the law. Of course, that would be a serious offence in itself. In such cases this legislation will render completely inadmissible evidence, which may be of a vital character, concerning serious crime; because the offences for the investigation of which interceptions can be obtained include murder, kidnapping, serious cases of fraud and cases of organised crime.

Where important evidence has been obtained illegally-even if it is the only really effective evidence-this Government's legislation makes it inadmissible in a court simply on that basis. Mr Justice Stewart, in his investigation of the New South Wales tapes, has already given clear evidence of how important such evidence is, and was to the police of New South Wales. Its value, even though it is illegal, can be absolutely immense. Mr Justice Stewart recommended that the admissibility of such material be determined by the common law principles. It has been a principle under the common law for a very long time indeed that the mere fact that evidence has been illegally obtained does not prevent it from being used in criminal proceedings. There is good sense in that and, as I said, Mr Justice Stewart's investigations into the New South Wales tapes are a very modern example of the good sense of the common law.

Those common law principles apply to many other types of evidence given or sought to be given in criminal trials-evidence that may have nothing to do with the interception of telephones. Evidence may be obtained in the investigation of a crime in many other ways which could be in breach of the law. The admissibility of that evidence-the right to use it in a criminal trial-is determined under common law principles, which largely boils down to a discretion of the judge, who decides, in accordance with various criteria that are all well established, whether or not such evidence should be admitted. That principle has been confirmed on several occasions in recent times by the High Court of Australia in a number of important cases. There really are no doubts of a substantial kind about how the common law works in this area. As I said, it will continue to work according to those principles in respect of other types of illegally obtained evidence. Yet this Bill precludes evidence obtained by illegal intercept being used at all, except in relation to past offences, which I think is wrong. A double mistake is made in this Bill, because the admissibility of past evidence obtained through illegal interceptions is in fact preserved. The application of the legislation will be retrospective in some cases; and that in itself is a further objection to the way the Government has gone about this particular matter.

The Opposition will be moving amendments to deal with the two major defects in the Bill. Both defects involve the Government's not following Mr Justice Stewart's recommendations. As I said, there are other weaknesses in the Bill, which I have identified. The minority report of the Joint Select Committee was very critical of the fact that the Government does not trust the State police. That is what it boils down to. It is insisting on the interceptions being made by a unit within the Australian Federal Police and, in the opinion of the Opposition, that is another failure of the Government and a weakness in this Bill.

For those reasons, the Opposition will certainly support this measure. It is a measure that, in effect, we pioneered when in government. It is a very sensible proposal to extend the powers in relation to the interception of telecommunications and this is certainly a Bill that moves in a positive way. However, it is moving too late and we will move further amendments to improve it. I have an amendment which I wish to move to the second reading in respect of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1987 to give effect to the points I have just made. I move:
At end of motion, add:
``, but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(1) its delay in introducing the legislation, and
(2) its failure to fully implement the recommendations contained in Mr Justice Stewart's Royal Commission report of April 1986 into Alleged Telephone Interceptions''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its obvious support in most quarters for these measures, although one could have been forgiven for thinking, given Senator Durack's speech, that support was offered somewhat grudgingly. Be that as it may, criticisms have been made of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill that require brief response at this stage. Other points can perhaps be picked up in Committee. The suggestion that the Government has been slow to act in introducing this legislation ignores the reality of the problems presented by telephone interception, particularly unlawful interception. This is a very complex matter and it raises important questions of principle which must be very thoroughly talked through and thought about before any government commits itself to a course of action.

SPEECH.PARA: I note further that the unlawful interceptions in New South Wales which produced the so-called Age tapes manifestly continued for years without action by the Government. One presumes the existence of such activities was known to the Fraser Government, or at least to the police force under its control. Certainly, plenty of people are now claiming, in retrospect at least, that they knew that this activity was occurring. Nothing was done by the Fraser Government about this whole phenomenon. This Government has, of course, moved to respond to that, and has moved in particular to allow State police to obtain the benefits of lawful telephone interception.

The criticisms about the report not fully implementing in every last chapter and verse the recommendations of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions I think are equally misconceived. It should be stated at the outset that, notwithstanding that this Government has a great respect for Mr Justice Stewart and his reports, they are not the only matters that the Government has had to take into account in formulating an appropriate legislative response. There is the Australian Law Reform Commission's admirable report on privacy and the report of the Joint Select Committee of this Parliament.

It should also be pointed out-and this goes not only to the question of the non-implementation of every last word of the Stewart report but also to the time it has taken for the Government to formulate its response-that the States have been really very tardy in expressing their views on how this whole enterprise should best be carried out. Only two States, Queensland and South Australia, made submissions to the Joint Select Committee, although all police forces commented on the subject. Initially, neither New South Wales nor Victoria would commit themselves to any proposal at all. New South Wales now supports separate State interception, and it had made that clear, but it is not as though we have had the kind of enthusiastic and brisk co-operation from the States that makes for easier legislative preparation. On the contrary, it has been very difficult to get people walking in any kind of marching step at all on this whole matter.

As to the specific criticisms about non-implementation of the Stewart recommendations, I point out that most of those criticisms seem to boil down to two matters, first, the notion that State police should be able to intercept independently of the Australian Federal Police. All I can say in regard to this alleged shortfall in the Government's legislative response is that the Joint Select Committee recommended that all interceptions be conducted through the Australian Federal Police. Procedures are now being worked out that are efficient and rapid, and each law enforcement agency will still be responsible for obtaining its own warrants. I note further that the Australian Police Ministers Council has supported the Bill with its variation from the Stewart recommendations in this respect and its variation from the original recommendations of the individual State police forces. The Australian Police Ministers Council has supported the Bill in a resolution passed on 22 May, so I believe that any lingering affection for the purity of the State-based model should be read against those considerations. I am not sure that Mr Justice Stewart himself would necessarily see any difficulties in the kind of practical model that has now evolved.

The second criticism in relation to the Stewart recommendations was that the Bill, rather than adopting simply broad tests as to the circumstances in which warrants could be issued, proposes a rather narrower approach of specifying particular classes of offences, spelling them out with some precision and only then having regard to the kinds of general criteria that Mr Justice Stewart articulated. My response to that is simply that the Bill does not ignore the tests referred to in the Stewart report. They are the matters to which a judge must have regard in relation to the two classes of offence under the Bill. However, the Government believes that Parliament should define the offences in respect of which telecommunications interceptions should be available and that such a privacy intrusive technique should be available only in respect of serious offences, that is, cases where the public interest and the prevention and detection of crime clearly outweight the privacy of individuals whose communications are interfered with.

I note further that although the tests adopted under the legislation, that is, the definitions of `offence', satisfy the description I have just given it is also the case that the two broad classes of offence for which telecommunications interception warrants may be obtained cover a broad range of criminal behaviour. It should not be thought that there is anything excessively narrowing about the criteria set out in the legislation. No doubt, much more could be said in an extended debate on this Bill, but time is pressing. I believe that I have answered the major criticisms that have been made and I will take up any other criticisms as they arise in Committee. I commend the Bills to the Senate. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is: That the amendment moved by Senator Alston in respect of the Proceeds of Crime Bill be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Michael Baume did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Grimes.)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question now is: That the Bill be now read a second time.
—Order! The question now is: That the amendment moved by Senator Durack in respect of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Michael Baume did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Grimes).

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is: That the Bill be now read a second time.

—The question now is: That the following Bills be now read a second time: Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill 1987, Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1987 and Proceeds of Crime (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are five Bills before the Committee. The only one to which amendments have been circulated is the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1987. Is it the wish of the Committee that that Bill be taken separately and first? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

INTERJECT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 4-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 3, subclause 5 (2), definition of ``class 2 offence'', paragraph (a), leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(a) an offence punishable by not less than 3 years' imprisonment; or''.

The current definition, which requires an additional onus on an applicant for telephone interception to satisfy a court that there will not be an invasion of privacy, applies at the moment to class 2 offences, and those offences, essentially, are ones that involve offences punishable by not less than seven years imprisonment. The Opposition's amendment seeks to reduce that term to three years imprisonment and to delete the seven year provision. The effect of this would be, in effect, to reduce the threshold, to make a range of offences accessible to law enforcement authorities, so that where, say, an organised crime figure was perhaps incidentally involved in the commission of what in this terminology could be described as being a lesser offence, nonetheless, telephones could be tapped in order to intercept a call and to obtain information and evidence that would assist in subsequent prosecution. At present, the hands of the authorities are tied very much by the definition of a class 2 offence and, on that basis, it is the view of the Opposition that the legislation is not wide enough and that the Government has shown an excess of caution. In the circumstances, the Opposition deems it necessary to go down the path that we propose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The obvious difficulty-which ought to be supremely self-evident to a competent lawyer like Senator Alston-is that an amendment couched in these terms is just far too broadly over-reaching. I understand that over 300 offences under Commonwealth law are punishable by not less than three years imprisonment. As such, there would be potential for warrants to be issued for a vast range of offences, quite outside the limits of what we believe to be community acceptability, and certainly outside what this Government is prepared to contemplate. We are concerned, though, to balance the proper claims of law enforcement against equally legitimate claims of privacy and only to allow privacy to be invaded in a grossly intrusive way, which telephone interception involves, in circumstances where the gravity of the offence is such as to clearly demand it.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Crime Authority deals only with organised crime, as defined in the National Crime Authority Act. Therefore, we are talking about courses of criminal conduct, not just separate offences, and in those circumstances it is justifiable for these to be a three year threshold. The NCA can only use its intercept power if it has a special reference-and, obviously, references are only granted to the NCA in the context of courses of criminal conduct, which put that in a rather separate category. The seven year threshold does ensure a minimum level of seriousness before the intercept powers can be used elsewhere, and that is the basis on which the provision has been formulated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We say that there is an inconsistency, because the National Crime Authority does have powers of surveillance in relation to offences punishable by imprisonment of at least three years. In those circumstances there does seem to be an inconsistency in the Bill. If the National Crime Authority can undertake surveillance in relation to relatively lesser offences, it seems anomalous that the hands of the authorities should be tied as they are in the present instance, which means that they would not be able to cover the same ground. We take the view that if the National Crime Authority thinks that it is sufficiently important to undertake surveillance in relation to the hundreds of offences to which Senator Evans has referred there is some likelihood that there will be just as much seriousness and urgency in relationship to intercepts in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 3, subclause 5 (2), proposed definition of ``class 1 offence'', paragraph (c), line 29, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(c) an offence:
(i) that involves 2 or more offenders and substantial planning and organization;
(ii) that involves, or is of a kind that ordinarily involves, the use of sophisticated methods and techniques;
(iii) that is committed, or is of a kind that is ordinarily committed, in conjunction with other offences of a like kind; and
(iv) that involves:
(a) murder;
(b) kidnapping;
(c) a serious trafficking offence; or
(d) any financial dealing relating to an offence referred to in sub-subparagraph (a), (b) or (c); or''.
(2) Page 9, subclause 5 (2), after the proposed definition of ``serious offence'', insert the following new definition:
`` `serious trafficking offence' means:
(a) a narcotics offence; or
(b) any other offence against a law of the Commonwealth, or an offence against a law of a State or Territory, being an offence:
(i) that relates to narcotic drugs; and
(ii) is punishable by imprisonment for life or for a period, or maximum period, of not less than 7 years;''.

The Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception inquired into the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill following the last time it was before this chamber. I was a member of that Committee. It brought down a majority report which recommended a particular definition of what was a serious offence and which offences could require telecommunications interception. The Committee recommended that these offences be murder, kidnapping and organised crime associated with a number of offences or conspiracy to commit any of the above offences. The Government has considerably extended the offences beyond what the Committee recommended. My amendments are designed to return the types of offences back to what the Committee recommended. When a considerable amount of work is done by a committee, it is important that consideration be given to that work. I believe that the Government's proposals are far too general. I am pleased that Senator Alston's amendment was defeated because it was even more general.

The main point the Committee considered was the invasions of privacy involved in this area. We were very concerned to make certain that serious trafficking offences were properly defined and that the range of offences not be extended to include possibly trivial crimes. I am not suggesting that the crimes the Government has mentioned in the legislation are trivial crimes, but some of them could be stretched to allow telephone interception in almost any situation. This is why I highly recommend that the chamber support my amendments to clause 5, which are basically what the majority of the Committee on Telecommunications Interception recommended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure Senator Vigor that the Government took the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception recommendation very closely into account when reconsidering the drafting of the definition of offence clause. I personally was involved in that exercise-in the absence of the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, who I think was overseas at the time-and I remember very well wrestling with the kinds of concepts that were in the JSC report and being attracted by some of them compared with the original drafting of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill. However, it became apparent on close scrutiny that the JSC recommendations on the concept of organised crime were not only quite complicated but also distressingly vague and difficult for practical application in the kinds of circumstances in which warrants might often need to be rather rapidly issued.

SPEECH.PARA: The seriousness of a crime does not necessarily depend on the involvement of two or more persons or substantial planning, sophisticated methods and so on, as referred to by the JSC. That is one useful working definition of organised crime and is helpful for conceptual purposes. It is one that I have used often enough in the past in a previous portfolio, but it is not one that we felt ultimately was very helpful in the rough and tumble real world situations in which one has to have a bit more precision in the statutory definitions. Equally, it was felt that it was important to strike a balance and that, while allowing a reasonably wide range of offences to be subsumed-and certainly serious offences as the community would generally regard them-the range should not be so wide or the language should not be so vague that it was difficult to apply this legislation in practice or only too easy to apply it in a way that would be too overreaching. Those are all of the considerations we sought to balance out. I believe, in short, that we now have the balance right.

Certain offences-the so-called class 1 offences-are defined quite precisely. Murder, kidnapping and narcotics offences are defined elsewhere in the legislation as meaning an offence punishable as provided under section 235 of the Customs Act-that is, in the parent legislation. So a narcotics offence is, for the purpose of the operation of this legislation, quite precisely clear and it basically extends only to the more serious of the drug-type offences. It extends to a clearly defined range of drug offences as set out in that legislation.

Class 2 offences is the more general category and is drafted in this way because of the difficulty of foreseeing all of the statutory offences-and, indeed, common law ones-that might conceivably be applicable and properly found a warrant. It is in the class 2 context that the particular criteria that Mr Justice Stewart identified have their application. The combination of the Stewart criteria as set out in the legislation and the particular description of the kinds of offences that are here involved-personal injury, serious fraud, serious loss to the revenue, and so on-gives sufficient precision to make the operation of the clause useful in practice but not too privacy invading and thus acceptable in principle. For those reasons, we reject Senator Vigor's amendments and hope that the Committee stays with the drafting of the Bill.
Amendments negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: EGG INDUSTRY RESEARCH (HEN QUOTA) LEVY BILL 1987EGG INDUSTRY RESEARCH (HEN QUOTA) LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1987[COGNATE BILLS:NURSING HOMES AND HOSTELS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987WOOL MARKETING BILL 1987WOOL TAX (Nos 1 to 5) AMENDMENT BILLS 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: EGG INDUSTRY RESEARCH (HEN QUOTA) LEVY BILL 1987EGG INDUSTRY RESEARCH (HEN QUOTA) LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Bill 1987, the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Collection Bill 1987, the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the Wool Marketing Bill 1987 and the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1987. In case there is any doubt as to which Bills I am speaking to, I will start with the egg industry legislation. Two of these Bills deal with the egg industry. The aim of the legislative package is to permit the continuation of a levy on egg producers to fund industry research. The Bills will facilitate the collection from producers of levies which will amount to about $250,000 a year, to be matched dollar for dollar by the Commonwealth Government. The outgoing hen and research levies will be replaced with a new research levy based on the producer's licensed hen quota.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation provides that the research levy be set no higher than 10c per hen per annum. The Council of Egg Producers has recommended an initial levy of 3.25c, and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in his second reading speech appeared to have broadly accepted that recommendation. The egg industry in Australia is a $200m a year industry with Australians consuming almost 180 million dozen eggs annually. Egg sales have decreased by about 2 per cent in the last five years, although this has been partly offset by increased sales of manufactured egg products. In response, the egg industry has commissioned a $2m national advertising campaign aimed at increasing egg consumption. This co-ordinated effort represents a welcome change from the fragmentation of State oriented campaigns.

Furthermore, our egg producers have begun to look at developing export markets. In September last year the industry was successful in negotiating a $15m contract to supply egg products to Japan. The contract for 8,000 tonnes of separated products from 8 million dozen eggs was won over competition from subsidised products from the European Economic Community and the United States of America. The contract was something of a landmark in export sales, because it represented a profitable return rather than simply the disposal of a surplus from the domestic market. The Opposition strongly supports research, which increases the competitiveness of rural industry. For instance, technological advance has led to greater automation in the feeding, water supply, temperature and lighting of poultry sheds. I reiterate the Liberal Party's support for the Bill and wish it a speedy passage.

I turn now to the Wool Marketing Bill 1987 and the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1987. The Wool Marketing Bill 1987, which replaces the Wool Industry Act of 1972, will place less reliance on government involvement in the industry in favour of joint responsibility and co-operation on major issues between the Wool Council of Australia and the Australian Wool Corporation. This Bill is being introduced in conjunction with the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills and under the new arrangement the Wool Council will decide on each component of the wool tax after consultation with the Australian Wool Corporation. Under clause 46 the total tax levy will be set by the Wool Council.

The short to medium term outlook for the wool industry is very promising, with export sales rising to record levels in the current financial year. Wool sales for 1986-87 are expected to be up 25 per cent in volume on last year. More importantly, the value of those sales is forecast to be up 40 per cent on last financial year. Indicative of this buoyancy was the price activity in early April this year when the market price indicator rose by 51c to 752c a clean kilo-the highest price since the reserve price scheme began in the 1970s. This price was 42 per cent above the 1985-86 indicator and 48 per cent above the reserve.

In just four years Australia's sheep numbers have increased to their second highest level ever, from 133 million to 155 million, and the price of greasy wool has risen from 187c a kilo to 450c a kilo. Preliminary estimates indicate that total shorn wool in Australia in 1986-87 will be 808,400 tonnes, an increase of 6.3 per cent on 1985-86. This represents the most wool shorn since 1969-70. Fortunately, this increased production has been more than satisfied by increased demand on world markets.

As the Australian wool industry is predominantly an export oriented industry, increased international demand has been a critical factor in improved profitability. A number of factors have contributed to this increased demand. This year has seen a buying spree by China, which increased its purchase of Australian wool by 61 per cent to 42 million kilograms, worth $184m. China has now overtaken Italy and France to become Australia's third largest wool buyer. In addition, Australia's two largest customers, Japan and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, bought larger parcels of our wool, with increases of 25 per cent and 19 per cent respectively.

The overseas promotion of wool is conducted by the International Wool Secretariat, a marketing association which is sponsored by the five main wool producing countries in the southern hemisphere. Australia is the major contributor to the IWS, providing approximately 65 per cent of its budget. Although, as I have mentioned earlier, the devaluation has been significant in increasing our sales and competitiveness on world markets, it has also resulted in Australia's contribution to the IWS increasing from $65m in 1982-83 to perhaps $130m this year. However, the devaluation benefit has fallen far short of the sort of increase that was forecast by Mr Keating a couple of years ago.

One of the most contentious issues facing the wool industry is the question of the export of merino rams, semen, ewes and embryos. Until now the export of merino rams has been limited to 300 per annum, supplemented by the sale of rams which have an auction price of less than $1,000. Under this program, 1,678 merinos have been exported since 1979, bringing in an annual income of about $1m. The change made last week introduces a maximum of 900 rams by the 1991-92 selling season. The export of merino semen will be allowed but the embargo on the export of merino ewes, embryos and ova will continue. This recommendation has been made in spite of the fact that all the constituent bodies of the Australian Wool Council, except the United Farmers and Stockowners Association, have expressed opposition to any liberalisation of the current quota and have argued for a total ban. According to some sections of the industry, with the use of artificial insemination just 300 Australian rams could get almost one million overseas ewes in lamb in one year.

Concern about merino exports has heightened since the entry of Spain into the European Economic Community. This concern has risen because of Spain's potential to substantially increase and improve its merino stocks. As such it could represent a significant threat to our access to the European market, which currently buys one quarter of our total wool clip. Howard Moxham, wool spokesman for the NSW Livestock and Grain Producers Association, has summed up this view. He said:
Australia is the premier supplier of high quality apparel wool, a position achieved through 200 years of research and development.
If we are to maintain that position it is imperative that the unique genetic superiority now, be retained on Australian shores.
Industry technology is highly protected by worldwide patents. We are trying to protect our wool as an industrial patent.

To me this seems an eminently reasonable position. If we are to defend our markets we must adopt a more hard-nosed approach to our overseas trade. I understand the view that a greater proliferation of merinos would have a beneficial effect on wool consumption, but this could happen anyway with spirited marketing campaigns from our own country in conjunction with the IWS. Perhaps for too long we have been too complacent, too benevolent even, in distributing freely the fruits of our technological research without adequate compensation.

The manufacturing and processing sections of the industry-and I choose to regard the industry as being a total industry which includes production, processing and manufacturing-have expressed concern that, in spite of the very significant parts they play, they have not been afforded adequate consultation or adequate consideration in the new legislation. The information I have is that on 30 October last representatives of the manufacturing sector were advised that the draft Bill had been prepared, and received a two-hour briefing. They were told there would be further consideration as the matter proceeded, but no more detail ever came forward and no further consultations on the issues raised were offered. I was informed that it was in fact the Minister who advised that he would refer back. In March, when it was generally known that the Bill was coming, the matter was raised by the processing sector but its request was declined. The decision of whether the Corporation would be working with or against the processing and manufacturing sector causes concern and I ask the Minister to give some assurances today.
Under section 39a of the previous Act the functions of the Corporation include:

. . . to such extent as the Minister approves, trading in wool and wool products, acquiring and supplying wool for the purposes of programs of aid by Australia to other countries, and manufacturing, or arranging for the manufacture, of wool products.

There is now no need or provision for the Minister to be asked or to give the opportunity to consider such moves as would bear on all sectors of the wool industry. No explanation is given in the new section 11 of the need for the Corporation to form subsidiary companies or whether they would be able to work with existing businesses or to work in opposition to them.

The New Zealand experience has been closely followed and there is certainly nothing about it that the Australian processors have seen that attracts them to that sort of operation. I am a solid supporter of all parts of the industry and I recognise the position each plays. Co-operation and working together is essential if we are to consider what is best for Australia-as well as the industry as a whole or in sections. Could or would the Wool Corporation stocks be used, for instance, for the Corporation's own operations or joint ventures without allowing those stocks to go back through the existing system and through the open market? Clearly, there should be greater collaboration between the various sectors. Australia must look at every way to add value to our major products usually sold in bulk. The wool industry is one of our key export industries and debate on this fundamental issue must be vigorous and well considered. In conclusion, on behalf of the Opposition, I support the Wool Marketing Bill. As I have indicated previously, I shall be moving amendments in the Committee stages to certain provisions relating to employment opportunity consistent with the Opposition's views in this matter. In general terms, though, the Opposition will be supporting the Bill and I wish it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate on an interesting collection of Bills, I shall be addressing my remarks to three categories of Bills, the two egg industry research Bills, the two wool Bills, the Wool Marketing Bill and the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills, and the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill. This parcel of Bills comprises an unusual collection, and is a challenge to someone who is charged with almost all the portfolio responsibilities in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin by making some comments on the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Bill and the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Collection Bill. The purpose of this legislation is to institute a new method of collecting the hen research levy, given that the current method of applying the levy is due to expire on 30 June this year. The previous legislation also included a levy for equalising losses among producers from the disposal of surplus eggs. Following industry rationalisation, this equalisation is being phased out. The research levy is set at a maximum of 10c per hen per annum but it is expected that the Australian Council of Egg Producers will set an initial levy of between 3c and 4c.

I commend the egg producers and the State governments which have been able to reduce surplus egg production by a progressive reduction of hen quotas which limit the number of hens an egg producer is licensed to keep. It demonstrates, as did the actions of the prawn fishing industry, that Australia's rural producers will respond to calls for rationalisation by a process of negotiation, and that the stick which this Government is inclined to use should be complimented by the carrot approach. It is anticipated that the levy will raise $250,000 from egg producers, and that a dollar for dollar matching grant from the Commonwealth will make $500,000 per annum available for research. If the representative body of primary producers, the National Farmers Federation, were interested in using its often-touted multi-million dollar fighting fund to help rural producers rather than satisfying the political ambitions of its leaders, the egg producers might indeed have more money to spend on research, or maybe there would not be need for a levy at all.

Whatever we believe might be the best solution to Australia's economic problems, all of us in this chamber can agree that a large part of that economic problem is the decline in Australia's exports relative to imports. In 1982-83 and in 1983-84 some 10 per cent of Australia's egg production was exported. In 1984-85 this proportion dropped to less than 4 per cent and in 1986-87 it is estimated to be 4.9 per cent. I understand that a single egg producer does not have the money or the time to investigate export opportunities in the Asian region, especially in Japan. If the NFF used its money and expertise to explore and establish these markets rather than playing politics with the money it has, it would be performing a real service to egg producers and helping to open up export markets to the Australian economy where every export counts. The Australian egg industry produces 178 million dozen eggs with a value of $200m. The manual produced by the Australian Egg Marketing Council tells us:

Growth and profitability in the egg industry is therefore inextricably linked to increases in consumption outside of the transitional shell egg area, that is, the exploitation of opportunities for egg usage in manufactured product form is either the primary component-for example, liquid whole egg, frozen yolk, liquid albumen-or a contributing component, for example, pavlova mixes and crepes.

The NFF could be helping to provide the research and establishing contacts which will open up the opportunity of more Australian exports in the liquid whole egg and frozen yolk form instead of engaging in political point scoring.

I am also pleased to see that the Australian Egg Marketing Council has encouraged product development beyond the normal shell egg areas, particularly in the area of free range eggs. I again quote from the Egg Council's manual which states:

Free-range eggs can command a premium over `standard' eggs, which appeal to that segment of consumers believing that free range eggs are nutritionally, visually and taste-superior. Free-range eggs are already marketed by most of the State Egg Boards and indications are that sales are largely incremental.

I believe that there should be investigation of another type of shell egg which is currently not available on the market and which would also command a premium over standard eggs-that is, eggs which are free of the various chemicals and unwelcome additives which are a feature of modern egg production methods. It is clear that Australia produces a surplus of eggs. The question therefore should not be how to maximise production but how to produce the highest quality products. I remind honourable senators that people pay more for a Mercedes car because of the quality they believe they are buying. Australian and foreign consumers who are concerned about what they are eating offer a potential market for the egg producers of Australia. These two Bills in their various aspects are supported by the Australian Democrats as an indication of the way in which an industry can co-operate in its own rationalisation and development.

I turn to the Wool Marketing Bill 1987 and the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills. After some years of decline it is pleasing to note that the Australian wool industry is becoming Australia's leading rural export industry, a factor noted only this morning in the Press in relation to the latest Bureau of Agricultural Economics report. In these times concepts such as terms of trade, balance of payments and balance of trade are increasingly part of the jargon that is used to explain our current economic problems. This highlights the fact that our problems are primarily trading, that we are exporting too little and importing too much, and that the increasing value of our exports, be they from primary resources or the manufacturing sector, is a major part of solving our economic problems. In that context the wool industry is one that has weathered the recent downturn in the world demand for commodities. This year it is likely to contribute almost $4 billion of exports to our balance of payments.

The Wool Corporation has done a magnificent job. Those who were ideologically blinded by the impulse to privatise and deregulate everything must realise that the Wool Corporation is a prime example of the way government regulation, combined with co-operation from the private industry participants, can be used to iron out fluctuations in world prices, monitor market trends, promote exports and improve the quality of the product. This particular legislation introduces reforms which will increase the indepen- dence and operational flexibility of the Corporation. The changes to financing provisions will enable the Wool Council to determine the apportionment of wool tax to the market support fund, to wool promotion and to the wool research and development fund. The Corporation will be able to borrow up to 50 per cent of the level of its net assets and to appoint commercial auditors. There will be reforms to provide additional powers for the Corporation to achieve greater quality assurance of wool, which has been a major factor in the success of the Australian wool industry. Generally these reforms have been welcomed by the industry and by all political parties.

Although our wool industry is doing well at the moment there are problems emerging which will require a corporation that can deal with the modern complex marketing environment for wool. Firstly, wool accounts for only approximately 5 per cent of overall textile use in the world. In those areas where the wool market is relatively strong-menswear, women's wear and knitwear-its share is still declining. Secondly, there are growing numbers of sheep in Australia. This is probably due to an increase in resources away from other farming activity such as cropping. Additional numbers of sheep can result in either increased sales or lower prices. The market solution so often admired by the New Right and its political allies, the Queensland trojan horse Joh Nationals, the Sinclair Nationals or Liberal dries, would simply encourage more wool production to the point where wool prices would have to fall.

I am sure that the Nationals of whatever faction will happily forget about the virtues of the pure market system when it comes to the wool industry. There was plenty of evidence of that in the past. I do not blame them for that. It simply means, despite the rhetoric, that they know that regulation of markets can produce superior outcomes in primary industries. They just want everybody else to be subject to market forces, especially the 2 1/2 million Australians-including 800,000 children-who live in poverty. The Nationals want them to be left in poverty because there is no market solution to poverty other than to ignore it. People such as the Joh Nationals and the Liberals who want to deregulate labour markets welcome the pool of desperately poor unemployed because they will provide the cheap slave labour their white shoe friends are clamouring for.

There has been enormous prevarication from Opposition parties on one aspect of this legislation. It was very interesting when these Bills were in the other place so shortly after the equal employment opportunity legislation had been opposed by the Liberal Party-and that Party again had failed when it was prepared to ditch its traditional principles of equality to try to woo the National Party and retain the coalition. It was necessary, and welcome I must say, for the Liberal Party to go back to its principles of equality and support the equal opportunity provisions of the Wool Marketing Bill. It was a clear demonstration that when politically suitable at least the current forces at work within the Liberal Party were prepared to ditch those principles for political opportunistic reasons.

There has never been a great deal of support from the National Party for equal opportunity provisions. We very strongly support those provisions in this legislation. Explicit legislative provisions have excluded women in particular from equal participation for decades in the paid work force. Examples of specific discriminatory laws are bountiful-the harvester family wage decision goes back as far as that-and include the requirements of married women to forfeit promotions, superannuation and other advantages of permanent employment. The Married Women's Act and the Matrimonial Causes Act belatedly reversed pre-existing legally-imposed discrimination. Women's access to education, trades and professions and income security has always been held back and is still hampered by laws designed to exclude them and protect privileges for men, based on a range of absurd prejudices and fragile male egos.

The equal opportunity provisions in this Bill move against those past practices and policies which really were social engineering. It is not enough that we simply wait for time to take its course. Our labour force statistics of occupational, industrial and hierarchical segregation and average weekly earnings of the paid work force on the basis of gender say it all. We believe we have equal opportunity and equal pay, yet women are still excluded from many areas of the paid work force and are clustered in low income and low status areas. Indeed, on average, they earn only about 65 per cent of average male earnings. The advantages of equal employment opportunity are economic. It does not seem enough to most members of this Parliament that they are soundly founded on principles of social justice.

It is interesting to note that within the primary industry corporations, which of course were excluded from the central EEO legislation, the record of female participation is not good. We certainly welcome the implementation of those equal opportunity aspects in this legislation. It is time that the contribution of women in rural life and rural industries as a whole was brought into recognition and into the 1980s. One of the most encouraging things I have seen for a long time was an article in the National Times on Sunday last weekend which demonstrated how successful the Australian wool industry is and has been during what really has been a rural crisis.

That was a significant article pointing to many specific aspects in which the Australian Wool Corporation has been successful. I have already referred to some matters. The very encouraging thing about this article was that it quite unremarkably related in particular to one property which is run by a woman whose husband had been deceased for 15 years. She continued to run the property because she wished to pass it on to her children-and both her children are female. The article makes no great moment of that but I congratulate the National Times on Sunday for choosing for a feature article a primary producer who is a woman and for not making an absolute fuss about it, but simply making the point that the property was a normal property. It clearly underlines the contribution of women in rural life and rural industries. We very strongly support these aspects of this legislation. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: MUTUAL ASSISTANCE IN CRIMINAL MATTERS BILL 1987MUTUAL ASSISTANCE IN CRIMINAL MATTERS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1987PROCEEDS OF CRIME BILL 1987PROCEEDS OF CRIME (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1987TELECOMMUNICATIONS (INTERCEPTION) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: TELECOMMUNICATIONS (INTERCEPTION) AMENDMENT BILL 1987
Consideration resumed.
Clauses 6 and 7-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 8 (Insertion of new sections).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 12, clause 8, proposed subsection 6d (1), proposed definition of ``Judge'', lines 18 and 19, leave out ``a court created by the Parliament'', insert ``the Federal Court of Australia''.

The amendment is aimed at making certain that only a limited number of judges have the power to issue the warrants to allow telephone interceptions. The Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception was very concerned about the proliferation of judges allowed to issue these warrants. We believe it should have been restricted to judges of the Federal Court of Australia so we would have some general definition. The Government proposes that any person who is a judge of a court created by the Parliament and who consents and is declared by the Attorney-General to be able to issue warrants should be included. This leaves the whole matter open. I would much prefer to follow the very well argued and properly set out recommendation of the Telecommunications Interception Committee. This is yet another amendment to have the Bill coincide with the recommendations of that Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The basic problem with confining the power to judges of the Federal Court is that in Tasmania and the Northern Territory there are no judges of the Federal Court there located. However, there are other courts which satisfy the description in the legislation as it now stands. For that very practical reason we believe that the Bill ought to stand as it is.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 9 to 20-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 21 (Addition of new Parts).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 34, clause 21, proposed section 64, leave out the proposed section.
(4) Page 37, clause 21, proposed section 74, leave out `64 or'.

We regard amendment No. 3, which is one of a series of amendments, as inextricably linked with the other amendment in relation to the deletion of proposed section 64, amendment No. 4. As I understand it, the amendment is now going to be opposed by the Australian Democrats, whereas they intend to support the other amendment to leave out proposed section 64, amendment No. 4, which states `leave out ``64 or'' ' in clause 21. I will deal with the arguments in favour of the deletion of proposed section 64 and leave it to the Democrats to explain why, at the eleventh hour, they have once again changed their minds.

Proposed section 64 has the effect of making admissible, despite illegality, evidence which has been obtained in proceedings already underfoot. In 1985, by a majority of 3:2, the High Court held that the obtainment of information illegally did not involve an implied prohibition on the tender in evidence of that material. Accordingly, in those circumstances the material would be admissible even though illegally obtained. Our concern is that that case, decided by a majority only and by a limited number of judges, is now in effect on appeal. A series of cases is pending before the High Court, the most urgent of which is a matter of the Commonwealth and others v. Jones. As I understand it, that case is likely to come on in a matter of days.

This Bill, by including a statutory provision, seeks to pre-empt the finding of the High Court to render it redundant. In fact, the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor has already written to solicitors acting for appellants in proceedings before the Court on the basis that this pre-emptive strike will render those hearings unnecessary. The aim, therefore, of proposed section 64 is to take away the prospects of acquittal which certain citizens would have had under the law as it stood at the time they engaged in the conduct--

TALK.START.PARA: —Totally unmeritorious acquittal.

—I suppose that every dog is allowed to have his day in court. Whether or not the appellants succeed in the ultimate, we take the view that it is an intolerable denial of justice to say to someone: `You have an appeal underfoot but we are going to take away the very basis of it'. That is retrospective, in our view. It has precisely the same taint and odour of retrospective legislation which would make something that was not criminal at the time of the commission of the act an offence after the event. We say that this provision is tantamount to doing that. Under proposed section 64 persons who might otherwise have been able to secure acquittals will be deprived by statute. In those circumstances we say that it is quite unfair and wrong to persist with such a provision. It is premature at the very least and certainly highly undesirable in terms of the administration of justice.

SPEECH.PARA: We therefore take the view that the High Court should be left to decide the proper interpretation of the Act. It will, in all probability, be constituted by a full complement of seven judges. We would much prefer that the Court itself made a determination on the existing provisions of the Act rather than the Government, for whatever purpose, serving up a pre-emptive strike of the nature I have described. We are cognisant of the fact that the Law Society of New South Wales, the President of the Bar Association of New South Wales and the Law Council of Australia have all been trenchant in their criticism of this provision. I would have thought that it would have eminently appealed to a jurist of the calibre of Senator Evans. In reversed circumstances, it would be hard to contain him in under half an hour in pointing out the vices of such a course. We do not see any justification whatsoever for opposition to amendments of this nature. We do not see the need for such precipitate action. If the High Court is about to embark upon hearings of these matters we are talking about only a matter of weeks at most. In those circumstances the provision is indefensible in our view.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me endeavour to explain the Government's position. The Government's general policy approach is that illegally obtained telephone intercept evidence should not be admissible. Subsequent provisions of this legislation that we will be debating shortly incorporate that principle unequivocally so far as the future is concerned. So let there be no misunderstanding of our commitment to that view: If evidence is illegally obtained, it ought not to be admissible. We will be arguing with Senator Alston and fighting our way through his crocodile tears again in a moment when we come to that section of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The particular concern we have which proposed section 64 deals with is rather different.
