It concerns the prospect that there may have been a very technical defect in a large number of warrants that have been issued under this legislation in the past; that the High Court might, within the next few days, hold that there has been such a technical defect; that the result of that may lead, in turn-unless the effect of that is countered by this legislation-to a number of people now in jail on serious narcotics offences, convicted as a result of such warrant evidence, ultimately securing their release in a rather unmeritorious way; and, moreover, that particular proceedings now pending in relation to warrants issued in the past may be equally overturned as a result of this technical defect.

The particular technical defect I am referring to-and I will not take half an hour to describe it-is as follows: There is a case called Hilton v. Wells. It was held by a very narrow majority recently in the High Court that Federal Court judges could issue warrants. Although warrants are not the sorts of things that can normally be issued by judges in their capacity as judges, because the issuing of a warrant is an administrative act, nonetheless under the legislation as it stands the view was taken that Federal Court judges who were being given this responsibility were so-called persona designata, which means that they were not acting in their capacity as judges under the legislation when they issued the warrant but rather as individual people who just happened also to wear another hat as a judge. That was the decision in Hilton v. Wells and that preserved the validity of warrants issued under the parent legislation.

However, there was a fiercely contested case. One of the judges in the three-two minority in that case is now the Chief Justice, and he has been involved, perfectly understandably-it is the prerogative of the Chief Justice, I suppose-in seeking a rearguing of that case. The case will be reargued and it is perfectly possible that it will go the other way, producing a situation whereby, on the legislation as it has been drafted in the past, the people issuing the warrants, who happened to wear the hat of Federal Court judges, were not properly able to issue those warrants. It may well be held that the legislation should have been expressed in a different way to make it clear that, in issuing those warrants, they were not acting in their judicial capacity. It is perfectly possible, on the strict questions of law involved, that that case, when it is reargued in the next few days, will go the other way. We are not talking about evidence that was obtained illegally in the sense that there was no warrant at all, or in the sense that there was some grossly excessive abuse of the formal legal authority vested in the officers concerned. Rather, we are talking about warrants that may prove to have been illegally obtained because they were issued by individuals who were not identified at the time by precisely the right bit of statutory incantation. That is the most technical argument possible that will be called in aid.

The result of the forthcoming High Court case being decided in that way will not be to release automatically from gaol all those people who have been convicted on that sort of evidence. The result will be to give them the capacity to seek a rehearing in relation to that part of their trial which concerned the admissibility of such evidence in order that another court can determine, in the exercise of the traditional discretion that has been available as a matter of common law to admit illegally obtained evidence, whether in all the circumstances of their particular case it ought to have been admitted anyway. I acknowledge that it is not to be assumed that all the 30 or so people in gaol at the moment, having been convicted of these offences, will be released instantly as a result of the case going that way, but certainly it is the case that their convictions will be put very much at risk for the most technical reason possible.

As a matter of good public policy the Federal Government does not believe that that is a good thing. As a result of the legislation being drafted in the way it is in proposed section 64, we believe that that possibility will not arise on the interpretation or construction of that legislation. Proposed section 64 (1) states `. . . a proceeding begun before the commencement of this Part . . .' Because this clause preserves the legality against the background of later clauses which will make it impossible in the future for any evidence obtained illegally to be introduced, and because later clauses do that, proposed section 64 preserves the admissibility of evidence that has been obtained unlawfully in the past in preserving the traditional application of common law rules. That is the way in which it is couched. It was inserted for a different transitional purpose, but we believe that it will have the effect of preserving the validity of those previous convictions in relation to warrants that may prove to have suffered this technical defect.

We support the retention of proposed section 64 because it will avoid quite unmeritorious, as we see it, claims being made subsequently in relation to people already convicted and in relation to proceedings presently at foot. I know all the anxieties that this chamber traditionally has had about the retrospective application of clauses and all the anxieties that people have about enabling defendants to take full advantage of every kind of protection that the law affords them. I acknowledge Senator Alston's jibe about the fact that normally I might be thought individually to be wearing a different hat when these sorts of issues arise, but I have tried to explain, as simply as I can, in what I am afraid is a very technical matter, why there is a potentially serious policy problem at foot, why proposed section 64 does the job of avoiding unmeritorious consequences flowing from that, and why, as a result, it ought to be supported.

Whether that is enough to persuade Senator Macklin, who has not listened to a word I have said for the last ten minutes, remains to be seen, but at least for the record I hope that it will become clear that this Government is behaving not in any unprincipled way, but in a way that is thoroughly defensible and ought to be supported. Perhaps we can get there by Senator Alston withdrawing his amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond to that invitation by saying that, as Senator Gareth Evans chooses to put his case on the ground of high policy, and moral rectitude no doubt, the consequences of supporting our amendment bear examination. One could well understand it if we were faced with the almost inevitable prospect of a mass outbreak of high powered infringements, but that, on Senator Evans's own concession, is not likely to be the case. I would have thought that the High Court of Australia itself would be seized of those possibilities and that it would, directly or otherwise, take them into account in deciding whether or not to overturn the earlier interpretation in Hilton v Wells. Senator Evans concedes that, even if the High Court upholds those appeals, nonetheless the matter then would revert to the common law situation where a discretion would be able to be exercised. If the Committee accepts the description of the technical defects in the issue of the warrants that might then be the subject of scrutiny by a judge, I would have thought that we would have a fair degree of confidence that a judge would be very slow to accede to a request that would have the consequences that Senator Evans purports to fear if this amendment is carried. It seems to me that that is a classic case of the end justifying the means.

SPEECH.PARA: We should be concerned about the fact that the judge is entrusted with the ultimate decision making, the ultimate discretionary power and the ultimate justice of the matter. I do not fear that the High Court will get it wrong any more than I would fear that a lower court judge would improperly exercise a discretion. If the only basis for not exercising the discretion favourably to the Crown was some defect as technical as that, I was never very successful in my career at the criminal bar, which covered some murder matters, in persuading judges that they should take that narrow view. I think that we should show our confidence in the judiciary, rather than telling them, in effect, that every time we think one body of judges might have got it wrong we will make very sure that their successors, or that even those who constituted the earlier court, do not get a second chance to put it right. Having appointed the Chief Justice, as the Government has done, I would have thought that it would then be sufficiently confident in his judgment to be alive to the consequences to which Senator Evans has adverted and to do what justice requires.

But, even if the High Court were to overturn the decision, all is not lost. Again, it seems to come down to whether one has sufficient confidence in the judiciary or whether, if, for instance, section 64 is subsequently proven to contain defects-or section 76, for that matter, which seems to spell out that future irregularities should be disregarded-the Government, if it is still the Government, would still want to step in and patch up the matter. It is an undesirable policy approach to take. If we are talking in terms of what is in the public interest, I think it is highly undesirable to try to take away from the courts those sorts of discretions and judgments which they are much more capable of exercising than is any senator in this chamber.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move amendments Nos (2) and (5) to (7):

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 33, clause 21, proposed section 63, leave out ``; or (b) give in evidence in a proceeding;''.
(5) Pages 37 and 38, clause 21, proposed subsection 75 (2), leave out the proposed subsection.
(6) Page 38, clause 21, proposed section 76, leave out the proposed section.
(7) Pages 38 and 39, clause 21, proposed section 78, leave out the proposed section.

Our principal concerns are that the Bill proposes to remove the common law discretionary powers to exclude evidence obtained illegally, to render such evidence inadmissible and to prescribe a statutory regime. Again, we have sufficient confidence in the common law to take the view that that is undesirable and that there should be a discretion. The statutory provisions are simply unnecessary if that general common law approach is retained. In those circumstances, we say that each of the amendments is justified in retaining that position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a straight out and simple policy disagreement between the Government and the Opposition. While the Government has normally, I suppose, been prepared to accept the applicability of the common law rule that evidence illegally obtained is admissible, nonetheless subject to judicial discretion, we have taken the view that in this particular context of illegally obtained telephonic interception evidence, the onus really ought to run all the other way and that the statutory provisions should make it clear, as the provisions in the clause do, that such evidence, if illegally obtained, is simply inadmissible-full stop.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two minor exceptions. The first applies where there is a purely technical defect, an insubstantial error in the actual process involved in securing the issue of the warrant. Provision is made for that. The evidence may nonetheless still be admitted under those circumstances. The other circumstance where such evidence is admissible is for the very limited purpose of proving that the substantive offence of illegally obtaining evidence has itself been committed. That apart, this Government has adopted a very clear policy approach that the intrusiveness of the telephone interception warrant is such that it is so important that the very precise legislative ground rules we have now set down as to the circumstances in which such warrants can be issued be observed and we believe that the language of the admissibility rules should be as it is set out in the Bill. We hope that that view will commend itself to a majority of honourable senators in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should have gone into slightly more detail in terms of the common law distinction, but it seems to me that what Senator Evans is doing is a hangover from the desperate, steadfast approach that he took in resisting the Age tapes inquiry. What the common law has always said is that if the prejudicial effect outweighs the probative value there could well be circumstances in which discretion should be exercised adversely, but hard and fast rules that ignore the magnitude of the wrong or the strength of the right seem to us to be arbitrary and unnecessary and, in many instances, unfair perhaps to one or other of the parties. That is not an approach that commends itself to us. I would have thought until now that Senator Evans would have been in favour of equity, justice, fairness and the balance that inevitably must be exercised in considering the use of discretion by a judge. To arbitrarily tie a judge's hands by statutory prescription seems to us to be inviting the very sorts of technical and arbitrary decisions that Senator Evans would otherwise deplore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to unduly prolong this debate, but Senator Alston is showing his common lawyer's slip. It may well be perfectly true that common law is equipped to deal with situations where the prejudicial effect outweighs the probative value of the evidence in question, and I do not dispute that, but what I do assert, I believe with a fair amount of accuracy, is that the common law has never had the slightest respect for the value of privacy. There is a long tradition that demonstrates just that. As a result, the common law exercise of the discretion that is here available is simply not apt to enable the courts to grapple with, in the absence of the kind of provisions that we are discussing, the issues of principle which are involved and to which I previously referred. I suspect that this is something on which Senator Alston does not feel desperate passion, being a person with a reasonable civil libertarian record, despite his political affiliations. I will not pursue the case further. Senator Alston has a brief and I have a brief, and perhaps the difference between us is that I believe my brief.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I point out a difference between this legislation and the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee. I seek leave to move amendments (4) to (9) together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Vigor moves his amendments, I draw his attention to the fact that the debate ends in four minutes.
—I will not be very long. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Pages 26 and 27, clause 21, proposed section 46, line 37 (page 26) to line 31 (page 27), leave out the proposed section.
Page 27, clause 21, proposed section 47, line 33, leave out ``or 46''.
Page 28, clause 21, proposed paragraph 48 (3) (c), line 14, leave out ``or 46''.
Page 29, clause 21, proposed subsection 49 (7), lines 16 and 17, leave out ``or 46 (1) (d), as the case may be''.
Page 35, clause 21, proposed subsection 67 (1), line 2, leave out ``A'', insert ``Subject to subsection (3), a''.
Page 35, clause 21, after proposed subsection 67 (2), insert the following new subsection:
`` `(3) A person who has intercepted a communication under a warrant issued to an agency shall not communicate to an officer of the agency information obtained by the interception other than:
(a) the information in order to obtain which the warrant was sought; or
(b) information relating to an offence punishable by imprisonment for life or for a period, or maximum period, of at least 3 years.''.

This is a very simple proposal. Basically, the Government wants all information obtained from an interception to be provided to the agency that obtained the warrant, and there will be stringent controls on the use of the information at that point. We are very keen to make certain that communication of any legally intercepted information other than that requested by the warrant should be prohibited; unless it relates to an offence that is punishable by imprisonment by three years or longer there should be no exception to this provision.

The whole idea is that it would be possible under this scheme for an agency to ask for an interception and say that it wanted to find out about SP bookmaking, which was the example referred to-not that I approve of that at all. That might be the sole area in which it was interested. The agency might convince someone that this area is associated with organised crime, obtain a warrant and perhaps prosecute people for a number of minor offences-offences that are even more minor than the SP bookmaking arrangements. I know that stringent controls are provided, but telecommunications interception could be used for obtaining information that is for intelligence rather than for prosecution purposes. I believe that it could be very intrusive if there were not very stringent requirements on how and what information can be used. That is why I have moved these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes these amendments. There are reasonable grounds for that opposition that I do not have time to articulate. There are stringent controls on the way in which information that is intercepted can be used. We believe there is an appropriate balance of protection and practical feasibility in the way in which the clauses are drafted at present, and we urge that the clause be accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Clause 21, as amended, agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: EGG INDUSTRY RESEARCH (HEN QUOTA) LEVY BILL 1987EGG INDUSTRY RESEARCH (HEN QUOTA) LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuing my remarks and before referring to the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, I would like to place on the record that the Australian Democrats will not support the amendments proposed to the Wool Marketing Bill 1987 by both the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia. The National Party amendments are predictable, as I said earlier, and are concerned in large measure with the equal opportunity provisions of this legislation. The Australian Democrats have been assured by the industry and by representatives of the Australian Wool Corporation that they are satisfied with the equal opportunity provisions in this legislation. Indeed, they have expressed concern that this legislation should not be held up by any actions that they expected would be taken by the Nationals and the Liberals.

—I raise a point of order about the statement that the industry was happy with the Bill. It was not happy with those sections. It asked for those sections not to be amended so that the Bill would go through.
—Senator Walters, resume your seat. There is no point of order.

—Indeed, it is interesting to see before us today a series of amendments. As I said, the National Party amendments are predictable, but the amendments of the Liberal Party appear to be part of that continuing courting process. The original opposition to the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Bill having failed in the House of Representatives and the coalition having disintegrated, the political situation being somewhat different today, it appears that we now have a series of amendments which are perhaps designed in some way to get that coalition back together again as we gallop off to our early election. Indeed, the Liberal Party is prepared to water down equal opportunity provisions in this Bill, as it has on past occasions, and use justice for women as a bargaining tool for politically opportunistic reasons.
—Point of order.
—What is your point of order, Senator Walters?
—My point of order is that the honourable senator is not speaking the truth. We are indeed abiding by the normal procedure that we have undertaken.
—Senator Walters, when the Chair stands you should resume your seat immediately. You have been here long enough to know that that is not a point of order.

—This fact will not be lost on the women of Australia, I am sure. It is a matter of concern to the Australian Democrats that there are still a number of primary industry corporations-the Meat and Livestock Corporation, the Dairy Corporation and the Australian Wheat Board-for which we still await this kind of equal employment opportunity legislation, and we will welcome it when it comes before us.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill which will amend the National Health Act 1953 and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974 to introduce new financial arrangements for nursing homes for the aged to commence on 1 July 1987 and provide a mechanism for establishing the standards of nursing home care to be provided in nursing homes approved under the National Health Act 1953. It is clear that Australian society is confronting a massive problem in coming to terms with providing care for elderly Australians. We are an aging or greying society, and we can see that when we note that the proportion of persons under 15 years of age has fallen from 35 per cent in 1901 to 23 per cent in 1986 and it is projected to decline to 19 per cent by the year 2021. If we look at the projected growth of various age groups in the Australian population from 1986 to 2021, we discover that the general population will grow by about 6.5 per cent in the next five years whereas the population over the age 74 will grow by 22.2 per cent, that of age 80 and over by 25.3 per cent, and that of age 85 and over by 21.2 per cent. This remarkable growth of the older aged population in the next five years requires immediate attention from the government.

The question of cost is important for two reasons: Firstly, as an aging population we will have fewer people in the work force to provide the income and care services needed by an increasing number of aging Australians and, secondly, any large government expenditure item is likely to come under increasing scrutiny by members of the New Right who all believe that Australia's economic problems will be solved simply if the Government spends less. I do not agree with that, but the Hawke Government's May mini-Budget cuts the incomes of the poorest Australians in this tradition which seems to have been established-the unemployed, the young, students and people who rely on social security payments.

The Liberals and Nationals have claimed that they can find up to $11 billion worth of cuts. For the 1986-87 financial year the total Commonwealth expenditure on the aged is estimated to be more than $9 1/2 billion-some $8 billion in pensions and some $1 1/2 billion on nursing home, community and home care for the aged. Total Commonwealth outlays are estimated to be approximately $75 billion in 1986-87. Expenditure on the aged represents about 12 per cent of total Commonwealth outlays. As I see it, those who believe that they can find another $6 billion or $7 billion on top of the $4 billion worth of cuts already announced by the Government will have to see how they can cut money to aged Australians. I am horrified that the Government has already cut the meagre incomes of young unemployed Australians. The Australian Democrats will certainly not support cuts to the aged at a time when we obviously must put more resources into caring for the aged.

There are currently no uniform standards for the care of the elderly in Australia. Such standards are set by State governments, despite the fact that the Commonwealth provides 80 per cent of funds for services to the aged and the disabled. The nursing homes and hostels legislation which I am addressing at the moment seeks to negotiate, impose and supervise uniform standards throughout Australia in the provision of care and accommodation for the aged by seeking to change the system of Commonwealth Government funding to private nursing homes to give them incentives to contain costs, to implement over time, uniform payments to nursing homes between the States and to simplify the funding mechanism so that the Department of Community Services can use its staff to supervise the quality of outcomes rather than approve individual funds to all the homes in Australia.

The need for quality control has been illustrated by a number of reports which outline abysmal conditions in some, although not many, homes. This legislation addresses the areas of new funding arrangements for homes, assessment of needs by teams rather than by the decision of one doctor and the surveillance of the services offered by nursing homes. The aim is to introduce uniform payments and uniform standards of care between States. Although everyone, including the private nursing homes, thinks the aims are admirable, private nursing homes, particularly in Victoria, are upset about the new funding formula that the Government proposes to introduce.

From 1 July the Government will introduce in phases a new system of funding to replace the current cost reimbursement arrangements. Furthermore, the system of reimbursement funding which has been in place has allowed a wide variation per capita to be paid between States, varying from $54.60 a day in Victoria to $35.25 a day in Queensland. Naturally any attempt to have uniformity between States would be to the benefit of Queensland and to the detriment of many Victorian nursing homes. Overall we note that 65 per cent of nursing homes in Australia will be better off and 35 per cent, mostly in Victoria and South Australia, will be worse off.

Under this legislation, it is proposed that from 1 July this year all nursing home fees will be split into two components-one for all direct nursing and personal care costs and the other for infrastructure costs and return on investment. This latter composite infrastructure component is known as the standard aggregated module, or SAM, and represents about 45 per cent of the average total nursing home costs. The level of SAM is set in the Bill at $27.65 per occupied bed day for the coming financial year. This figure represents the average infrastructure cost for all participating homes in 1984-85, indexed, and the Bill provides for the Minister to gazette either a higher amount or a formula in accordance with which a higher amount will be ascertained. At this stage the standard aggregated module will be the only component in respect of which all nursing homes for the aged will begin a gradual transition to a uniform national funding level from 1 July.

Until new national uniform staffing standards are agreed to, State governments and indeed, for some time after they are introduced, current approved nursing and personal care staffing levels will continue to be reflected in fees on a cost reimbursement basis. The formula will provide that in 1988-89 and subsequent years the SAM will be indexed by a weighted average of the annual expected movements in average weekly earnings and the consumer price index. The Commonwealth of Australia Gazette notice for any alterations will be subject to parliamentary disallowance. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I undertake to monitor clearly the gazetted notices with a view to protecting people in nursing homes, especially the many nursing homes in Victoria and South Australia which will be financially disadvantaged.

If the messages that I have been getting from the private nursing homes in Victoria are right, many nursing home beds might be closed in Victoria, which already has a shortage of nursing home beds. Once the financing arrangements are standardised, the Department will have more resources to supervise the quality of outcomes-that means the quality of care and the quality of life of people in nursing homes. This is a commendable change, but I also have sympathy for the private nursing homes in Victoria which have had their funding reduced and as yet have received no guidelines on how the Department intends to monitor the quality of outcomes. Similarly, there are no guidelines for those homes which might want to take up the option, which is now to be available, of charging more and providing more expensive services.

Like all legislation being dealt with this week, the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 is being rushed through because of the Government's decision to hold an early election. This does not mean that I am unaware of the real problems of Victorian nursing homes and those whom they service and of the problems they may experience as a result of this legislation. The Australian Democrats will hold a future Labor government to the commitment made by the Minister for Community Services, Mr Hurford, in a letter written to nursing home residents in Victoria, in which he said:

Because the new arrangements are to be introduced very gradually, nursing home staff and residents should find that there is minimal disruption to their normal routine. The end of these arrangements will mean a fairer deal for all nursing home residents and for nursing home proprietors.

In relation to the fourth Bill in this package of Bills, that is, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, on which I do not intend to speak but on which Senator Macklin intends to speak if time permits, I point out that the Australian Democrats will be moving some amendments, which are based on the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills report. I foreshadow those amendments at this time. It is hoped that Senator Macklin will have an opportunity during the Committee stage to address the issues covered by those amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to speak briefly on two of the Bills in this package of Bills being considered this afternoon, namely, the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 and the Wool Marketing Bill 1987. I certainly do not intend to re-write any of the voluminous reports which over the years have led to this series of amendments being introduced to rationalise in many respects, to bring under much better scrutiny and to produce considerable equity where at present very little exists between States in the nursing home industry. It is very gratifying to find that the Government has taken up almost all of the recommendations of the most recent parliamentary report on private nursing homes and is introducing them in a way which, I believe, will cause the least possible disruption to an industry which should not be disrupted.

SPEECH.PARA: The very nature of the nursing home industry means that one is dealing with vulnerable and apparently powerless people. Whatever happens it must be explained to them, to the proprietors of the nursing homes and to the workers, who most often are the people in the firing line, as it were. These new measures to be implemented over the next few months involve a new method of funding nursing homes. This is a greatly improved series of measures which will allow for monitoring the quality of care and quality of life standards, the introduction of peer group reviews in each State, and the development of national standards. These are all matters which have been emphasised over the years in one report after the other.

I find it rather perturbing that some of the nursing home proprietors in Victoria are finding that, perhaps as a political necessity, they must make as much fuss as possible about these changes-gentle, gradual and incremental as the changes are. It is excessively regrettable that, once again, some of these proprietors have taken it upon themselves to use their patients, their residents, to try to put pressure on the Government and on the unions-without any justification. This Bill was very well explained in the second reading speech provided by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), representing the Minister for Community Services. Everything possible has been said about the Bill during the second reading debate in the House of Representatives. I can see not point at all in rehashing the details of these proposed measures. I would like, though, to emphasise that in Victoria the conventional wisdom has been that operating costs have been so much higher than those in other States and that there have been idiosyncratic reasons for this. However, an independent study by Coopers and Lybrand and W. D. Scott has indicated that there is no apparent justification for Victoria's higher infrastructure costs. I am not challenging the conventional wisdom about the higher ratio of trained nurses to patients or, in many cases, the higher percentage of patients who need more intensive nursing. But as far as this exercise is concerned, we are dealing with infrastructure costs; we are dealing with what in the Bill is referred to as the standard aggregate module which, in the first instance, will be that cost factor which will be yielding to efforts to provide that equity between States which has eluded us until now.

During the inquiry undertaken by the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, interestingly enough we received no evidence at all particularly relating to contract arrangements. These are used commonly, it appears, in Victoria for cleaning, laundry and catering and, on examination, it appears that they are exceptionally expensive-in many cases costs for these services are 50 per cent higher than for the other States. It is suggested that if the nursing homes in Victoria involved in contractual arrangements were to re-examine the nature of providing such services, together with their higher administrative costs generally-and we certainly did have evidence about those-their outlays on these infrastructure items would be virtually the same as those in other States. This provides a rather interesting view of the administration of Victorian nursing homes, particularly those that are represented, I understand, by the Private Geriatric Homes Association of Victoria. I recall from my own experience the strenuous efforts that were made in Western Australia during the 1970s and early 1980s to persuade the nursing home proprietors not to change their mode of operation of using contract cleaners and caterers, but to employ workers within the hospitals. In every case the standard of work was higher, the level of commitment of the workers was higher and the costs involved were considerably lower.

Claims have also been made that, with the introduction of the proposed arrangements, the standard of care and quality of life will fall. This is totally misrepresenting the facts. The new funding arrangements apply only to infrastructure costs, that is, food, laundry, transport, et cetera. The new grant has been set at a level which will increase total infrastructure funding for two-thirds of all nursing homes in Australia, the exceptions being, as we have been told before, chiefly in Victoria. The proprietors, I hope, will rapidly get used to the idea that they will have much greater flexibility in the way that they manage their infrastructure funds. Funding will not be cut. What will happen is that the level of increase will not be the same as it was in the past. This will be greatly to the advantage of the patients, who will no longer be continually faced with the alarm that can be caused when they have anticipated that their fees are going to be increased several times in a year.

Worst of all, claims are being made that the new arrangements will mean that some nursing home owners will incur significant financial losses and that they will be forced to close down, leaving residents with nowhere to go. I have heard that people with relatives in nursing homes are being told to take them home, as there will be no other accommodation available. Once again, in Victoria the conventional wisdom is that there is a shortage of nursing home beds in comparison with the demand that is assumed to exist.

The new arrangements will provide considerable opportunities for proprietors to manage their homes far more efficiently and profitably than they do now. The new arrangements will be phased in very slowly, as I have said, to bring about a gradual and equitable redistribution of Commonwealth funding across all nursing homes and to minimise disruption to the nursing home industry and its residents. If there is one thing that came out strongly in every report that has ever been made on nursing homes, it is the vulnerability of the patients, the fact that one is dealing with a very powerless group of people. Patients and their relatives are very easily alarmed and changes must be handled very sensitively.

I feel very proud of the fact that our Department of Community Services and our Minister for Community Services (Mr Hurford) have designed a series of changes in a sensitive fashion so as to provide the least possible alarm and disruption. It needs to be said very firmly that should any nursing home close down or turn out residents on the street, the Department will move quickly to ensure that they are accommodated elsewhere. The Minister has the power under this new legislation to take immediate action to revoke that nursing home's approval. That is the heaviest sanction which exists and proprietors who are making wild and completely irresponsible statements should take very good note of that fact. It has been very clear over the years that although there were a few cases of mismanagement and mistreatment, to the point of severity and to the point where the community would be very perturbed, the Department and State Government structures simply did not exercise the sanctions that would pull irresponsible proprietors into line.

Another point that should be made about Victoria is that Commonwealth expenditure in that State for a person aged 70 plus in the aged care area is very high. In 1985-86 Commonwealth expenditure on programs for the aged in Victoria was $334m, which represents $1,128 per person aged 70 plus, compared with $1,110 for New South Wales and $1,011 for Queensland. I should also make it quite clear that nursing home benefits in Victoria were increased in May 1987 to $54.60 a day, a significantly higher rate than applies in any other State.

It bears repeating that Australia is well equipped with institutional care for the aged compared with pretty well every other westernised society with which we normally compare ourselves. Even so, only 7 per cent of our population over 70 years of age is in any sort of institutional care. We are a fairly healthy population and I and my colleagues, I am sure, have every intention of continuing that trend. However, we must-the Government is aware of this fact-make provision for the range of care that will be appropriate for people in that age group who are in need of support in one way or another. Something like 1.6 per cent of our total Budget is currently being spent on our population over 70 years of age. I do not complain about this. I believe that a country that looks after its aged is a compassionate society and I hope that Australia comes into that category. I do believe, though, that we should be getting good value for that money and that we should be providing from that significant amount the appropriate care, the adequate care and the care that meets the social, medical and economic requirements of the said population.

Very briefly, I will comment on the equal opportunity provisions of the Wool Marketing Bill 1987. This is part of the amazing charade we have had from the Opposition over the last few weeks. First it did not approve of equal opportunity, then it did, and now it seems as though it is not quite sure again. It is worth repeating that, in all our affirmative action legislation over the last year or so, we have endeavoured to produce language which is acceptable and which will be effective. The notion of quotas is not acceptable to many people in the community and we are aware of that. It is not particularly because of that that we look towards the strenuous use of the merit principle, but it certainly has been one of the elements in our thinking. We have developed a modification of the Canadian system of affirmative action. I believe that is accepted very well wherever it is introduced whether it be into the private sector, the tertiary education sector, the Public Service or statutory authorities. The Bill before us refers to the Wool Marketing Board and other such legislation will come up for amendment, as is appropriate, over the early months of the next Hawke Government.

The Opposition's amendments leave me very puzzled indeed. From the language used it seems as though there is a case of severe regression in the Opposition to the notion of quotas. They advocate `quantitative measures or aims which may be expressed in numerical terms', referring to the quality of measures and aims, expressed as a general principle, and so on. It is high time the Opposition worked out what its position really is on affirmative action and equal opportunity. If it does not approve of these measures it should continue to say so as Opposition senators did on the Carleton-Walsh Report just a few weeks ago. If it believes in these measures it should work with us and believe that we have the intention to continue to introduce, by legislative measures, by educative measures-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point or order. The things Senator Giles is saying are quite untrue. Our Party has been completely consistent in its approach to equal opportunity, and the amendments before us today continue that line. They are consistent.
—There is no point of order.

—I think there will be ample opportunity for these amendments to be explained and I certainly hope that I am around when that happens, because they leave me very confused. The people of Australia are giving us a very strong vote of confidence because of our measures on equal opportunity. A recent poll has shown that 75 per cent of the Australian population endorses our measures to try to eradicate discrimination in the community on the grounds of sex, race, ethnicity or disability. They are saying to us: `We approve. We believe that this will work and we want you to continue along that track'. This is very comforting for those of us who have worked for a long time to introduce, against quite strenuous opposition, the measures such as those before us today. The Opposition has done itself a great deal of harm, particularly over the last few weeks, with its ambivalence, to say the least, about its attitude towards equal opportunity. We know what the Opposition does not believe in; we are not utterly sure about what it does believe in. I think that it is to the Opposition's advantage-if I might provide a little gratuitous advice-within the next few weeks to get its act together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard an incredible speech from Senator Giles. However, I will deal solely with the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 and leave some of my colleagues to answer Senator Giles. The way a government looks after its elderly and sick patients reflects the moral attitude of that government. To date we have certainly seen the way in which this Government looks after the sick. We have 100,000 people on public hospital waiting lists. They are waiting for operations not only which would alleviate their pain and suffering but also are life saving.

SPEECH.PARA: We are all aware of the Government's socialist ideology that prevents it from introducing a just health scheme. We are all well aware that at the moment the citizens whose priority it is to care for their family know that the only possible way they can do so is by taking out private health insurance. When they do this they know that they are paying twice-once through the levy which this Government forces them to pay and again through private insurance. We all know how terribly important it is for our elderly citizens to have security-security of knowing that there will be a hospital bed available when they need it. At present they are so concerned about not being able to get into public hospitals when they want to that many of them are being forced to insure privately. The Australian Bureau of Statistics health insurance survey shows that 46.05 per cent of married couples with dependent children on less than $126 per week are privately insured. They earn $126 a week, yet they struggle to take out private insurance. That is an indication of what Australian citizens think of this Government's health scheme.

Let us look at other ways in which this Government looks after its aged. Again, we all remember Mr Hawke's promises when he told us in his first policy speech that there would have to be some belt tightening. He said:
That cannot be done by taking the money out of the weekly pay packets of the pensioners.

What happened to that promise? What happened immediately after Mr Hawke made that statement? The assets test was introduced, taking the money out of the pensioners' cheques. What sort of promise was that? Later we had Mr Hawke's next election promise when he said:
Specifically we will continue to work towards the goal of raising the basic pension rate to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.

What happened to that promise? Pensions were frozen and pensioners had to do without. The increase was delayed. That was the answer to that promise. What the Government has done to the pensioners of Australia is unforgivable.

Yesterday I referred to the treatment of war widows by this Government. I also pointed out that this Government's mini-Budget had decided to phase out the B-class widows-those elderly women who, on turning 50 and who have no dependent children, will lose their pension. Indeed, if they have been receiving a pension and their dependent children become independent they can lose their pension when they are only 45 or 46. Under our Government they were entitled to a pension. This Government says `No. If you are over 50-indeed if you are 58-we will retain you and put you back in the work force'. That is what this Government says-that 58-year-old women, who have been at home looking after their children for perhaps 25 years and who have lost all their work force skills, should be retrained. When their husbands die they are no longer entitled to a pension. What a dreadful situation this Government is in. I think that the executive of the Government must have hoodwinked its back benchers because there has been no outcry about this. We have heard Senator Giles telling us today how we are not looking after the women of Australia. This Government has done more to act against the elderly women of Australia than any previous Government could ever do during any term of office. It is a disgrace.

The Government must realise that our elderly citizens do not want much-all they want is security. They must be allowed to plan their retirement and old age but this Government has created terrible problems for them. So many of our elderly have been caused untold and unnecessary worry yet these people are less able to look after themselves. Recently in my State an elderly pensioner had her pension cut back without any notification simply because the movement in the share market increased the value of her shares. Can the Minister tell me how an elderly woman can possibly cope with that sort of thing? The case was taken up by the Department and the Department apologised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, Ha!
—Senator Robertson is laughing as though that is not true. It is a completely true statement-the Department apologised and admitted that it had taken the woman's pension without notification.
—So what? They have apologised.

—Now Senator Robertson says: `So what. They have apologised'. Not all pensioners have the ability to approach their local senator or member of parliament to set the position straight. They are just terrified by it; they do not ring the Department; they do not know how to go about it; the average pensioner does not know how to approach a senator or a member of parliament, nor do they have relatives or children who can take up the matter for them. Fortunately this pensioner did. The whole matter amounts to intimidation and, indeed, is a disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: Above all else elderly citizens need security. I believe that it is something to which they are really entitled. They need to know that as they grow older they will be looked after but that when they can no longer look after themselves and have to move from their own home, accommodation will be provided and they will be able to afford it. These are very traumatic decisions for an elderly person to make and that is certainly not understood by this Government. Under the Fraser Government an emphasis was put on increasing home and community care. It is essential that governments understand that elderly people will only want to move out of their own homes as a last resort and only when it is no longer possible for them to look after themselves.

The further a government goes in supplying assistance to keep elderly citizens in their homes the happier they will be. The community can do so much-there is the meals on wheels service for example. I have served those meals and know how much elderly citizens appreciate not only the meal but also someone coming into the house because it is probably the only time they see someone in their home. They wanted to delay me and have a chat; they asked me to do little errands for them. That is very important to them. The community can do a great deal. I have been asked just to change a light globe because it was impossible for the elderly person to climb up on a ladder and change it herself. This Government could not care less; it is completely uncaring. But when an elderly person can no longer stay in his or her own home then the automatic step should not be straight into a nursing home. Alternative arrangements should be made to allow people into retirement villages, senior citizens homes or hostels should they wish. Again, under the Fraser Government, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was instrumental in putting an emphasis on building more hostels and houses for the aged. When one realises that it is not only the wish of our aged that they should stay in their own homes as long as possible or be independent in a hostel or aged home, but that the cost to the taxpayer to maintain a person in a hostel is only $80 a week as against $350 a week on average to keep such a person in a nursing home, one can understand how right the Fraser Government was to put the emphasis on expansion in this area.

Fortunately, the Government is following that lead but, true to its socialist ideology, it has gone too far. In an effort to control nursing home numbers, it has implemented in this legislation complete control over nursing, nursing homes, the total number of beds, who the patients are, what costs are involved and so on. It will regulate fully the bed numbers, even to the extent that if nursing home authorities want to abolish the home and rebuild they have to seek permission. Again, the Minister will say who will be admitted to a nursing home, how long they should stay and whether they are fit enough to be taken out of a nursing home. He will lay down what the homes will charge, or the benefit paid, for those beds. Indeed, he will lay down everything associated with the administration. All this will be done at a cost in 1988-89 of $14m. That is only half the package; the rest will come later.

This Bill applies only to domestic costs-food, laundry, cleaning and an element of profit for the home. The other half, such as the nursing costs, will come later. That matter has been put in the too hard basket and it will be dealt with later. However, again there will be full Government intervention. The Government intends to control all staffing standards in nursing homes. It wants to introduce a new quality of care and of life standard. All these things can be enforced by the Minister because he has the ultimate power by refusing to pay benefits to a home which fails to meet the standards that he sets. It is a matter of great concern that the right of appeal will not be in place by 1 July when these provisions come into force. The Opposition has decided to seek to amend this legislation, and I shall read our amendment:

The Minister shall not take action under subsection 45e (2) or (3) of the Principal Act in respect of a nursing home unless the Minister has established a Nursing Home Standards Review Panel in the State or Territory in which the nursing home is located.

So if the Minister sets certain standards that should be abided by and decides that that nursing home is not abiding by them, according to the legislation he could then cut off benefits. But the Opposition has an amendment providing that first there must be an appeal provision, a review panel that the industry can approach. I received a letter from the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and I have been told that Senator Tate will be giving assurances. I shall read the letter to honourable senators:

I am writing to you in regard to the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 which is currently before the Senate. I understand that the Opposition in the Senate proposes to move the following amendment:
I have just read that amendment to the House. The letter continues:
While I have no objection at all to the spirit of this, I am concerned that the passage of amendments will require the Bill to be returned to the House of Representatives.

Here we have the same old situation. Bills are being rushed through this place and Ministers in the other place are saying to the Senate: `We understand that we are doing something wrong. The Bill needs amending, but we do not want to keep the House of Representatives here. We are rushing this legislation through, we definitely want it, we do not want it held up. So I shall give a personal assurance that we will implement the Opposition's amendment in the Budget session'. It is the same old problem year after year while this Government is in office. The Minister continues in his letter:

This raises the possibility that passage could be delayed to the Budget sittings, which would seriously delay and disrupt the introduction of major program changes which have been recommended by parliamentary committees. The changes are strongly supported by most sections of the nursing home industry and by the major consumer bodies representing the aged.
I shall talk about that later. The Minister gives the following assurance:

I am willing to give an undertaking that the new powers will not be exercised in respect of a nursing home until a Review Panel has been established in the State or Territory in which the home is located. This approach would reflect the administrative realities involved in establishing Panels, but at the same time would not inhibit appropriate action being taken in the interests of residents in those States where Panels have been established.
The Minister continues:

In addition to this I will also give an undertaking to introduce further amendments to the National Health Act 1953 in the Budget Sittings to pick up the amendment that has been proposed by the Opposition. I hope that the assurances that I have given in this letter will mean that the Opposition will not proceed with the amendment at this stage.

It is the same old story. The Minister has to give assurances and bad legislation is being passed because the Government wants to get up in a hurry and hold an early election that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised he would not hold.

I do not know why I am accepting the Minister's assurance. Because the Democrats have told us that they will support us, we should make the Government act correctly, make the Government bring back the House of Representatives and make the Government delay the election an extra day, if necessary, but pass proper legislation. That is what should be done, but I have agreed to accept the Minister's assurances. I presume that later we shall be given an assurance from the Minister in charge of this Bill that the matter will be amended in the Budget session. If we received that assurance, I suppose we shall have to put up with it.

There have been several committee reports on this subject and, once again, the Government's decisions have been hampered by their ideology of socialism because the Government wants full Federal control. The 1982 report of the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee recommended that the Commonwealth should progressively get out of the area and leave the running of these nursing homes to the States, which already have so much input. The report recommended that for the Commonwealth to retain control results only in overlapping in various responsibilities. The States already are the major providers of health care for their citizens. Why should the Commonwealth take over the aged care just because people are getting older?

As an Opposition we shall be monitoring the position because we tend to think that the one area of government should take over the lot and that there should not be an overlapping of responsibilities. Indeed, Dr Blewett in February 1983 supported the House of Representatives report and said that there had to be fundamental changes-not piecemeal but fundamental changes. Yet here we have half a package, which will have a piecemeal effect, in respect of nursing home care being rushed through the Parliament prior to this early election. The industry was not given time to examine the matter and adequate consultation did not take place. The industry had only a weekend to consider the Bill before the debate in the House of Representatives took place. I bet the Government is being lobbied hard by the Victorian industry at the moment. I should like to read from a report by the Department of Community Services.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension I was saying that I believed that the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation was being rushed through the Parliament by the Government. The Government commissioned a report, which I have in front of me, entitled `The Cost of Nursing Homes and Hostel Care Services' by Coopers and Lybrand, W. D. Scott for the Department of Community Services. The Government asked Coopers and Lybrand to establish the cost patterns and levels which would assist in determining levels of program grants if the Government decided to go down that track of national benefits to nursing homes. The main recommendation says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . nursing homes are a mixed group, with a variety of individual characteristics and operating situations which means that they tend to develop individual cost patterns . . . the concept of `equal funding' is thereby complicated.
The report states:

We are ultimately led to recommend the independent approach because after exhaustive search, we are unable to substantiate that costs as they currently exist in the industry show sufficient consistency for generating standard costs.

If the report tells the Government that an independent approach ought to be made and that there is insufficient consistency of industry costs throughout Australia, why will the Government not accept the recommendation? This Government does this sort of thing so often. Bettina Cass in the social welfare areas was commissioned to tell the Government what she thought about family allowances and whether they ought to be means tested. She said very clearly that for horizontal equity purposes the Government must not means test the family allowance. This Government spends I do not know how many hundreds of thousands of dollars commissioning reports then, of course, refuses to take any notice of them. Again I ask: Why the rush? The hospital industry had only the weekend to look at the legislation. The Minister for Community Services (Mr Hurford) in his letter to me said:
The changes are strongly supported by most sections of the nursing home industry and by the major consumer bodies representing the aged.

That is not what we on this side of the chamber have heard the industry say. I assure the Minister that not only Victoria but also New South Wales have rejected the legislation. So again I ask: Why the rush? We all become very suspicious when this Government does this sort of thing. As things stand, from 1 July this year nursing homes will be that section of their costs called-a very complicated name-the standard aggregate module, nicknamed SAM, comprising food, laundry, cleaning and all those sorts of domestic costs plus an element of profit and being 45 per cent of the total cost of nursing homes, paid at the average infrastructure cost for all participating homes in 1984-85. It is to be indexed by the weighted average of actual and projected movements in average weekly earnings and the consumer price index. Working out this SAM is a very complicated business. The gist of it is that nursing homes throughout Australia are to be given a certain benefit by the Government-and that will be it. The Government claims that this will advantage 65 per cent of participating and deficit-funded non-government nursing homes by upgrading their fees and will disadvantage only 35 per cent of homes. As the Government has pointed out, these are mainly in Victoria, but there are also some in South Australia.

The cost of patient care in nursing homes across Australia varies considerably. The Government argues that because nursing homes can claim increases for fees and benefits on the basis of their actual cost increases, this does not provide any incentive for efficiency. The Government says that under the new system if nursing homes keep their costs under SAM-that is, the average cost of nursing homes-they can earn a larger profit because their profit will be tied to that fee. The Opposition is prepared to monitor the progress of this system to be sure that there are not unexpected anomalies. However, we still believe that the Commonwealth should accept the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, gradually handing over the responsibility for nursing homes to the States. As I have said, it is the States that understand local priorities, issues and needs. All this cannot be understood by big brother in Canberra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on behalf of the Opposition on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. I congratulate the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) for squeezing something out of the scrooge that we call a Treasurer. These poverty traps needed to be fixed but I have to say that election time is a particularly cynical time to be doing so. The fact that the Government has finally come to grips with these poverty traps cannot hide the fact that the changes and cutbacks by this Government in veterans' entitlements over the four years that it has had to do something meaningful for them have been really unjust.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw attention to just what the Government has been doing for veterans over its four-year stewardship. The first group of cutbacks arose from the May 1985 mini-Budget. In that mini-Budget the travel allowance was reduced by half to a flat rate of 11.6c per kilometre with a reduction in government expenditure totalling $3m. Obviously this particularly affected country veterans, but it did not seem to matter to the Government; it was a question simply of money. In addition, the subsistance allowance, including meals and accommodation, was reduced substantially by half a million dollars. We also know that the eligibility for some categories of service to utilise the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme was terminated. Under the dental scheme there were four categories of treatment which were limited to a maximum of $300 annum. Those changes came under the May 1985 mini-Budget.

Then there were changes arising from the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Some of those related to the totally and permanently incapacitated pension. I am very concerned as to what was done. Criteria were tightened up and veterans who suffer further disability after leaving the work force are no longer eligible for TPI pensions. That will not be forgotten by the veterans of this country. Provision was also made for the termination of the dependants' allowance by commutation, albeit on a voluntary basis, and there will be no further increases in that allowance. The repatriation cover was extended to those who served in HMAS Sydney and other support ships between Australia and Vietnam, but still recognition by way of an appropriate award remains unresolved.

Then we turn to the 1986 Budget. Once again the veterans felt the hot breath of this Government. War widows and their dependants, as well as service pensioners with their fringe benefits, no longer have access to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme. They bitterly resent it. They will not let the Government forget that, come the election. The war widows who also receive an age pension had their social security component frozen at a maximum level of $60.05. An additional Budget decision to apply a reducing permanent maximum level below $60.05 has now been dropped because a successful campaign was launched to redress that injustice. It is interesting to note that the worst excesses of this Government have been overcome only by a concerted attack by the Opposition and the veterans' community. The Government will not listen to the good sense that presumably comes from its own ranks or from its departmental advisers. The situation has to be politically unpalatable before this Government redresses some of its wrongs.

Provision was also made in the 1986 Budget for the Government to claim from private health insurance funds where a veteran was insured for the cost of hospital and medical treatment which until then the Government had paid for. There is no longer any compensatory payment towards his private insurance. That is a mean sort of a provision. Only a mean government which did not really understand the veterans' contribution to this nation would make such a provision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pusillanimous.

—What a lovely word! It describes the situation completely. I thank Senator Messner. Veterans suffered the same six-week deferment from early November of the consumer price index related increases for veterans' pensions. Let us not forget the nit-picking change to the method of veterans and war widows making travelling claims. All of a sudden they found that, having saved their claims over many months to put them all in together, the provision had been changed, which meant, if the claims had not been submitted, that they could claim only for the past three months. I think we may have sorted out that problem after many complaints and representations on behalf of veterans and war widows, but it was another pusillanimous attack on our veteran community. Under the Budget and related legislation, the assets test continues to apply to veterans' service pensions. This has resulted in over 13,000 veterans having their service pensions reduced or cancelled. I am proud to say that my Party remains committed to the abolition of the assets test-lock, stock and barrel.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the most unjust anomaly is the entitlement to totally and permanently incapacitated pensions. A veteran whose health deteriorates the day before he leaves the work force can become entitled to a pension, whereas another who retired the day before will be ineligible. In this category are people who were prisoners of war under the Japanese for many years, but it does not make any difference. Let us not forget that only a fierce campaign stopped the Government succeeding with its 40-year cut-off rule, a cruel decision which would have prevented nearly half a million women from becoming entitled to the war widows' benefit. The veterans will not forget the shameful saga of the Minister and the Australian War Memorial, about which I do not propose to say any more now. However, this all goes to the picture of what this Government has done to the veteran community and what the community will remember when it goes to the polls. That is the record of this Government in veterans' affairs.

By contrast, the Liberal Party's objective is to provide veterans and their dependants with the greatest generosity that responsible government can afford. We do not recognise veterans' entitlements as welfare payments. It is important that they are regarded as compensation for war service. We are all very ready to send our servicemen away to fight for us, but governments can be very mean when it comes to compensating veterans for the effects of that service as they get older. This Government should be ashamed of what it is doing to the people who should be entitled to TPI pensions.

The Minister tells me quite often that he cares very much for the veterans in this community. I take his word that he does care for them, but he certainly does not seem to have a government that cares for them and he does not seem to get very far with his Government. The increasing number of veterans who have been forced by this Government's mismanagement of the economy into the poverty traps we are sitting about trying to rectify tonight will not give him any thanks for caring but not being effective as a member of a government that has put us in this economic mess from which we have to rescue veterans from their poverty traps. Nor will the returned servicewomen thank the Minister for his good intentions.

I remind the Senate of a question a colleague of mine asked the Minister a week or two ago about the plight of returned servicewomen. The Minister said that the matter was going to be the top priority for him, that was at the top of his wish list. Wishes do not help these women. They have waited for 42 years for some recognition of the service they gave to this country on the dirt-floored hospitals at the end of the Kokoda Trail, taking the wounded off the trail and nursing them, regardless of their own state of health. I would have thought that the Minister, who cares so much, he tells me, about these returned service women, and his Government, if it had any heart, would have achieved something for them by now. We have a precedent in the fact that nurses who served in the First World War had to wait 40 years for some sort of recognition of their needs. This country has now waited 42 years for something to be done for the returned servicewomen of the Second World War. It is time they got a fair go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I thank Senator Reid. I am glad to see that somebody cares, even though Senator Tate does not seem to think it is worth worrying about. Obviously, my colleagues on this side of the chamber do.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I find those words extremely offensive. Senator Newman deliberately did not reply to my interjection which would give some sense to the reader of Hansard as to her remarks about me just then. I reminded her that her husband was in a position in the Cabinet to influence the sorts of decisions she would have liked to have seen made in the many years the Liberal-Country Party was in coalition government after the Second World War.
—Senator Newman, obviously the words you used were offensive to the Minister. I ask you to withdraw.

—If I offended the Minister, of course I withdraw the words. I draw his attention to the fact that he has had four years to rectify what obviously is a most unsatisfactory situation. Therefore, there is not much point in pointing to deficiencies in previous governments when the Minister has had four years to rectify what he apparently regards as deficiencies. The mote must also be in his own eye. I am very glad that he recognises that there are deficiencies. If he were ever to get back into government, I am sure that he would do something about it but as of 11 July he will no longer have that opportunity. We will have that opportunity, and Senator Tate will then see what we do. Let him just wait and see.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister in his second reading speech placed a great deal of emphasis on the increased expenditure in repatriation hospitals and on increased wages bills. That does not wash because we all know, and he should know, that expenditures must continue to rise for the time being with the increased number of veterans in their mid-70s and the number of elderly veterans in need of care which will not peak until about 1992. These increases, which the Minister makes so much of, do not really say much except that we are in the peak of our need. They do not reflect any special generosity on the part of the Government. If the Government were truly generous in this area, the Minister would not have spent the past couple of years trying to foist the domiciliary nursing care of the Department of Veterans' Affairs on to the State departments of health. So far, I am glad to so say, the Minister has not been successful.

Once again, as I pointed out earlier, I remind the Senate that veterans' affairs benefits are for compensation for veterans. We expect a very special kind of tender loving care to be given to our veterans who need domiciliary nursing care. The way this Government has mis-managed the health system in this country it is very clear that the State health departments do not have the money or the manpower to provide the sort of domiciliary nursing care that our veterans, at least, are entitled to. Of course, I hope that all citizens could have access to high quality domiciliary nursing care but, if any group of people should take priority in that area, I believe that it is our veterans. At least at the moment the Department of Veterans' Affairs is providing that care. I understand that at least for the past two years the Minister has been trying to get rid of this responsibility and foist it on to the States. If he and his Government were really generous and caring towards veterans, he would not be trying to get rid of this area of responsibility from his Department.

On return to government, our first task will be to restore prosperity. That has to come first. Nobody can afford anything when the country is in the mess it is in. But once we have restored prosperity we will remove anomalies as the resources permit. Much will depend on the fine print in the books when we see what an economic mess we have actually inherited. We cannot really tell from the utterances of the current Treasurer (Mr Keating) just what the true state of affairs is. We constantly hear what the interest rates will be and what the economic performance will be, but when it comes to the point it so often falls short of Treasurer's expectations. So, until we see the books of this nation we cannot judge entirely how bad this mess is. Once we know that we will know just what we can afford to do and how quickly we can afford to do it.

We do not oppose this Bill, as at least it will assist some of those people who are the victims of this Government's economic mismanagement. For that reason we support it. But I wish now to draw attention to the fact that the Australian Democrats intend to move three amendments to this Bill. I would like to describe the attitude of the Opposition to those amendments. We will not be supporting the amendments moved by the Democrats, due mainly to our reluctance to jeopardise the passage of the legislation for the sake of the veteran community itself. We do not want to delay it. We feel it is important that they get the benefit of the removal of the poverty traps. But the lack of time to consider the amendments has been caused directly by the Government's determination to push through a multitude of legislation at the eleventh hour of this Parliament. We recognise that the amendments which the Democrats will be moving are in line with the concerns expressed by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in its sixth report some weeks ago insofar as they relate to the personal rights and liberties of the citizen. We also recognise that the Minister has undertaken to bring an amendment forward in the Budget sittings in relation to sub-section 93 (c) (4) if the advice of the Attorney-General is that such an amendment is desirable.

We have no wish to support fraudulent applications; nor do we believe that the veterans' rights should be placed in jeopardy through some action of the Parliamentary Draftsman. However, the pressure of time that has been placed on us by the Government in respect of this Bill has meant that we are not entirely satisfied that these particular amendments will not make the work of the prosecution impossible where offences are solely within the knowledge of the defendant. On the other hand, the Senate should be aware that only today the Scrutiny of Bills Committee reported to the Senate in its tenth report on the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987. At page 164 of that report the Committee reported:

. . . in future it will, by analogy with the common law defence of mistake of fact, regard as acceptable the imposition of the persuasive onus of proof on the accused in relation to a statutory defence in criminal proceedings where:
(a) the matters to be raised by way of defence by the accused are peculiarly within the knowledge of the accused; and
(b) it would be extremely difficult and costly for the prosecution to be required to negative the defence.

In the light of all those considerations, we undertake, when in government, after 11 July, to reconsider these three sections and, after taking advice from the Attorney-General, if it is clear that these amendments are needed, to present them to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Bill and the related Bill, and the Wool Marketing Bill 1987 and its related Bill. I do not think I could add much more to what Senator Newman has just said about the Veterans Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. I agree with what she said. I have already expressed concern about the report of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes that was presented just recently and my concern about over-regulation and over-control of private hospitals. Similarly with nursing homes, I think it is very important that governments give attention to the provision of care for those who need it. It is a pity that this Bill has been brought in in such great haste and now has to be pushed through at the end of a parliamentary session. That does not do a great deal of credit to the Government because it will not be able to be debated at the length that it probably should be debated.
