SPEECH.PARA: The Bill basically involves a change in funding arrangements to provide standard daily resident fees and standard Commonwealth benefits to replace currently existing cost reimbursement arrangements for non-government nursing homes for aged people. Of course, the aged people of this country of ours are increasing all the time. They are our forebears and I think we owe them a great deal for what they have done for our country and for the way they have worked hard to make this country what it is, although I must admit that in the last few years this beautiful country of ours has fallen away a bit under the stewardship of the Hawke Labor Government. I suppose that is another story for another debate at another time. I suppose that debate will rage through the Australian community in the next little while. It is a debate which I think we will win. The Australian people have been wanting us to be able to have this debate. But, of course, they are wondering: `Why is this election being held? Why is this election coming on so quickly?'.

I return to the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill and the new arrangements which will apply to some 1,250 homes catering for up to 60,000 aged people. As I said, we have to look after the aged people, because we are getting older too, and we want to make sure that when we get to that stage of life and have put a lot of effort into this country of ours, we get looked after in the manner that we would like to see these people looked after at the moment. I think that governments have a very high moral obligation to ensure quality and availability of care for those who need it in their most vulnerable period of life, old age. I want to ensure that private enterprise gets a fair go and that government does not unnecessarily over-regulate industries. I am quite sure that Hansard has recorded all the comments that were made by Senator Walters earlier tonight regarding the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill.

I turn now to the package of wool Bills. Because of the restricted time we have available, I would like to direct my remarks to the Wool Marketing Bill. Its purpose is to replace the Wool Industry Act of 1972. Here again I could make reference to the Hawke Labor Government and the way that it has been pulling the wool over the eyes of the Australian people for the last four years. It has completely pulled the wool over their eyes and it has hidden the real effects on the Australian economy of some of their actions. This Bill will provide for major reforms to the Australian Wool Corporation and the export marketing of wool.

It is designed principally to improve the operational flexibility of the Corporation in today's modern marketing environment. How much it has changed over the past 20 years. The changes are designed to make the Corporation more responsible for areas such as corporate planning and reporting. The impetus for the changes came from the Government's White Paper `Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities' which was published early last year. The wool industry is only one of the industries for which legislation is pending to effect changes to marketing and changed corporate responsibilities. Change for change's sake is not always good, but I think that, with minor amendments, the changes proposed in this Bill will help the industry, and I know that the industry requires it.

While the Bill is fundamentally directed at export marketing, it is expected that the benefits will also flow through to the domestic marketing arrangements. Under the new legislation, the Corporation will have either a full time or a part time chairperson. The full time chair will also be a chief executive or, if part time, a managing director. In addition to the chair, the Corporation will have nine directors as opposed to the existing 10. Selection procedures will also be altered with a selection committee established to suggest suitable directors. The Corporation will set and announce the minimum market indicator reserve price which, as we know, was increased recently. In the past, that has been determined by the Minister for Primary Industry.

The legislation provides for the compulsory registration of wool classers who class wool that is sold at auction. Under such a scheme, minimum standards will be established and penalties will be imposed if the standards are not met. This is a commendable move which should see problems of dirty wool and bales contaminated with an array of objects-in fact, anything that might have been in the shed at the time of baling-alleviated. If something is found in a bale of wool, the wool classer will be responsible. Some interesting objects including items of clothing have been found in bales of wool over the years, even when the wool gets to Japan. Australia currently enjoys a reputation as the best producer of wool in the world. Therefore, we cannot afford to have that reputation jeopardised by sloppy classing and dirty bales, wool contaminated with daggy or coloured wool, and inconsistent classing. Therefore, the legislation is a good thing. We must always strive for excellence in Australia. Excellence is not a word that is often associated with Australian products and it is rarely applied to the Australian work force. It is commendable that one of Australia's rural industries is attempting to provide that level of excellence. It is to be hoped that other industries follow its example.

The whole thrust of the legislation will be to make the Corporation more responsible and more autonomous. All the changes have been proposed in consultation with the Wool Council of Australia. Setting the floor price and the appointment of an auditor will also be undertaken after consultation with the Wool Council. That is good. The Bill is a commendable achievement for the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). I believe that the level of consultation he has undertaken in framing the legislation is to be applauded. Therefore it is a great pity that there are clauses in the legislation which totally negate the good work that he has done. I refer of course to the clauses which impose equal employment opportunity conditions on the AWC. They are clauses 41 and 42 which I will discuss more fully in the Committee stage. However, I warn that the National Party of Australia totally oppose these clauses and will be moving amendments to them, time permitting.

There is no question of the National Party's support for women in the work force. Women and men should have equal opportunity for promotion on merit. In my Party that has always been the case. To impose artificial requirements on any company is absurd and an insult to women in this country. Professional women in Australia do not need artificially constructed quotas to assist them to move into higher positions. Australian women have the ability, the tenacity and the talent to make it on their own. Legislation which somehow suggests that they need help to get ahead is, in my opinion, offensive.

One only has to look at the number of women in this chamber to realise that the role of women in society is much further advanced than it was in the days of our grandfathers and the people about whom I was talking a minute ago in relation to the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill. We now have women heads of our large companies, women heads of government departments, women in the judiciary, women ministers of religion and Ministers in government. One, Senator Ryan, sits opposite. We have a woman Speaker in the other place. She did not need any help to get that position. Because she is in the Australian Labor Party she might have had to have some faction giving her support or not giving her support because the Labor Party has about ten different factions, but I bet she achieved what she has, not because of any female or male connotation. I guarantee that, because the Labor Party thought that in her own right she was the equal of any of the men in the other place. She got the job as the Speaker of the House. Good on her! She did it on her own and she did it because she had the ability. She did not need any legislation to get her into that position. I do not believe therefore that we need special legislation. These ladies are taking and continuing to take their places according to merit. I do not deny that it has not always been so, and I do not deny that there is still a resentment in some areas. We do not live in a perfect world, and legislation cannot always make it so.

It is outrageous to think that we need rather complicated, bureaucratic requirements to ensure that the AWC chooses its staff on merit. It has done so in the past, and I have no doubt that it will do so in the future. A number of women are involved in the wool industry, and they are there because they are talented. They got there on merit. If women think that they will get there because of legislation, they will not feel quite so good. They will wonder whether they got there because of merit or because of legislation. As I said, they are there because they are talented, not because they resorted to any legislation. It is a great pity-and I repeat it for the umpteenth time-that the Minister felt the need to include these clauses in an otherwise very sensible piece of legislation. I personally regret this move.

The Hawke Government has totally mismanaged the economy. I suppose we will be talking about the Government's mismanagement in the next few weeks on the election trail. The wool industry is one of Australia's most buoyant industries. It is one of this country's biggest success stories.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly in Tasmania.

—Even in Tasmania. Tasmania had its record wool price taken away from it by some of my colleagues, the Gills, from Walcha in northern New South Wales. Unless Tasmania does a fiddle down there, it will be a long time before it gets that record price back, because very fine wool is grown in the northern tablelands.

SPEECH.PARA: Wool provides $3.1 billion in export income-the second largest export contribution by any industry, and the largest rural contributor. It is a wonderful industry. This year, despite falling incomes, it is anticipated that the national wool clip will be worth around $4 billion. This is truly a remarkable achievement. At a time when the rural industry is facing record levels of debt and debt repayments, adverse seasonal and market factors, and spiralling costs, the wool industry has shown resilience and, indeed, brilliance in adapting to changed economic conditions. It is no coincidence that the history of the wool industry is full of great men-men who were brilliant; in some cases, men who are still brilliant. They are brilliant wool growers, great administrators and, at times, great leaders and innovators.

At present the industry owes a great debt to the present Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, David Asimus. He has provided great leadership and guidance to the industry for the past 15 or more years. He has given up much of his personal life to attend meetings all over the world, to argue for a better deal from successive governments for the Australian wool growers. He has promoted his product, our major primary industry product, in forums around the world for many years. He has participated in negotiations at the highest levels. Look at the magnificent job he has done in China. The wool industry is indebted to David Asimus for its present prosperity.

There are many others in the industry who I will mention. Ron Hunter, who comes from Moree, was one of the first people to push for a floor price for wool. Mr Bryce Killen was one of the instigators and fathers of the wool industry. I mention also Mr Dick O'Brien, the late Bill Fagen and, of course, Sir William Gunn. They have all played a great part in the wool industry in Australia. As I said, they have all contributed immensely. On the promotion side, the wool industry, because of those men-and many others whom I have not mentioned-has gained enormously. Of course, since those men started things-some of them, as I said, are still working on them-the consumption of wool in Australia has jumped by 53 per cent in the last year. Australia is one of the largest per head consumers of wool in the world. This is a good thing. Wool is a wonderful fibre to wear. I think that many more people should wear it. I had better state, in regard to pecuniary interests, that I do not grow a lot of wool, so I do not really have a pecuniary interest to declare.

The wool industry is a wonderful industry. It will continue to be a wonderful industry because of the people associated with it. We are comparatively lucky that Australians are able to buy the highest quality wool and wool products of any country, and our designers, of course, are in great demand throughout the world. The Corporation can take great pride in its promotional activities. It has provided an example for other industries to emulate. Through Australia's involvement with the International Wool Secretariat, wool and wool blend trademarks now have world recognition. Through the assistance provided by the IWS, advances have been made possible in wool technology, quality control, product marketing, design and styling and research and development.

In the areas of research and development the wool industry again contributes by actively supporting research programs on a range of issues, such as pasture improvement, sheep breeding, parasite control, improved husbandry techniques and automated shearing. Of course, there are two centres in Australia that are looking at robotic shearing-one in Adelaide and one in Perth in Western Australia. I do not think that we will ever see the shearing of a sheep change from being done by people like--

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Mick Young.

—Like Mr Young in the other place. Maybe he should go back to shearing. He might have to go back to shearing after the next election. Maybe Mr Young will have to find his vocation in the shearing sheds after the next election.
—I think he has slipped the skin off you.

—He would be too rough, I think. An amount of $2m was provided last year from the Wool Research Trust Fund to research wool harvesting and development. A number of patents have been filed and licences negotiated with a number of manufacturers of shearing gear. Two new shearing hand-pieces were released for sale as a result of the work that has been done in this area. Australia, as I said, is contributing enormously to the wool technology field. Growers, as much as anyone else, need to be applauded for their contribution through levies to this important work.

SPEECH.PARA: The important thing about the wool industry, of course, is that the people who are growing the wool are putting money back into the industry. Similarly, growers' funds have been used to improve measurement techniques and manufacturing methods. Over $7m was provided during 1985-86 for research into textiles. Nearly $1m was spent on economic research, and over $1m on research into diseases and parasites. Money has been provided for scholarships and funds to universities and colleges for programs associated with the wool industry. The amount that growers provide will be increased through the Wool Tax Bills, which form part of this package, from the present 8 per cent to 10 per cent of the gross value of the annual clip. Therefore, growers take seriously the importance of research, promotion and education. I repeat: This Bill is a good Bill except for the inclusion of the provision requiring people to have equal employment opportunities, which I do not think is necessary in this legislation. In the time remaining to me, the other Bill about which I wish to speak is the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Collection Bill 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't got chooks, too, have you?

—As a matter of interest, I have some free ranging chooks. They are very good chooks, as I have told Senator Georges, and they are well looked after. The two egg Bills involve increasing the amount of levy collected from the egg industry. This levy is necessary because the Commonwealth hen levy which funded research has been phased out. The levy is imposed annually and collected twice annually. Under the provisions of the Bill the Commonwealth is able to make arrangements with the States, through the State egg boards or corporations, to collect the levy on its behalf. The only thing that worries me a little is that if this Government were returned it would probably want to collect a little more. The method of collection enables the State boards to deduct the levies from receipts of egg sales and from those who sell direct to wholesalers, and egg producers pay direct to the board.

SPEECH.PARA: To ease the financial burden the levy is paid in two instalments over the year-in January and July. Previously the levy was payable every fortnight, so there will be savings in the twice-yearly collection. The levy was primarily collected for use by State egg boards in equalising the impact on individual producers of losses incurred in disposing of egg surpluses. In recent years the States have reduced surplus production through limiting hen quotas-a step in the right direction. As anyone following the egg industry would know, this measure has been progressing for some time. In 1984 a decision was made to phase out the Commonwealth hen levy with effect from 30 June 1987. Accordingly an alternative mechanism to secure producers' contributions towards research was needed, which is why this legislation is before us tonight.

The legislation will secure research funds from the industry and this will be matched by Commonwealth grants. Under the Bill a levy is imposed, based on the quotas of hens the producer holds under licence. A maximum rate of 10c a hen is provided for with an operative level set by regulation, taking into account advice from the Australian Council of Egg Producers. An operative rate of 3c to 4c per hen would provide funds comparable with those currently received. Under clause 12 of the Bill the levy will be discontinued if any State opts out of the quota system. The two Bills involve no additional Commonwealth funding; and that is good for this Government, which is the highest spending and the highest taxing government in Australia's history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a package of Bills, many of which seem to have little relationship to others. The reason for this is so that the Government can guillotine the Bills through the Senate, which it is doing with the support of the Australian Democrats. Those people who would never agree to a guillotine have once again agreed to guillotine through the legislation that the Australian Labor Party requires. Interestingly enough, this was done with the support of Senator Siddons, Senator Georges and Senator Gietzelt.
—I should hope he did; Gietzelt is one of ours.

—I apologise, I meant Senator Vallentine, and also Senator Siddons and Senator Georges, who all supported the guillotine and the gag. I was thinking of Senator Gietzelt because I was about to turn my mind to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, and Senator Gietzelt is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in the last days of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the differences between the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal and National parties is that we remember that the assistance that we provided to veterans is compensation, not welfare. I was only a kid at the time, but I remember back to the Second World War, when we told service men and women, who we were sending overseas: `Look, if you are unlucky and cop it you will not have to worry; your wife and kids will be looked after'. Forty years after the end of that war, there is a tendency to forget that. The new generations are a fair age and they may have forgotten it. However, I am sure that, once they are reminded of it, they will say that it was fair enough. Service men and women were told: `The widows and kids will be looked after, and if you are lucky enough to return from the war, you will not need to worry if you have any war injuries because we will look after those also'. That is a solemn contract into which the nation entered with them. We must, of course, comply with that contract to the end of their days.

I regret very much that many of those service people are now getting on in years. I understand that their average age is over 65-indeed, about 68. There is still a large number of them, about 400,000, but they are coming to a time in life when they need the sort of assistance that we promised them when they volunteered for overseas service.

One thing that is happening as a result, quite frankly, of the economic problems of this country-for which this Government must bear a great deal of responsibility because of its economic mismanagement of the nation, the resultant economic problems and the Government's attempts to reduce its expenditure by squeezing various areas instead of responsibly considering ways that the problems could be overcome-is the squeezing of the medical and nursing professions, which is flowing through to, in particular, the repatriation hospitals.

I wish to quote from a letter from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Gietzelt) about the extensive delays for, for example, vascular surgery at the repatriation hospitals at Heidelberg, Victoria. He said:

The extensive delays for vascular surgery at RGH Heidelberg have mainly been brought about by the rapidly declining health of an ageing veteran population, combined with the lack of adequate resources to cope with an increasing demand.
I repeat the last sentence:
. . . lack of adequate resources to cope with an increasing demand.

The Minister has kindly provided me with the following table of approximate waiting times for surgery at Heidelberg as of 7 May: Ear, nose and throat, 18 weeks; detailing optical works, 18 weeks; general surgery, 20 weeks; joint repairs and replacements, for example, hip replacements, 20 weeks; other orthopaedic work, 18 weeks; neuro-surgery, 18 weeks; plastics, 29 weeks; urology-very important, I would have thought, with an aging population-40 weeks; vascular surgery, 28 weeks. I suggest that those periods would seem interminable to elderly veterans who may be immobile, in pain or in serious discomfort. The Minister has pointed out that the waiting list relates to the shortage of nurses and the nurses' dispute last year. However, he said that there had been an improvement since the settlement of that dispute and that all the theatres were now fully operational. Yet between 27 April and 7 May this year, according to the Minister's own letters, that routine list grew from 120 to 132 patients. If that rate of growth were to continue, the number on the waiting list would double by the end of this year. The Minister, in his note to me detailing the delays, went on to say:
Other factors influencing waiting times include large numbers of patients and shortage of specialists in some areas.
In paragraph 4 of that note he said:
The Visiting Medical Officers' dispute had no effect on waiting times.

Here we seem to be getting close to the truth of the matter. If the visiting medical officers' dispute has had no effect on waiting times, the alternative is obviously simple lack of resources. This is backed up by the information reaching me.

Last week an elderly veteran came to see me with an absolute catalogue of complaints about Concord Hospital, and I understand that it is only because of the untiring efforts of a small, overworked and dedicated group of doctors at Greenslopes in Queensland and the admission of many patients to other hospitals, that those hospitals are not facing a similar crisis. The position at Daw Park in South Australia is critical. I heard recently-and this is disgraceful-of an 80-year-old veteran with a broken leg who was turned away from Daw Park because of the continued dispute between the Government and the Australian Medical Association.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who turned him away?

—The hospital turned him away because it was unable to deal with him as a result of the dispute with the medical profession. Today my colleague Senator Messner has had a telephone call from a Mr Brace in South Australia, who apparently does not mind his name being mentioned. Mr Brace is a 64-year-old totally and permanently incapacitated pensioner. He is below the average age. He has suffered a stroke and has some soft tissue problem and skin cancer, yet he has been told by the Daw Park Repatriation Hospital that he cannot have treatment until the strike is over. He recently asked for medication and was told by the medical staff that he could not have it and that if he really wanted it he could buy it because, in their words, `you are on a good pension'. He is very angry because he feels that, as a veteran, he is being badly done by. He simply does not feel looked after. He believes that the doctors in South Australia are being greedy and unrealistic. He feels that Daw Park is not being run properly and he criticises the administrative and medical staff. He claims that he is not getting a fair go. I understand his complaints and I have much compassion for him and the many other veterans who are having great difficulty in repatriation hospitals around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is hard to believe, but I have heard that a 72-year-old veteran has been on a waiting list for 16 months. Another veteran, aged 67, has been placed on the long routine list of vascular surgery, despite having just suffered a debilitating heart attack. The simple fact is that something is wrong. This Government has failed to provide the services needed to cope with the aging veteran population. The Government knew that this would happen. The statistical evidence continues to point out that this aging population will be a very considerable problem over the next decade. There is no doubt that these additional services will be needed. But now, apart from targeting veterans' entitlements in a series of economic measures, as this Government has done, frankly it has simply failed to ensure that the system will be able to cope with the growth in demand for veteran health care. As I have said, the demand will reach a peak in the mid-1990s when, sadly, there will be a fall-off among World War II veterans.

The Government is aware that much of this crisis has been created by its problems with and its reluctance to negotiate new contracts for visiting medical officers-nurses and other medical staff-at repatriation hospitals. The truth is that this reluctance to negotiate is connected with the wider problems associated with the explosion in Medicare costs and the inefficient delivery of health services to the general public.

I said the other day in the course of a debate that one of the great problems is that the Government offered to the people of Australia that they should opt for public health treatment. That was the Government's promise back in 1983 and repeated in 1984. The Government told people not to worry about private health cover as it would look after them under Medicare and would charge them one per cent-I think it is now 1 1/4 per cent-additional tax to cover their health care. But, having taken that 1 1/4 per cent out of people's income, what the Government failed to do was to provide additional services in the public hospital sector to cope with the massive increase in demand on that sector. The result has been that people around Australia have had to opt out of the public health system, notwithstanding the additional tax that they are paying for that cover, and have had to take out private health insurance so that when they get sick they are able to receive treatment.

The Government is fearful of the explosive cost contained within the Medicare service. The Government fears that, if it were to pay the doctors and nurses at the repatriation hospitals the sorts of allowances that they may very well be entitled to-I am not au fait with all the details to be in a position to know whether they are entitled to them-that might flow back into the public hospital system and there would be an explosion in costs that the Government would simply be unable to contain.

The Government has been avoiding proper negotiations with the medical staff at repatriation hospitals. I add that this problem already exists in the Australian Capital Territory, where until today, the Government had refused to enter into meaningful negotiations with the doctors in public hospitals, and health care services have been coming to a standstill. I understand that today, at long last, the Government has indicated that it is prepared to negotiate with the Australian Capital Territory doctors in this dispute, at least along the lines on which it is prepared to negotiate with the New South Wales repatriation doctors. I am hopeful that that dispute will at least be deferred in some way or another. Quite frankly, I make a plea to the Australian Capital Territory doctors, and to the repatriation doctors in South Australia, Queensland and other places where strikes or withdrawal of services are taking place, to stop their action. Parliament is about to rise, an election is due and there may well be negotiations which the Government will be able to carry on during the next five weeks or so, but the truth is that as from now this Government is only a caretaker government. It should not be entering into final solutions to these problems. It should be simply entering into tentative settlements so that when we come into government after 11 July we shall be able to enter into proper negotiations with the medical profession.

In view of the way in which this Government has messed up this nation's economy, we as the next government may well have great difficulties in meeting the doctors' demands, no matter how valid they may be. This country is in an economic crisis. The first and most important thing that needs to be done is to bring the nation back to a stage where at least our books are balanced. We must get the economy flowing again. We must reduce interest rates and bring down taxation so as to provide some incentive to this country. Once we have established those circumstances, we shall be able to look to resolving some of the problems such as those about which the medical profession is complaining. If we can get this country firing again, we shall be able to do something about them. But this Government has mismanaged the economy; it has screwed it down so that people are unable to make a quid, are unable to get out and be successful in their operations. We all know the way in which this Government has been ripping into small business and taking its hard-earned gains in taxes. The Government has brought this country to a stage where most small businessmen are sick to death of the situation. They will certainly want to throw out this Government on 11 July.

Turning back to the veterans, I believe that they are being treated shabbily in having to pay the Medicare levy. I am sure that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs is sincere in the concerns he expresses for veterans, but the truth is that the Minister has been unable to get through to the Government the urgency of veterans' demands. While he may be sincere, the Government has taken benefits away from the veterans to whom we all owe a special debt. They are being forced to accept an unfair share of the burden of this Government's mismanagement of the national economy. The Government cannot pass the buck elsewhere. Australians will not accept the proposition that veterans' medical care services should be starved of resources, but the Minister has acknowledged that that is what is happening. I am sure the Minister will not deny that veterans are being placed on long waiting lists for surgery, that admissions are being delayed, and that patients are being discharged prematurely. The Minister admits this in his letters. He also admits that he cannot be of `assistance' to these patients. He says that the long wait has been caused, on his own admission, by a `lack of resources'.

I am concerned about the financial burden which the Liberal-National Party coalition government will be facing when we attain government on 11 July and about the great difficulty we will have in overcoming this Government's failure to supply those resources. I ask: Who is responsible? Well, it clearly has to be Mr Keating, for the way he has mismanaged the economy, and his colleague Senator Walsh. They have screwed the departments, the taxpayers and the nation. Yet they have still managed to end up with a great debt. I believe Australia has always been proud of the treatment that it has provided veterans in the past. I repeat that it is quite improper that these mostly elderly veterans of the Second World War should be expected to bear an unfair share of the burden of this Government's economic mismanagement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wool Marketing Bill proposes some quite wide ranging changes to the present program under the Wool Industry Act 1972. Some of these changes include, for example: The extension of the marketing powers of the Australian Wool Corporation; new provisions for quality control and the requirements that the Australian Wool Corporation prepare corporate plans each year for ensuing five-year periods; new procedures for the selection of the board members of the Corporation; provisions for the Corporation and the Wool Council of Australia to determine minimum reserve prices for wool; and the full vesting of ownership of the Wool Stores in the name of the Australian Wool Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: The wool industry is vitally important to Australia, accounting in 1985-86 for 10 per cent of the nation's exports, and earning some $3,100m in export income. In my own state of Tasmania the wool industry has historically played a very significant role, and as a tribute to that, as a bicentenary project, a Tasmanian wool centre is being established in the midlands town of Ross to give recognition to the contribution made to this industry in this area. As many honourable senators will be aware, superfine wool from properties in this region consistently draws world record prices. The wool industry is currently buoyant, with export earnings contributing significantly to the solution of our balance of payments problems. I believe it is widely recognised that much of the credit for the development of this industry, and its progress over recent years, has to go to the Australian Wool Corporation and to the untiring efforts of its membership. However, in these times I believe we cannot afford to be complacent.

It has been calculated by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics that the real price of wool to the producer, taking inflation into account, is in fact lower in 1985-86 than it was in 1974-75. Mr David Asimus, the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, notes in the 1985-86 annual report that there are no inherent loyalties to wool in the highly competitive international textile fibre markets. Furthermore, the cost of the promotion of wool overseas has increased markedly with the depreciation of the Australian dollar. Most would agree that there is a need to keep pace with this changing and volatile market and, to this end, some of the proposals put forward in the Bill I believe are to be welcomed. In particular I refer to Division 3, clause 74, which relates to quality control. Short cuts in the preparation of the wool clip can only jeopardise Australia's reputation as a supplier of superfine wool. If we are to maintain a competitive edge in the market-place, it is essential that we meet requirements in this area and that we can guarantee a consistent standard to all purchasers. For example, I refer to programs to introduce staple length and staple strength measurements to the auction selling system and the introduction of a code of practice and standards relating to wool clip preparation. Both of these measures are signs that the industry is moving in the right direction. The ability of the Wool Corporation to monitor and control the quality of export wool should give overseas buyers the confidence in the product they require to maintain satisfactory prices. As announced in the May economic statement, the wool industry has suffered a cut in research funding of $5m, and that amount would have gone towards improving the marketability of the product. I believe that such research is important in maintaining the standard expected of our export wool.

It should be noted, however, that these proposals relate only to the auction system and do not provide the same measure of control over wool sold through other channels. I do hold some reservations about some of the proposals before us. My principal reservation concerns the extension of the powers of the Australian Wool Corporation to enable its board to form subsidiary companies and to enter into joint ventures. I believe that such proposals contain the foundation for changes within the industry that have the potential to damage many established wool processing and exporting companies. I also believe that we must be quite wary of the possibility of socialisation within the industry which may result from giving statutory marketing authorities such as the Australian Wool Corporation too much power and too big an advantage in the market-place.

It is in this area that we should be able to learn a valuable lesson from the New Zealand experience. The New Zealand Wool Board is currently in conflict with the International Wool Textile Association over the extension of the Board's commercial activities. It is therefore probable that similar changes in Australia will occur as a result of this legislation. More specifically, changes in the New Zealand Wool Board's commercial activity have created rifts between the Board and companies involved in the industry. I believe this legislation has the potential to cause these sorts of problems and these sorts of rifts here in Australia. Concern has been registered, for example, that the New Zealand Wool Board is now trading in wool in its own right and has invested, for example, in major scouring and exporting in competition with the rest of the industry. It is felt, I believe rightly, that it is both unfair and totally unacceptable for a government body to engage in commercial and regulatory functions.

The proposals at hand pertaining to the Australian wool industry contain no provisions to prevent the Australian Wool Corporation opening up in competition with established companies. The objection here is not to competition per se but to a government statutory organisation having an unfair advantage in the market-place by virtue of its access to and knowledge of regulatory and market developments.

The accountability factor also has to be considered. Establishing public companies outside the control of the Parliament means that public scrutiny of the operations of the organisations would be markedly decreased. That would be an unfortunate development. As a result of the implementation of these proposals there would be a decline in public accountability at a time when we should be striving to achieve just the opposite. This is a reflection of a tendency started by this Government to remove more and more items from the scrutiny of the Parliament; in other words, to move them off-Budget and into not properly accountable company or corporate forms.

I believe it is the job of the Minister for Primary Industry to foster and develop the Australian wool sector. This proposal means that the Minister will abdicate much of this responsibility under this legislation as compared with the legislation that it supersedes. For example, one could well ask: To whom will the subsidiary companies of the Australian Wool Corporation be accountable? A few years ago there were problems in relation to Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd with the creation of subsidiary companies and the question of accountability arose in that instance. Whilst I understand that there is a need for a degree of what we might term commercial flexibility, I believe this legislation goes far too far down this road towards socialisation.

In summary, whilst many of the proposals contained in the Bill will enable the wool industry to secure its foothold in the international market, I believe the provisions relating to the formation of subsidiary companies by the Australian Wool Corporation overstep the mark. We should be aiming to maintain vitality and innovation in industry and to provide cohesion between all sectors. In this way the industry will be best fitted to maintain a favourable position in the international market.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this scrambled eggs package of Bills which deals with hen quotas, veterans' affairs, nursing homes and hostels, and wool marketing. The three areas I wish to touch upon are nursing homes and hostels, wool marketing, and social security and veterans' affairs. I shall deal firstly with the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. The Bill is merely a cost containment exercise by the Government, which one could have expected after looking at the history of nursing homes legislation and administration in Australia over the last 20 years. I remember that in 1972 the Federal Government decided to help nursing homes and hostels by providing subsidies for their patients. I stormed the country advising nursing homes and hostels not to take the government subsidy because if they did that their whole economy would become dependent upon that subsidy. Once that happens the Government can assume control of those institutions. There is an old proverb that says that anything the Government wishes to control it first subsidises. This is what happened with the nursing homes industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Once it was subsidised, of course, the Government realised the enormous costs involved in running the homes and hostels so it started an exercise in cost containment. That exercise has been going on for many years in Australia. The way in which the health insurance industry was structured previously meant that there was a flow of patients from their homes to hostels, to specialised care, to nursing homes and then to hospitals. This forced the patients up the ladder and caused a log jam at the high priced end of the system-nursing homes and hostels. All of a sudden the bureaucracy realised this was costing too much and it decided to reverse the flow. This is what we are seeing now; the Government is trying to reverse the flow of patients to nursing homes, hospitals and hostels and to push them back into their own homes. This creates its own log jam, which we are seeing now.

The legislation deals with cost containment in many areas. It is not equitable for all of Australia. Nursing homes are funded under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act and the National Health Act. The idea behind this legislation is to gradually force them all into the one area of funding. It is a mechanism of standardising down. Not only that; at the same time as it standardises down nursing care in the public sector, it precludes the private sector from entering the field and taking the load off the back of the Government.

Many people in the nursing homes and hostel industry will now be very happy to be removed from the yoke of government. It is the intrusion of government into the industry which has increased the costs no end. On reading this legislation, we see that the Government is requiring a high level of standards at a low level of costs. This has just removed this business from all economic reality. Everybody knows that if one wants a Rolls Royce, one has to pay more; if one wants a Holden, one can pay less; but both will get the person to the destination.

It is a pity to see this legislation coming in. It disadvantages certain States, particularly Victoria, which at the moment is up in arms. I remember when this sort of legislation first came in. The Government was trying to work out what sort of subsidy it should give to nursing homes in different States. All the States put in their nursing home costs to work out what the rebate should be under the insurance scheme. In Queensland, for example, the costs of the guilds or other goodwill workers who provided services to nursing homes were not added in, whereas in Victoria they were. So the costs in Victoria seemed a lot higher than in other States. So the subsidy in Victoria was a lot higher than it was in Queensland. The same thing applied in South Australia. Everybody wondered why this should come about.

Now the Government is working, over a series of steps, to have the same subsidy apply all over Australia. In Mount Isa, for example, where there are wage loadings different from those in Sydney or Melbourne, how can costs be the same? With this legislation the Government is withdrawing to quite a considerable extent from the funding of nursing homes and hostels. I regard that as a good step, but it is only a good step if the capacity to look after people who want to be looked after privately is unlocked. But the Government is not doing this. It is keeping locks on the private industry, as it is in the whole of the health industry throughout Australia today. It is putting more and more restrictions on the public service, but not unlocking the private service. So there is a glut of people wanting accommodation in public hospitals. A lot of public hospital beds are being closed because of costs. This is happening also in the private area. The Government is deciding how many beds it will license for nursing homes and hostels all around Australia. It is curtailing costs and putting a ceiling on them without unlocking the private sector. This robs many people of the type of care they are entitled to, that they want and are prepared to pay for. I cannot talk on that subject any more because time is running out.

I will move on to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. This again is another exercise in the Government cutting expenses. But in this case it is trying to overcome the fraud and other means by which people are getting money out of the veterans and social security area. We cannot oppose that. In fact, we are in favour of stopping that kind of rip-off of the public purse. This Government has opened the floodgates, enabling people to rip off the system. The Government, having found the system was being ripped off, is now trying to close the loopholes. I do not think the Government pays enough respect to those people who are entitled to veterans' pensions and other government assistance. It plays down the whole defence of this country, from the forces that are supposed to defend us, including the reserve forces, right through to the returned servicemen, some of whom are disabled, who are entitled to repatriation and veterans' benefits. Previously, the Government opened up opportunities to rip off the system. It is now closing the doors, for which we are grateful, but it is denigrating the place of veterans in our society.

The National Party welcomes the Wool Marketing Bill because of the new structure it provides for the marketing of wool in Australia, which will help the industry no end. What we object to in the Bill is its affirmative action elements pertaining to the employment of women in the industry. Our Party will be recording our dissent from those features, as we did when the recent affirmative action and equal opportunity legislation was introduced here. We do not support that type of modification to behaviour in society. We are very sorry to see that it has been included in the Wool Marketing Bill. National Party senators will record their dissent at the second reading stage of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Wool Marketing Bill, which is of great importance to Australian wool growers and to Australia. It should be of interest to all Australians as this year we are likely to benefit from an all-time record $4 billion return from our wool exports. Clearly, this makes the wool industry our second most prominent source of export income, behind only the coal industry, which is earning a shade more than $5 billion. In net terms the foreign exchange obtained by the wool industry probably exceeds that of coal because the wool industry does not repatriate much of its earnings through overseas parent companies and certainly does not have to satisfy the demands of very substantial loans from overseas borrowers. Wool is perhaps the best placed of all farm industries in these difficult times, although grower incomes on average this year across all sheep and wool farms still do not reach the level of the average wage. I pay tribute to all rural producers who are on the receiving end of high costs and high interest rates. It is certainly not very easy for them.

SPEECH.PARA: My National Party colleagues and I do not feel that it is necessary for the Government to keep putting equal employment opportunity provisions into all its legislation. I have always said that if a woman has ability she can get where she wants to. That is evidenced in our Senate. I believe in equal opportunity but I do not believe in favouring women against men. This could happen if we keep on putting equal employment opportunity provisions into legislation. Those are my thoughts on the matter. Senator Boswell, who is not here this evening, also feels exactly the same way, as does Senator Collard. Senator Sheil, Senator Brownhill and I all want to register the fact that we feel it is quite unnecessary to have an equal employment opportunity provision in this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, before you call the vote, I want to give an undertaking to the Opposition. The Opposition had proposed to move an amendment to one of the Bills requiring that the Minister not take action against a nursing home under the new powers in the Act until he or she had established a standards review panel in the State or Territory in which the nursing home was located. The Government endorses the spirit of that proposal. However, to avoid the possible delay to the legislation that would ensue from the Opposition's amendment, the Opposition has agreed to the Minister's proposal that it would not proceed with the amendment subject to his giving two undertakings. The Minister has now given these undertakings, which are, first, that no action will be taken under the new powers against a nursing home until a review panel has been established in the State or Territory in which the home is located; and, secondly, that further amendments will be introduced to the National Health Act in the Budget sitting to give effect to the amendment moved by the Opposition.
—I thank the Minister.

—Order! The time allotted for the consideration of these Bills having expired, I put the question: That the remaining stages of the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Bill 1987, the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Collection Bill 1987, the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the Wool Marketing Bill 1987 and the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1987 be agreed to and that the Bills be now passed.

DEBATE.TITLE: TELECOMMUNICATIONS (INTERCEPTION) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendment made by the Senate to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: ORDER OF BUSINESS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That unless otherwise ordered, and notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, the routine of business for Friday, 5 June 1987 be as follows:
(a) Petitions
(b) Notices of Motion
(c) Questions
(d) Any proposal pursuant to Standing Order 64, discussion of which shall not exceed 1 hour
(e) Ministerial statements
(f) Formal motions; discovery of Formal Business
(g) Presentation and consideration of papers.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will take us up till when?
—With a bit of luck, that will take us up till about 1.30.
—What about the valedictories?

—Oh, sorry, no. The expectation is that we start at 9 o'clock, pursuant to the existing standing orders, with Question Time; that we will have a one-hour matter of public importance or urgency motion after that, which will take us through to 11 o'clock; followed by a ministerial statement, which will take as long as the Minister chooses to take; followed by one hour for the presentation of papers, which will enable discussion of all those papers and statements about which motions have been moved this week-not just those which I am about to table in a moment but things like the Parliament House motion which I moved before.
—Fifty papers!

—Yes, but Senator Sheil will not speak on any of them, will he? After that time expired we would move to the valedictory. If that is finished by 1.30 or whatever, so be it. The idea would be to move continually through and get up at 1.30 or 2.00-however long it takes to do that. I think that that would suit the convenience, expectations and desires of honourable senators all round the chamber. There is no desire to constrain time, but I think that there is a feeling that the sooner we get out of here the better for our mental health.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON NATIONAL RESOURCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources on the adequacy of quarantine in the Torres Strait area and seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows-
The Senate Standing Committee on National Resources Report was tabled in the Senate on 16 November 1986. The Committee had previously reported in 1979 more broadly on the adequacy of quarantine.

The Torres Strait region covers the area of water north of the Cape York Peninsula to the south-west coast of Papua New Guinea, and the Northern Peninsula reserves of the Cape. The Strait itself is marked by innumerable reefs, cays, and islands, with an estimated population of over 6,000. The area subject to Australian territorial control forms part of the State of Queensland.

Animal and plant quarantine activities are carried out by the Queensland Department of Primary Industries on the Commonwealth's behalf. Tasks of a human health and more general quarantine significance are carried out by Commonwealth officers, with regional control exercised through Townsville. These activities rely heavily on islander cooperation.

The region poses unique problems and challenges in a quarantine sense. It is a major international shipping route and its proximity to Papua New Guinea and Irian Jaya poses particular risks, as both have pests and diseases exotic to Australia. A number of pests not found on the mainland have been identified on the islands themselves.

Subsistence cropping, and the presence of both domestic and feral animals on islands exacerbates the risk factor. The detection of citrus canker on Thursday Island in 1984, and black sigotoka, a serious banana disease, following eradication attempts on initial detection in 1981, are but two examples.
The Torres Strait Treaty guarantees freedom of movement for traditional inhabitants, and traditional trading arrangements, while acknowledging quarantine importance.
Additionally, while the Cape York Peninsula is sparsely populated, its volume of recreational vehicle movement has increased markedly.

The Senate Standing Committee report has highlighted the high quarantine risks Australia faces in and through the area, and the challenges these pose for control purposes. While viewing quarantine initiatives in the area as generally sound, the Committee has raised a range of matters it sees as needing particular attention and action.
These cover:
Arrangements under the Torres Strait Treaty, including frequency of meetings of the Torres Strait Advisory Council, and a review of the Treaty's quarantine-related articles within four years;
Review of the adequacy of quarantine resources and ways and means of increasing a quarantine and treaty awareness among islanders;
The adequacy of screw-worm fly and Newcastle disease monitoring and control contin- gency arrangements;
Review of the adequacy of plant quarantine measures;

A range of other issues including control of the movement of live animals and goods; training aimed at appointment of islander quarantine officers; powers to search Australian vessels coming from the protected zone; review of the schedule of items exempt from quarantine; revival of tripartite quarantine meeting arrangements with Indonesia and Papua New Guinea; possible purchase of a larger more seaworthy vessel for quarantine patrols.

The Senate has, moreover, stressed the vital need for quarantine measures to be adequate to protect Australia's rural industries, particularly in relation to the level of human and financial resources employed.

The Australian quarantine and inspection service-AQIS-was established in October 1986 within the Department of Primary Industry, combining quarantine and inspection responsibilities. Its corporate brief includes review of the relevance, cost-effectiveness, and efficiency of all inspection and quarantine policy operations.

The Senate Committee recommendations are being assessed, and as appropriate actioned, in this light. The Queensland Department of Primary Industries is jointly involved in the exercise. Other recent reports such as that by the joint committee of public accounts also have a bearing on the process.

Full review of Torres Strait quarantine arrangements thus goes well beyond the specific problem areas highlighted in the Senate Committee report. Issues being addressed, along with the Committee's recommendations, include:
Clear delineation of the Torres Strait region for administrative control purposes. This includes the major points of mainland entry and the question of buffer arrangements;
Better co-ordination and rationalisation of quarantine control arrangements and staffing resources in the area;
An appropriate joint administrative approach by AQIS and the Queensland Department of Primary Industries for control oversight and review, and operational forward planning;
Specific and clear instructions and guidelines for all staff, backed up by appropriate training packages;
Extension and publicity;
The scope for extending and formalising cooperative arrangements with other Commonwealth and State agencies with an involvement in the area; and
The involvement of the island co-ordinating council and islanders in quarantine control.

Final action on the individual recommendations of the Committee will of course be significantly influenced by the review process. Quarantine is, however, so critical to our welfare, that more immediate action is needed in some areas. The threats we face don't heed review timing.
Without prejudicing the review's outcome, action already taken or under way on a number of the issues raised by the Committee can be indicated.

The Committee has seen a need for annual meetings of the Torres Strait Joint Advisory Council. The Government supports regular meetings but considers timing should be flexible to cope with pressing issues as they arise. Existing Torres Strait Treaty provisions provide this flexibility. Significantly, a regular quarterly pattern of liaison meetings between Australian and Papua New Guinea officials has been recommenced, under article 18 of the Treaty. These aim at practical cooperation at the local working level on treaty matters, including quarantine.

On the recommendation that the Treaty's quarantine provisions should be reviewed within four years, the Government again prefers a more flexible approach. Amendments should be pursued as a need is identified, and not tied to a specific time frame. The Government is keeping a continuous and close watch on the effectiveness and implementation of treaty provisions. The Treaty provides a consultative mechanism on matters of concern. As and when the need for any changes is identified this course will be followed.

The Committee has highlighted the need to increase islander community awareness of the Torres Strait Treaty and quarantine. Both Australian and Papua New Guinea authorities are currently working on a comprehensive information program in this light. A variety of information media is involved including printed material, radio broadcasts, video presentations and other extension activities. The involvement of islanders and the use of local languages is planned.

Turning to more specific concerns, the Committee's report focuses on the increasing threat to our livestock and poultry industries posed by screw-worm fly, present in the Western Province of Papua New Guinea, and by Newcastle disease, which has in the past occurred in Irian Jaya.

The possibility, and practicability, of increased screw-worm fly monitoring in the Torres Strait area is being addressed. In relation to the livestock free zone, construction of the northern stock-proof fence is now complete. Development of management arrangements for the zone, which will be the responsibility of the Queensland Department of Primary Industries, is in hand. This will include a sentinel cattle herd at Bamaga.
One of the recommendations was that the adequacy of the CSIRO's sterile screw-worm fly production facility to cope with a screw-worm fly outbreak be assessed.

In 1983-84 the Department of Primary Industry assumed funding control responsibilities for the unit, which is located in Papua New Guinea. It is staffed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Equipment has been upgraded to an operational response level by addition of larval rearing equipment and a large capacity irradiator.

The possibility of a mass rearing and insect release trial program starting in 1987-88 is being examined. This is an essential component in maintaining the operational response capability of the unit. It would also provide training opportunities in control procedures.

Annual activity plans aimed at operational readiness are in train. An emergence facility to hatch flies from irradiated pupae will be tested and placed at Townsville later this year for rapid field deployment should an outbreak occur.

In relation to Newcastle disease, Queensland authorities have established a serological and virological monitoring program covering the more vulnerable northern areas. The program includes sentinel flocks on several islands in the Strait.

Surveys of plant pests exotic to Australia have been carried out in the Straits. An assessment of the risk of them entering the mainland, the potential economic impact of such entry, and the broader question of whether current plant quarantine controls are adequate, will be addressed as part of the joint review.

As indicated earlier, the Committee has also identified a range of issues of more general concern, and mostly of an administrative nature. While these will generally be taken up during the review, Australia has already approached Papua New Guinea and Indonesia for a meeting of the Tripartite Committee on Animal Health and Quarantine. Papua New Guinea has indicated agreement in principle and I understand the matter is under consideration by relevant indonesian departments and agencies.

The Minister for Primary Industry has already arranged for the Quarantine Act 1908 to be amended to overcome the anomaly identified in the report that there is no power to search luggage on ships and aircraft coming to Australian ports from the protected zone. As a matter of priority he is investigating the question of more appropriate controls on movement of live animals or goods.

Finally, the Committee is commended for its initiative in seeking and conducting its inquiry, and for the thoroughness it has applied to the task. Quite aside from the inquiry's value in identifying and highlighting specific concern areas, it has served to heighten public, and parliamentary, awareness of our vulnerability in a quarantine sense and the critical need for continued vigilance.
