DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO CHAMBERLAIN CONVICTIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

With all respect, I begin by congratulating Mr Justice Morling for the lucid, comprehensive and exhaustive review of the evidence which he has brought forward on the matter. I spoke on the adjournment on Tuesday and made a number of points which I do not propose to repeat, other than to say that, as will be well known as one of the people who for many years in this place worked towards gaining a commission of inquiry into the Chamberlain case, I am delighted not only that that inquiry was eventually held but also that the matters which were brought forward by the Innocence Committee, myself and other members of that Committee, including Sir Reginald Sholl and others, were the points which, after the inquiry, were shown to have been the relevant ones. In other words, I and others have always argued that certain points concerning blood in the car and damage to baby Azaria's jumpsuit were crucial in that they demolished the Crown's case. I am delighted to find that, after the calling of 87 additional witnesses, that has been the conclusion of the commissioner.

Again I would like to go over this matter. I seek to correct some statements made in the media, which are totally incorrect, that because Mr Justice Morling did not quash the convictions somehow he has pulled his punches on this matter. That is not true. On page 8 of Mr Justice Morling's report he defines his function as merely to see whether there had been in fact a miscarriage of justice. In the very moving and, I think, dramatic final words of his lengthy report he says that if the evidence presented to his commission had been presented to the original trial the judge at that trial would have had no option but to have directed the jury to acquit the Chamberlains of all the charges against them. He could hardly have gone further than that.

The question of what happens next is of vital importance not only to the Chamberlains but also to the people of this country because there is a precedent in this matter, just as there was a precedent, in the interests of all Australians, present and future, that if new evidence were found against a convicted person there should be a place in which it should be heard. Now there is a precedent that when a person has been found to be wrongly convicted that person is not left to the wolves. If there is evidence and reason for it, no legal technicality should prevent a complete quashing of the conviction against that person, if that is what the evidence states. Mr Justice Morling surely has made that clear enough.

Beyond that, the person is entitled to reasonable compensation not only for the enormous costs that they have incurred. When a person goes through the sort of ordeal that Mr Splatt or the Chamberlains have been through it is enormously expensive. I know that in the Chamberlain case it amounted to hundreds of thousands of dollars, much of which was advanced to them by other parties and which they regard as a loan that should be repaid. There is the question of the suffering of a person of no previous ill-repute-the mother of a family who goes on an innocent holiday and finds herself in the long nightmare that the Chamberlains found themselves in. I am delighted to have seen a statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that he feels that in all compassion and reasonableness compensation should be paid in this case. That, I think, is satisfactory.

Beyond that is another point. When I was in Europe last year I noticed that Mrs Chamberlain was known and was the subject of concern about Australia. There were people who knew who Lindy Chamberlain is but do not know who Bob Hawke is. If we muff this up now, if we allow ourselves to say that a pardon is good enough and that no compensation should be paid, we will make ourselves the vehicle of contempt for the whole of this planet. I can think of nothing which would attract the approbrium of sneers and Australia being seen as a really low grade community as a result of that kind of decision.

The Northern Territory Government ought to realise that the eyes of the world are on it. Like the Dreyfus case of the 1970s, this has been proven to be a case of the wrongful conviction of innocent people. That is something with which I suggest one should tamper at one's peril. Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and through honourable senators I ask the Northern Territory Government, if any influence can be brought upon it, to pass a Bill quickly quashing the Chamberlain convictions and give them that form of compensation which is legally and morally required and which is decently appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Mason's plea that a request be made-I make it on my behalf-to the Northern Territory Government that it take some action, whatever is necessary, to quash the convictions against Mr and Mrs Chamberlain and to provide them with some reasonable and fair monetary compensation, not that money can ever compensate them for what they have had to suffer, for the travesty of the injustice that has been done to them.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate His Honour Mr Justice T. R. Morling for a most incisive, clear and fascinating report. He certainly has put a massive amount of work into it. The report is clear, lucid and well indexed, and one is able to quickly search out the areas that might have been causing concern. It is an excellent report. I would like to have known what Morling thought about certain aspects of the report which perhaps do not relate directly to the proceedings and to the evidence but relate to some of the peripheral reasons why these prosecutions took place in the manner they did, why the charge of murder in the first place was made against this woman when the Northern Territory did not have the appropriate charge that it should have placed against her, and why the charge of murder was proceeded with instead of withdrawing the case right from the word go.

By that I refer to the crime of infanticide which is in existence in all the States-I believe it is now a crime in the Northern Territory, but it was not at the time she was charged. A woman who kills her child within the first 12 months of the child's birth can be charged with infanticide. That charge was not available to the Northern Territory Attorney-General. It did not exist as a criminal offence in the Northern Territory at the time, so Mrs Chamberlain was charged with murder. I would have thought that at that stage, because the Northern Territory laws did not provide for a crime of infanticide, that the Attorney-General should have acknowledged that the correct charge was infanticide and should not have proceeded with the charge of murder. However, that is what happened.

For those people who have been listening to the debate and who still have some concern about this poor unfortunate woman, I will read two sections from the report which should make it clear as to what this is all about. Mr Justice Morling states on page 20 of his report:

Mrs Chamberlain left the barbecue area carrying Azaria and followed by Aidan. She walked in the direction of her tent with the apparent intention of putting both children to bed. Her account of what then occurred was as follows. She returned to the tent, and placed the baby, who was then asleep, in a bassinet and tucked her under the blankets. The bassinet was at the rear of the tent. Aidan said that he was still hungry so she went to the car and obtained a tin of baked beans. She returned to the tent and then went back to the barbecue area with Aidan. There is no doubt that Mrs Chamberlain did return to the barbecue area accompanied by Aidan and carrying a tin of baked beans.
So Mrs Chamberlain got a tin of baked beans from somewhere because the evidence was that she came back to the barbecue area with a tin of baked beans. The report continues.
Estimates of the length of time she was absent from the barbecue area varied at the trial from 5-10 minutes. When she returned to the barbecue area she appeared normal and composed.
Mr Justice Morling then states:
The Crown case was that during this short absence from the barbecue area, Mrs Chamberlain took Azaria from the tent into the car, sat in the front passenger seat and cut the baby's throat.

According to the Crown case she must have then stuffed the baby into a camera case. We do not know what happened to the camera that would normally have been in the case, because subsequently an independent person rode in that car that night and did not see any evidence of the blood or the body which was supposedly in the car. So the Crown said that the body must have been in the camera case. It is inconceivable. The Crown was then asked where the blood was that would have been all over the place. The Crown replied that she must have put on a track suit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unbelievably bizarre.

—Yes, unbelievably bizarre. She must have put on a tracksuit. During that five to ten minutes, she took the baby from the tent-she had been seen to take the baby there-put a tracksuit over her dress, took the baby into the car, cut the baby's throat, stuffed the baby into a camera case in such a way that there was no evidence that she had cut the baby's throat to be seen by a person who subsequently got into the motor car and sat in the front passenger seat while it was driven to a motel, and, having driven there, she went back to the tent, took off this tracksuit and then went back to the barbecue area-all in five to ten minutes.
—And opened a can of beans.

—And appeared normal while opening a can of beans. It is absolutely bizarre that this woman has been put through this trial on the basis that this was the Crown case-do not worry about what the defence was. Subsequently, she appeared in that tracksuit. She walked around in the tracksuit when it grew cold at night. She appeared in lighted areas in the tracksuit. No one noticed any blood on the tracksuit. Subsequently, back in Mount Isa, the tracksuit was sent to a drycleaner and someone there thought they might have seen some blood on it. Because of that, it is suggested that that is why she was wearing the tracksuit.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to what Mr Justice Morling says about this point. He went through the evidence about the tracksuit pants very carefully. I will read into the record his final conclusion in relation to the tracksuit pants:
I am far from satisfied that the tracksuit pants were blood stained. Indeed, on the whole of the evidence, I am of the view that the marks on the tracksuit pants were not blood stains.

So that is the end of that. It is bizarre to think that this woman has been put through this terrible trial and tribulation which has taken up eight years of her life. Not only did she lose her baby; she was charged with murder and spent a period in goal. Why was she gaoled? Allegedly it was because she was able to kill her baby within five minutes by cutting its throat. As Senator Mason says-I cannot think of a better word-it is a bizarre story. She has gone through all of this trial and tribulation. I congratulate His Honour Mr Justice Morling on bringing down a very fine report. I issue a heartfelt plea to the Government of the Northern Territory now to take some action to provide a proper and fair discharge of this couple's convictions and some reasonable compensation to them in monetary terms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to speak on the specific recommendations made by His Honour Mr Justice Morling, other than to say that I believe that this particular case is not yet concluded. I think that it would not be helpful to seek to add at this stage to what I think has been clearly expressed by the views of Senator Mason and others as to what might constitute a proper response on the part of the authorities in the Northern Territory. I do believe that there are a couple of points to be made, and I shall make them as briefly as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: The first is that it is perhaps useful to reflect upon the fact that it is still possible within the Australian judicial system as we know it, and the political system as we know it, for abuses of the processes of law, for outcomes which clearly are believed by people in the community to be unsatisfactory outcomes, to be further tested and not simply concluded in the way in which all of the original proceedings in this case were concluded. I pay particular tribute to those people around Australia who advocated in the most responsible and correct fashion that certain further steps should be taken after this matter had proceeded through all of the mechanisms available under the law of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the failure of the appellate court to consider new evidence.

—With respect, I ask Senator Mason to let me make the point that I am seeking to make on this matter. This is a case on which opinions-apart from those which have been pronounced ad nauseam by the media and authors-have been expressed by coroners, jurors, judges, including judges of the Federal Court of Australia and the High Court of Australia, and now by a special royal commissioner and politicians. Throughout the process a number of defects in the way in which the Australian legal system operates have been exposed. At the end of the day, it was necessary to take political action to secure the protection of the rights of an Australian citizen. I was in the process of paying tribute to those-I include Senator Mason, my very old and dear friend William Charles Wentworth and members of the Seventh Day Adventist community in New South Wales and throughout Australia-who worked through the processes available in a free and open democratic society to expose the defects which exist in the Australian legal system and to have those defects constantly brought to the attention of the Parliament and, eventually, to secure some justice in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of recommendations which flow from what Mr Justice Morling had to say need attention. Senator Mason has correctly, by way of interjection, identified one of them, namely the artificial restrictions placed by the legal system upon the operation of the legal system and, in particular, the rights of appellate courts to look at new evidence. That matter must be addressed. I do not propose to say anything more than the fact that it must be addressed. I want to take two or three minutes to relate to one other matter and that is the unsatisfactory nature of the way in which scientific evidence is handled and the way in which lay persons are not properly assisted by the existing judicial system to understand scientific evidence presented to them in an adversarial situation. Science, inherently, is not an adversarial matter; it is not a matter of simply putting forward those parts of the scientific evidence that one likes and excluding those parts of it one does not like and then having somebody else do the reverse-that is, presenting his scientific evidence and expecting an adversarial backward and forward contest between sets of allegedly scientific evidence which have to be resolved in the minds not only of people who are expert in the field-I do not mind that-but also people who, because of the nature of the judicial process, are simply not given all the evidence that they ought to have.

Mr Justice Morling, in chapter 16 of his report, makes the point forcefully that in criminal cases, where the standard is that of proof beyond reasonable doubt, it is highly desirable that complex scientific evidence called by either the prosecution or the defence, should be put to a jury in a way which is not essentially adversarial. Stuart Tipple, a solicitor in New South Wales, won a prize in the 1986 Law Week Advance Bank young solicitors' essay competition by writing a paper entitled `Forensic Science: The New Trial by Ordeal'. Mr Tipple, in this excellent prize winning paper, drawing very largely upon the Splatt and Chamberlain trials, exposed quite clearly the way in which conflicting scientific evidence, even when it is brought before the High Court of Australia, nevertheless presents difficulty for people in reconciling and coming to significant conclusions. Increasingly, the sophistication of scientific evidence becomes more and more important in determining the outcome of criminal proceedings. We know that the new techniques that are being introduced for genetic markers and all the rest are making scientific evidence much more complicated and sophisticated yet much more central to the way in which a jury has to reach its verdict. What I believe should be one of the outcomes to which this Parliament could address itself is actually to undertake through one of its Senate or select committees an investigation of the numerous proposals that have been put forward in Australia and throughout the rest of the world for a more effective way of allowing scientific evidence to be assessed before it is presented to a jury-and hopefully to allow scientific evidence to be presented to a jury by somebody who is not one of the contending parties in the proceedings. The British and the Americans have considered the matter in detail and, as a result of Mr Justice Morling's findings, it has been clearly suggested that if we had a very prestigious national forensic laboratory--

TALK.START.PARA: —An institute.

—Yes, an institute. It does not matter whether it is located in Canberra and it does not matter who pays for it in the long run. It would be an institute that would not be beholden to the defence or to the prosecution; it would not seek to adduce evidence favourable to one side or the other in the conflict, but simply would be responsible for presenting, in a totally neutral way, to a judge, jury, commissioner or whoever the best possible analysis of the scientific issues that have to be raised in these proceedings. I think that that would be a substantial improvement in the whole of the judicial processes in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: My point, therefore, is that the Commonwealth Parliament, as a result of this inquiry, could well profitably undertake an inquiry as to whether a national forensic institute should be established and should play the role of the neutral adviser to courts and commissions when scientific evidence is central to proceedings, especially those that affect the rights of ordinary Australian citizens. If anything could be done by this Federal Parliament arising from Mr Justice Morling's report and recommendations, that is one of the undertakings that this Commonwealth Parliament could profitably consider in its next session. Progress on that score may well have been materially significant; just as it was in the Splatt case, so it was in the Chamberlain case. It could be a most worthwhile outcome of what otherwise has been a series of personal, legal, scientific and, in the end, community tragedies.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

DEBATE.TITLE: A CASE FOR CONSTITUTIONAL RECOGNITION OF LOCAL GOVERNMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I believe that constitutional recognition of local government is a very important step that must be taken some time in the very near future by the Australian Government. Local government is one of the most important areas of government and it has so far been completely dependent for funding upon the State governments. It has always been the first area to be cut in cases of major cuts in funding. More and more the Federal Government has moved social and community services into the care of local government organisations. More and more it has been expecting local government to raise its own funds through higher rates. In New South Wales the rate pegging operation has meant that local government has found itself squeezed between decreasing Federal grants and the inability to raise extra money from constituents in the local government areas, the ratepayers.

The Australian Democrats were instrumental, at the Australian Constitutional Convention in Brisbane, in suggesting recognition of local government as an integral part of the operation of Australia's system of government. It is extremely important that this should be followed through. It will require a referendum. I recommend to any government-whatever government is elected at the next election-that it should undertake to carry out such a referendum and endeavour to get a proper constitutional basis that will allow for this very important area of government to stand alone and to stand up against the pressures from both State and Federal funding bodies.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADJOURNMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mail-Medicare-Station Hands: Working Conditions-Bird Smuggling-Australian Democrats

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to deal with a few things, as briefly as possible. In particular I want to refer to the interesting activities of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party in the southern part of Sydney and into Wollongong. I have here a letter under the compliments slip of Stewart West, MHR, posted in Wollongong with `The Hon. S. J. West MHR' on the envelope. The letter is under the banner of the Australian Labor Party, Cunningham Federal Electorate Council and it starts with the words `Dear Comrade'. It deals with matters that are clearly of a party political nature and is signed not by Mr West, in whose envelope it was sent out and on whose franking machine it was despatched, but by someone called Graham Roberts, Hon. Secretary to the Cunningham Federal Electorate Council.

SPEECH.PARA: I have here an envelope marked `Senator A. T. Gietzelt', franked at Caringbah on the franking machine of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt. I also have a notice of a Labor women's meeting which was held on 23 May with the theme of `national social justice policy'. It was not in fact sent out by the Minister. His name does not appear on it. It was simply sent out in his envelopes, through his franking machine. Clearly, it is not official parliamentary business.

I have a similar letter addressed to someone else in Wollongong from the same organisation. I also have under the compliments slip of Peter Baldwin, MP-we all seem to be dealing with the left wing of the Labor Party tonight-a letter from the Central America Peace Coalition, signed not by Mr Baldwin, advertising a march on Saturday, 9 May, `Stop US intervention in Central America'. Among the people involved in this committee is the Committee in Solidarity with Central America and the Caribbean. We know about that of course. It was one of the Socialist Workers Party fronts that was exposed by the Waste Watch Committee as having received $52,000 under community employment program grants, which I presume was one of the reasons that the program was killed off by the Government as a result of the embarrassment involved in the Waste Watch Committee pointing out where so much of what was supposed to be long term unemployment money was in fact going to support those clearly political bodies. In that context it is interesting to note, as Senator Short did last night, the change in the immigration laws relating to visitors which says:

Now mere membership of, or an association with, an organisation which has at any time in the past advocated violence as a means of achieving political goals, will no longer constitute sufficient reason to refuse a visa.
I suggest that the objectives of some of these organisations appear to involve a touch of violence, and no doubt people who support them feel comfortable in that environment.

I wish now to deal with something entirely different, and that is a serious problem relating to the health care of handicapped children. When Medicare was introduced the Federal Government effectively advised the population that it could give up its private health insurance as Medicare would fulfil all its needs through the public hospital system. As a result, the insured population fell from about 70 per cent to about 50 per cent within six months of the inception of Medicare. Most of these people were the young and healthy of marriageable age and child bearing age. When Medicare was introduced private health funds brought in a pre-existing condition rule which gave no hospital benefits for 12 months to anyone with a pre-existing condition. Immediately a developmentally disabled child is born, it has a pre-existing condition and the parents cannot receive benefit for 12 months. Many parents believe therefore that their position is hopeless as they need time immediately a child is born rather than when 12 months has elapsed.

As from 1 March this year, in spite of the highest historical cost increases which occurred over the previous 12 months, hospital rebates were reduced by the health funds after Dr Blewett set the basic hospital rebate rate at $155 for 14 days and $125 thereafter. This is a drop in income of $29 a day after a patient has been in hospital for 14 days, as the previous rebate was $154 a day over the complete period of hospitalisation.

A reduction in rebate after 14 days is not unreasonable for surgical patients in hospitals as the average length of stay is two or three days. However, for non-surgical patients 14 days is not even an average length of stay. After a patient has been in hospital for 35 days, a certificate is required under section 3b of the Health Insurance Act to be issued by the attending doctor, indicating that continuing care is needed in hospital. This certificate is sent to the health fund with the hospital claim and the certificate is referred to an acute care advisory committee formed by the Commonwealth Government authority in each State.

Prior to January this year no 3b certificate was ever revoked by the ACAC. The Minister had instructed his delegate in New South Wales that no 3b certificate for any child under 16 should be revoked. From January, however, that instruction was apparently withdrawn and the acute care advisory committee has commenced revoking 3b certificates in respect of profoundly and severely developmentally disabled babies and infants. Revocation of the 3b certificate means effectively that the child should not be in hospital. When a certificate is revoked the fund benefit falls to $84 a day and it is absolutely impossible to run any hospital and to give even minimal care and treatment for these babies and infants at that rate of hospital rebate, I am informed by people in the industry. The criteria used for revoking 3b certificates are totally inappropriate for babies and infants who need 24-hour intensive care.

I have received complaints from parents of children at at least one hospital in Sydney, and I have been advised by other people that they are also extremely concerned, because there is now a risk that these hospitals, which provide specialised care for very small disabled children, will be forced to close. Of course, this is a matter of major seriousness. I wish to quote from a letter that one of the parents has received from such a hospital.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the name of the hospital?
—We can deal with that when we come to it. I was asked by the parent not to reveal the parent's name. In the circumstances, I suppose the hospital's name could be revealed.
—Is it a big public hospital or a small private hospital?

—No, it is a specialised hospital called the Allowah Babies Hospital in Dundas. I was being reticent only because I had been asked not to reveal the name of the parent. I am not blaming the hospital for sending the letter, but it states:

SPEECH.PARA: We refer to Erin's hospitalization at this hospital which is still current and to a copy letter dated 15th April 1987 from the relevant health insurance fund, the MBF, advising you that the acute care certificate (3B Certificate) covering the period 30/1/87 to 31/1/87 was revoked by the Commonwealth Department of Health.

There has consequently been a shortfall in payment by the MBF to this hospital for those 2 days in January of $59.15 per day viz. $118.30. The Certificate for 1/1/87 to 30/1/87 was apparently accepted.

That claim was sent to the MBF on 9//2/87 and although we had been verbally advised by the Acute Care Advisory Committee (ACAC) that no certificate would be revoked retrospectively, such revocation has taken place, and it took some 2 1/2 months for advice to be sent to you and ourselves.

Claims have been submitted for February, March and April, and will be submitted for the current month of May and we must bring to your attention the financial implications of further revocations taking place, which would amount by shortfalls in payment to this hospital of approximately $1,774.50 per month.

These implications are, of course, quite horrendous because, as you are aware, Erin suffers from micro- cephaly, profound developmental delay, recurrent fitting, consistent major urinary tract infections, and is a severe problem feeder and severe problem drinker.
The letter goes on to state:

In view of the discriminatory actions of the Acute Care Advisory Committee it is difficult for us to form any other conclusion than that it is the policy of the Federal and State Governments to ensure closure of this facility which has served the community of New South Wales and beyond for well over 30 years.

We have already heard that Eaton's Babies Hospital, the only other hospital in New South Wales which has similar characteristics as Allowah, was forced into closing on the 16th March by the same method. If Allowah is forced into a similar situation, both you, and the New South Wales community in general will lose a much needed and first class resource for such babies and infants.

I have here a whole list of statements-I will not go through them-by leading paediatricians and specialists in this area expressing very grave concern and also expressing their confidence in the standard of care that has always been maintained at this hospital. They include the staff specialists at the Prince of Wales Children's Hospital, Gillian Turner; P. G. Procopis, Acting General Superintendent of the Royal Alexandra Hospital for Children; a paediatrician, Dr A. Greenberg of Greenwich, and from Dr David Starte, from the Chatswood Assessment Centre who says:
. . . it would be devastating for many families to be stripped of the possibility of such high standard nursing care and intensive developmental therapy, when they need a helping hand.
Even the Department of Health, Southern New South Wales Metropolitan region Senior Medical Officer, Elizabeth Wilkinson, has written saying:
There is currently no other facility in N.S.W. providing this type or quality of care to this age group.

The adequate care of this relatively small number of children is extremely cost effective in that it reduces family stress, secondary breakdown of family units, and breakdown of the mental and physical health of individual family members.

Laurel House, a unit of the Cumberland Area Health Service, Dr Vivian Bayl, a paediatrician, and Dr Helen Walsh add their weight. A report from the Review of Acute Care Needs of Developmentally Disabled Children in New South Wales said:
The Review Team noted that the care provided by Allowah Babies Hospital was of an exceptionally high standard.

So we have here the undeniable proposition that there is a need for this hospital. Only a relatively small number of people are involved. It is a matter of great significance, and I understand there has been consistent pressure brought to bear on the Department on this matter. I understand I am not bringing it to the Department's attention for the first time, and all I do is ask the Special Minister of State (Senator Tate) to refer to his colleague this matter of great concern.

I also raise in relation to health issues the matter of a gentleman named Mr Fred Goodfellow. Mr Goodfellow stood against me, I might say, as an Australian Democrat candidate in the seat of Macarthur some time ago. Naturally, he lost-unfortunately at the time so did I. He believes he should be eligible for Medicare cover for problems relating to his disability because he was not relevantly compensated under the damages award for future medical expenses. Mr Goodfellow had an aircraft accident in 1979 while in the Royal Australian Navy, and became a paraplegic. He was discharged in 1980, and sued for damages. He was awarded $187,000 because the RAN was found to be 75 per cent at fault, there being 25 per cent contributory negligence. Therefore, the Commonwealth is still liable to compensate him for 25 per cent of expenses relating to his disability.

From 1981 onwards he has been continually ill due to an unknown cause, and in December 1984 he broke his leg falling over his wheelchair. On submitting claims to Medicare he truthfully admitted that he had received damages and signed a declaration accordingly. In February 1985 he received a form letter informing him that because of his claim for damages on the Commonwealth he was not entitled to Medicare cover. At that time he was ill with a temperature and was confined to bed with twice daily nursing care. Because of his general poor health and resulting psychological condition he did not seek medical attention due to his inability to meet his medical costs. In July 1985 he suffered complications and was hospitalised for 10 days. The resultant medical accounts are still outstanding. In November 1985, on the strong advice of doctors and nurses, he was admitted to the Royal North Shore Hospital for three months and one week for surgery and recovery involving the removal of infected bone that was causing all the problems. On 4 November 1985 Mr Goodfellow wrote to the Minister for Health requesting that the Minister determine that he was eligible for Medicare cover under the Health Insurance Act. The Minister had all the information to make a decision, but no decision was made. This matter has gone on and on. In May 1986 he had a broken upper right femur, and the doctors' bills are still unpaid.

This man is an ex-serviceman, and it is disturbing that on 1 May he sent his last correspondence to the Department of Health asking for acknowledgment of various letters he had written and again asking for a decision with which he could at least agree or attack. He now has medical bills to the tune of $3,000, which he is currently paying off at $150 a month. He claims he pays his Medicare levy through his defence force retirement and death benefits pension yet he is not entitled to a benefit except for conditions that are not in any way related to his disability. I do believe the Government should look at this matter very closely. He has been most unfairly treated, and I request the Government to take action.

I turn to the last point I wish to raise. The Senate will be aware that I criticised the use by a Mr John Wright, the Labor candidate for the Federal seat of Gilmore, of facilities in the Australian Taxation Office, where he works, some time ago. I recognise the fact that the Commissioner of Taxation acted promptly and withdrew those facilities from Mr Wright so that he could no longer improperly use government facilities for his election campaign for the Federal seat of Gilmore against Mr John Sharp, the outstandingly effective National Party member for that seat.

I am disturbed to see that Mr John Wright, the endorsed Australian Labor Party candidate for Gilmore, is raising in his political activities tax issues relating to individual people. Under the heading `Liberal Treasurer not to pay tax-Wright', Mr Wright said that the Liberal Party National Treasurer, John Elliott, is a wonderful patriot when he wants to move his company's operations overseas in order to escape paying 10c in the dollar tax. The substance of whether Mr Elliott wants to move his companies off-shore does not relate to the heading `Liberal Treasurer not to pay tax'. I would have thought that Mr Wright, being an employee of the Australian Taxation Office, would have been particularly careful about saying anything about anybody in relation to taxation matters. I suggest it would be a much wiser and more reasonable course if he restrained himself from writing misleading headings relating to tax and kept his nose, as a Tax official, out of the tax matters of his political opponents while he is in this particularly delicate position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not detain the Senate long tonight on a matter which I regard as very important in the wake of the recent tragic deaths of two young jackaroos in Western Australia. I raise another example of young people being placed in extremely vulnerable positions by working on outback stations. My comments have general relevance to young people in all walks of life and in a number of industries around this country who, without the protection of trade unions, would have no bargaining power and in some cases-as in this case-would be left at risk by the actions of irresponsible and uncaring employers.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to a young man called Glen Chapman from Lithgow who, with six other young men from New South Wales, was recruited via an advertisement which he answered to work at Wave Hill property in the Northern Territory. This station did not give any indication to those young men as to what conditions they would be working under when they went there, but the young men were keen; they wanted a life in the outback and thought there was some vocation in front of them. After these young men answered the advertisement bus tickets were sent to them and they made their way to Wave Hill station. On arrival there they were told, much to their surprise, that they would be sent further out on the station, camping outdoors for two months in conditions which they later found to be quite unpalatable and extremely tough and rigorous for young people in that occupation for the first time. They brought their own sleeping blankets, but groundsheets were provided. They later found out that the cost of them was deducted from their first pay from Wave Hill station.

This young man lasted two weeks on the trail. He objected, not loudly or vociferously, to the conditions that he was working under; he just thought that the life was not for him. He was not exactly a young city greenhorn; he had some experience in manual labour, and he was keen and willing to try a new job. The station accepted him on that basis. In his last week at the station he was allowed to work with a family further out on another part of the station mending fences. The interesting and rather tragic point is that he was told virtually that the station had no responsibility for him after that; once he had worked long enough to pay off his debts he would be allowed to leave. The cost of the groundsheet, stores, food and so on and any other items given to him by the station to protect him from the environment was deducted from his wage. At the end of three weeks he had worked long enough to pay off everything he owed to the station and he decided that he would leave. At that stage the station gave him no assistance whatsoever, not even a lift to the nearest hotel or town.

This young man of 18 to 19 was allowed to leave the property and make his way to the nearest pub which was more than 100 kilometres or so away at Top Springs. He arrived at the hotel, having walked and finally hitched a ride with a group of Aborigines. The publican, I believe, was extremely kind and generous to him and arranged for him to find work for about two weeks on a nearby property. This young man was not a slacker or bludger by any means and was not totally without experience in this type of environment back in Lithgow. Of course, there is a long distance between Lithgow and Wave Hill in the Northern Territory.

Finally, the young man made his way home. That salutary experience that he had in the outback he communicated to his parents who then wrote to me via the honourable member for Calare, Mr David Simmons, who has a very real interest in employment for young people in country areas. He has been known for a long time as a battler in matters such as this. Mr Simmons contacted me and the letter was written. I am extremely concerned for a number of reasons: First of all, the fact that these young people were not given a clear indication of their responsibilities and the nature of the work they would have to undertake when they arrived at Wave Hill; and secondly, the fact that their wages and conditions were not outlined in any way at all. Once those vulnerable people were on the station they had no alternative but to give up the job, lose money and make their own way back.

I raise this matter because of the tragic consequences in a similar situation that occurred in Western Australia where two young jackaroos were found dead on the track when they decided to make their way home and were lost. I mention it because it shows the vulnerability of young people in a number of areas and the importance of having trade unions to protect them. After some discussions last week, today I rang the secretary of the Queensland branch of the Australian Workers Union, Mr Errol Hodder, who is noted for his very broad views about the responsibilities of the trade union movement and who runs a very efficient and effective trade union in that state. That union covers a very large proportion of workers of all kinds in Queensland. Mr Hodder informed me that his union will be taking immediate action to make sure that any young people, regardless of whether they are unionised, who find themselves in this vulnerable situation will be able to get to the nearest phone to ring the union to indicate their plight, ask for advice and make inquiries, for example about their wages and conditions and their rights as ordinary citizens. He has also indicated to me that he believes that special awards should be sought for young jackaroos working in this situation. Those awards exist in some States but there is no award coverage, as I understand it, in Western Australia where those two young people died recently.

Mr Hodder intends to insert into the changed award conditions in his State a request that young people be supplied with certain means of communication, such as radio. At this stage we should be looking at making a telephone available. Obviously, there is a problem because some employers in outback areas have total control over their workers, make access to phones very difficult and certainly do not encourage young people working in that environment to make a telephone call to a trade union.

I will end on this note: I believe that there may well be other tragedies in the outback and other cases of young people being exploited unless people start to realise that when they send their sons, and in some cases their daughters, into those areas they ought to be looking for the protection of the relevant trade union. The Australian Workers Union has indicated to me that it has 19 centres in Queensland, for example, to which a call can be made and union assistance sought. But it brings home to all of us, the rights, role and responsibilities of trade unions in our community. If young people or vulnerable employees are left to deal directly with employers, on many occasions without a trade union to intervene on their behalf and represent them, these people will be exploited. The strengths are very much in favour of employers in this area. The attacks on the trade union movement that are going on around the country at the moment by the Liberal Party will be shown to be totally false. If the use of the trade union movement is criticised in this country to such an extent that people will no longer have confidence in trade unions and young people, for example, will not go to trade unions for assistance, I believe the Liberal Party will be doing a great disservice in turning people away from what is a very important institution in our society and one on which the lives of some young people may well depend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate my speech in Hansard to save the time of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The subject I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate is one which I have raised on several occasions in recent months. Last year an incident occurred at Sydney Airport resulting in the arrest of two people on charges of attempted bird smuggling. The responsible Minister, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has attempted to provide me with the answers as best as his Department is able to. I am sorry therefore that, despite my efforts and those of the Minister, the matter is still not resolved. The Minister has informed me that the matter is now before the Director of Public Prosecutions and because of that I do not wish in any way to influence the case or comment directly on it. However there are aspects of the whole situation about which I am concerned.

It would appear that a case has been thoroughly prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. What I am concerned about is the apparent length of time it is taking in the Director's office for a decision to be made on the matter. I am aware the Director would have a great many cases to handle. However, I am very concerned that justice is not only done but also seen to be done. This is not an offence such as non-payment of parking fines. The question of smuggling-both in and out of Australia-is a very serious crime. It has a great many implications for our wildlife, for the protection of our very important disease free status. Any illegal movements in or out of Australia involving animals puts at risk that vital health status. Attempts to take Australian wildlife out of Australia are very serious crimes. As a result of my work with the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare I have been told many stories of illegal flights in and out of Australia carrying wildlife. Therefore I would hope that the apparent delay within the Director of Public Prosecutions' office is due simply to a backlog of work within that office and not because the Director considers the matter to be of so little significance as not to warrant a high priority.

There are a great many people in the community and particularly within industries that involve Australian wildlife that are anxious that any malpractices within their industries be stamped out and penalties imposed that will deter people from resorting to illegal means to obtain or sell their products. As I said I do not wish to prejudice in any way any case currently with the public prosecutor but in fairness to everyone involved in the issue, I would hope that the matter can soon be finalised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon in the Senate I made some comments about the South Australian division of the Australian Democrats and explained my reasons for dissociating myself from that division of the Party. I wish to amplify my comments and incorporate in Hansard the letter I sent to the South Australian division of the Australian Democrats which seems to have been misrepresented in the Press, as evidenced by the Press clippings I have received. I seek leave to incorporate the letter in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
The Senate
The Secretary
South Australian Division,
Australian Democrats.
2 June 1987
Dear Sandra,

In view of the impending double dissolution of the Parliament which has forced me to an election earlier than my natural term, and according to the Divisional Regulation balloted March 1982 which reads as follows:
``In the event of a double dissolution of a Parliament, any Australian Democrat upper house politician forced to an election shall be placed in the top position on the AD team if they so wish.'',
I request that I be placed in one of the two top positions on the South Australian Australian Democrat team of Senate candidates to contest the forthcoming election.
Subsequently a further clarifying regulation was passed in a ballot closing 30 July 1982, which stated that
``In the event of a double dissolution of a Parliament where more than one sitting member has been forced to an election the Council be given the right to elect the order on the ticket.''
In accordance with these Regulations and the Rule passed by Council as an Upper House preselection guideline in January 1984, and which is interpreted as a Rule under the Constitution, namely
``In the event of a double dissolution situation, the position on the team of any sitting member/s will be determined by a special meeting of Council called specifically for that purpose.'',

I request that the special meeting of Council called for 3 June 1987 do so determine my position on the team according to the Regulations quoted above. I unfortunately cannot attend this meeting as I am required in Canberra where Bills for which I am responsible are to be debated under guillotine.

I consider the the chances of gaining a second Senate seat for the Australian Democrats in this coming full-Senate election in South Australia will be greatly enhanced by a ticket with Janine and myself at the top. The preselection for a half-Senate election was held concurrently with the leadership ballot, despite my request that it be deferred until the results of that ballot were known. Once Janine was elected leader, I preferred to not oppose her in preselection for a half-Senate election, but to seek an alternative position where the party could better use me, such as standing in the A.C.T.
I bring to the ticket considerable electoral support from community groups complementary to those who have traditionally supported Janine.

My portfolio responsibilities in Science and Technology have earned me the personal support of professional engineering and scientific bodies, as well as students and academics; as the only South Australian Senator who is a farmer, I have a strong following in rural areas; as a small business and industry spokesperson I have developed a lot of support amongst the small business community; my work in local government has led to my becoming well-known throughout the state; as the only Senator born in continental Europe I have strong support from the various ethnic communities in the state; I have also earned the respect of environmental and peace groups for my successful representation and achievements in these areas.

The practical physical resources of a sitting Senator, as well as my own office facilities, will be invaluable to the party in a campaign. I am able to campaign effectively as as sitting Senator in South Australia while Janine must fulfil her national responsibilities.
A speedy decision on this matter will enable us all to get a successful campaign underway without delay.
Yours Faithfully
DAVID VIGOR

TALK.START.PARA: —Because I was working in the Senate, I wrote to the South Australian division and pointed out its constitutional responsibilities to organise the ticket in South Australia with Janine Haines and me at the top of the ticket. It did not fulfil this constitutional duty. This was the last of a large number of similar problems which had developed within the South Australian division and which initially led to the resignation from the Party of Mr Lance Milne. It later resulted in the forced removal from the top of the South Australian Legislative Council ticket in 1985 of Donald Chisholm by a process of attrition which was quite uncharacteristic of the early days of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Australian Democrats were founded the Party was based on democratic principles of openness and fair dealing, with honesty, tolerance and compassion as guiding principles. The original Party was made up of people who sought to change Australia and world politics, promote peace and prosperity and to secure the future for forthcoming generations. The Party placed strong emphasis on strength through co-operation and understanding, making the best use of everybody's talents and achieving consensus policies which worked for the good of everyone. In the early days Party members worked together enthusiastically with mutual trust and appreciation to merge together as many different people and parties as possible, aiming to bring to government a working multi-partisan team with effective management and efficient business control of the affairs of the country.

That original openness and factual dealing in South Australia have become closed rumour-mongering. The honesty, tolerance and compassion have been replaced with introverted suspicions of anybody who falls mildly outside the expected dedication to a number of fairly narrow views. Instead of representative management there has been a complete inability to separate administration from politics. Where elected candidates did not suit the administrators they were pressured in unpleasant ways to stand down for more suitable people. This type of process has, in fact, also happened in other divisions such as New South Wales, where Liz Kirkby was similarly approached, and in Western Australia where Richard Jeffreys, who was top of the ticket, is no longer top of the ticket.

Where policy was not to the liking of the party leaders, attempts were made to prevent democratic discussion and balance. Eventually, official policy that everyone who does not agree should get out made meetings so uncomfortable and unpleasant that people left and control has passed to those who enjoy the unpleasantness, the rumours and the closet decisions. In other words, all these problems of the major political parties are concentrated into a microcosm. This, indeed, is the reason that I feel that there is a need at this stage to look at a new way of approaching politics. That is the reason why I have taken the stand which I have taken and dissociate myself from the South Australian Division and am offering myself as a candidate for the Senate at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Senator Vigor elaborated on the reasons for his resignation from the South Australian Division of the Australian Democrats. Senator Brownhill incorporated his speech and I am therefore not aware of its contents. Senator Aulich, speaking on the death of two jackeroos, touched on a quite tragic theme and very neatly turned it to demonstrate not only the utility but very real vital necessity of unions in the defence of employees in vulnerable situations.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Michael Baume demonstrated his political ineptitude by concentrating firstly on rather trivial and feeble instances of, as he saw it, misuse of facilities. But he did so preceding what is his major responsibility as the Opposition spokesman on health matters. He spoke then of a children's hospital in New South Wales and the problems of a particular constituent in regard to health treatment. I would have thought that an Opposition spokesman on health matters would have given that matter priority in his remarks on the final adjournment debate for this parliamentary session. But, as we have seen with Senator Michael Baume, who has not asked a question in relation to health all this week, he is very good at Press releases, but when it comes to Question Time or real debate on health issues he has failed miserably.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 24 March 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Education aware of the contents of the `Orientation Week Handbook' produced by the Students' Association of the Australian National University.
(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the 5-page section on drugs, contained in this publication.

(3) Does the Minister accept the view that the material in the booklet, on drugs, would be capable of giving students, particularly first-year students, a false impression as to the dangers involved in drug taking.
(4) Are the views expressed in the document consis- tent with the Federal Government's approach to dissemination of information of drugs, through, for example, the `Drug Offensive' campaign.

(5) Does the Minister believe that the publication represents a proper and beneficial use of students' money, contributed in the form of the General Services Fee paid by all under-graduate students at the ANU.

(6) Does the Minister accept that students at the ANU should have the option of refusing to contribute to such publications, through the provision of the General Services Fee, if so, what steps will the Minister take to see that this option is made available.

(7) In what circumstances, if any, would the Minister feel it appropriate to intervene in such publications, in the interest of young people, who might be on the receiving end of inadequate and, indeed, dangerous misinformation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) I agree that the material is an unacceptable way of providing information to students or anyone about drug using behaviour. It is written in a way which glamorises drug use as an acceptable recreational pursuit and minimises the harmful effects of misuse of drugs.

(4) The views expressed on drug use in the `ANU Orientation Handbook' have nothing to do with the efforts being made by all Australian Governments to reduce harmful drug use through the Drug Offensive. Because of the specific need to ensure students are provided with accurate information about drug use, the Commonwealth Department of Health, the Drug Offensive and the Australian Medical Association have prepared the booklet `Your Body-Just the Facts'. Over 180,000 copies were produced for school leavers and tertiary students. The booklet canvasses health issues, including harmful drug use, common health issues, contraception, AIDS and Sexually Transmitted Diseases. The Australian Medical Association is responsible for the distribution of the booklet. My Department was advised by the Commonwealth Department of Health that a number of copies have been sent to the ANU Health Centre and that more copies are available on request.
I have forwarded copies of the booklet to the Honourable Senator and have made copies available to other Senators and members through the Parliamentary Library.

(5), (6) and (7) The Australian National University has power under its Act to make statutes on the payment to the University of fees payable in respect of the provision to students of amenities or services that are not of an academic nature and of an organisation of students, or of students and other persons.

As the University is an autonomous tertiary education institution under the governance of its Council, this is not a matter which comes directly under my control. However, I have drawn the Honourable Senator's question and my answer to the notice of the Vice-Chancellor of the University.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Primary Industry: Advertising Agencies and Public Relations Consultants

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 29 April 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What advertising agencies and public relations consultants have been engaged by the Department for the 1984-85, 1985-86 and the current financial years.
(2) What was/is the value of those contracts.
(3) On what projects were/are they engaged.
(4) What selection criteria were used for their appointment.
(5) Who in the Department was/is responsible for formulating the selection criteria and the final selection of the successful agency/consultant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The advertising agency, Fountain Huie Fish Pty Ltd has been engaged by the Department in the years 1984-85, 1985-86 and 1986-87.
No other advertising agency or public relations consultants have been engaged in this period.

(2) The agency is remunerated for its production costs and head hour costs following standard Government procedures administered by the Information Co-ordination Branch, Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism. Payments made to Fountain Huie Fish for the three financial years are as follows:
(3) The projects the agency has been engaged on in the three years are:
(a) Plant Quarantine Publicity
(b) National Quarantine Publicity
(c) `Rural Policy Action' leaflet series (1986-87 only).
(4) The selection criteria used were the normal Government procedures for advertising agencies as administered by the Information Co-ordination Branch, Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism.

(5) Officers of my Department's Public Relations Section, in conjunction with the Information Co-ordination Branch of the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism were responsible for the selection of the agency.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 30 April 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How are advertising contracts arranged within the Department of Finance.
(2) If they are not arranged with the Department, how are they arranged.
(3) If another Department undertakes arrangements for the Department's advertising, what is the procedure and under what guidelines are the contracts made.
(4) Are these procedures uniform with arrangements made by other Departments in respect of their advertising contracts.
(5) How long have existing arrangements for advertising contracts been in practice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Advertising arrangements within the Department of Finance consist of:
recruitment advertisements placed with the Commonwealth Gazette Officer; and
a once per year graduate recruitment advertisement placed directly with a limited number of campus newsletters
(2) In general advertising is arranged through Neville Jeffress Australia Pty Ltd, the master agency authorised by the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism.

Advertisements inviting expressions of interest for the supply of items not covered by a Commonwealth/State Government contract are arranged through the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services (DOLGAS).
(3) The procedure for advertising for the supply of non contract items is:
originate a procurement demand, form No. M17
prepare a requisition for supply, form No. 11
forward the procurement demand form to DOLGAS for subsequent gazettal and if required media advertising through the authorised master agency.
The guidelines for the foregoing procedure are:
Finance Regulation 46/47
Finance Direction 25/23
Finance Circulars 1984/16 and 1985/10
Commonwealth Purchasing Manual Reg. 3.2b
Personnel Management Manual Vol. 7
(4) Yes, according to advice provided by DOLGAS.
(5) Regulations covering existing arrangements came into effect in November 1982 (Finance Regulation 46/47 refers).
